Actually, they are not bad in this respect but I would recommend washing these first since they are a little stiff (probably some treatment to keep them from just wrinkling in the package).  Surprisingly, even though these were packed tightly in a plastic pouch and had been for who knows how long, there were few wrinkles or nasty creases.As these good curtains?  For $10, yes.  For over twice that amount the investment is somewhat questionable.

I was pleasantly surprised upon receiving this pendant/necklace.  Most times you get a frail chain along with a pendant that requires a magnifying glass to see.If I had to venture a quick guess, I’d state this is over an inch from point to point and is well finished and presented.  No rough edges and the polish is nicely done.  It hangs nicely without binding on the chain.About my only gripes involve the box and chain.  The former is the usual cardboard with felt affair so plan on getting something better if you plan on giving this as a gift while the latter comes with a “squint and fidget” clasp that must have been designed by a sadist.All thing considered, a good choice for an inexpensive piece of jewelry to add to your informal collection.

Nicely made and constructed silk boxer short that fits exactly as the size states with about 25% leeway because of the elastic band.Front button flap stays closed and doesn't appear to wave or bunch up while you're wearing it; however, if there is one flaw it belongs to the fabric and lack of lining.  This is a somewhat sheer (thin may be another word) garment so you'd better really like the person you're wearing it for or be a bachelor with the window blinds closed because any light from behind will expose what you're trying to hide.Otherwise, a nice pair of boxer shorts

Over the years I’ve used a wide variety of Kensington keyboards but this is first convertible unit that can operate via USB or Bluetooth.As designs go, this is best described as a full-sized unit, typical of what you might find with a desktop computer or in an office.  It has the ubiquitous numerical keypad to the right along with a complement of F1 through F12 keys above the standard keys.About the only major differences belong to the keys and overall thickness. The keys are chicklet instead of the usual raised keys you might find on a generic keyboard and the thickness is in the category of svelte (read below about the battery hump).Construction appears top notch with a black matte finish that seems to wear better than the usual glossy you find.In keeping with the market share tradition, this unit is clearly marked for Windows users with the Microsoft flag taking prominent position near the space key.  If you’re wondering, there are no secondary markings for any other OS such as OS X, Android, Chrome, etc.While this unit is ultra thin there is a prominent hump in the back for battery storage and while this may look ungainly at first it does serve secondary duty as an elevator (of sorts) that keeps the keyboard at a nice upward angle.  Even with batteries installed (2 AA, included) this is still a lightweight unit.  I did find it somewhat odd that pop-out elevators are included on the bottom.  Extending these actually made the angle a bit steep (just the battery hump is sufficient in my opinion).Connections are simple enough.  Essentially, if you want to use the USB connector you merely attach the included USB cable to the keyboard and the other end goes, you guessed it, into a USB port on your CPU.  There is a switching key on the keyboard itself and pressing this converts it from Bluetooth and battery power to USB connected and port powered.Bluetooth is the usual “press the pairing key and wait” scenario and was simple enough; however, the pairing button on the back was so small and indented I had to use a pen in order to press it.In my household we have a mixture of OS X, Android, iOS, Chrome and Windows electronics and this keyboard had no problem connecting with any of them; however, there are a few quirks:*  iOS tablets see it as a keyboard -- period.  Function keys have no function here; however, to be fair no keyboards I’ve used with iOS have function keys that work.*  Chrome OS had the worst time with this keyboard.  Chrome uses a dedicated Search key to bring up the app menu and I couldn’t find an acceptable substitute here.  No matter, I just used the mouse to access it.*  Android tablet usage exhibited the same virtues and vices as the iOS usage did.  Function keys have no function, although they did exhibit unusual behavior on occasion (such as the F4 key decreasing volume one time but never again).*  OS X was a mixed bag.  With no dedicated Apple keys, owners must know that the Windows based Alt and Del keys may have to substitute for equivalent Apple Control, Option and Command keys.  Don’t believe reports that this keyboard doesn’t work with Apple computers -- it works just fine but the notes above about the keys still apply.*  Naturally, Windows computers and tablets had no problems at all with this keyboard.  That should be a given since the keyboard is geared for those systems.*  Run out of USB ports and utilize a secondary hub?  If that hub is powered via the USB port on your computer and nothing else, it probably won’t work with this unit.  My powered hub had no problems but when I unplugged the power pack it wouldn’t work (then again, my mouse wouldn’t either).And now for the final quirk -- why in the world would anybody using a tablet consider using a full size keyboard, even if it does have Bluetooth connectivity? After all, this keyboard is probably 4 times the size of your standard tablet and probably weighs more than two of them put together.In the end analysis, this is a great keyboard for those with desktop computers but the tablet users would probably best be served by the much smaller versions without the numerical keypad.  This unit is just too large for tablet applications.

Let’s face facts, dropping close to $250 for a thermostat is a good chunk of change, so this unit had better perform.Physically, it’s a little bigger (5 x 4 inches, give or take) than your standard unit and at a shade over 1 inch it might be a little thicker, too.  The screen takes up roughly half of that forward facing real estate which puts it in the smartphone screen size category.As for that screen, it’s a touch model and is designed very much like a smartphone interface so it’s very easy to learn the basics.  If you’ve used an Android tablet or smartphone recently you’ll notice it right off the mark.Connection is a fairly straightforward proposition with a nicely designed manual coming in the pack so you’ll know which wires go where; however, make sure before you buy that your system has a dedicated 24V C wire (this may require an HVAC technician to check that out).  Why?  Because if your system doesn’t have this wire you’re out another 30 bucks for the “Add-A-Wire” accessory.In addition, if you see labels stating 120V or 240V this unit may not work, nor will it work with thick copper wiring or those utilizing wire nuts. In short, if your home was built prior to the 1980s or you have an older HVAC unit, this might not work for you.Fortunately, none of these stipulations applied to my HVAC and within a half hour I had it hooked up (and most of that was properly attaching the base plate to the wall with the included drywall setup).Once installed, it’s pretty much what you’d expect -- a thermostat.  However, it does have a touchscreen instead of the usual buttons.  Getting things setup is fairly intuitive and users have the option of setting up for daily temperatures, away temps and can even program it for various temps throughout a day (warmer in the morning and cooler at night, etc).Now on to that touchscreen.  It’s definitely an aesthetic wonder with cheery background images along with the text and users can even add their own background pictures if they so desire.  As I soon discovered, it can also double as a nightlight in a dark hallway (yes, it’s that bright!) although it does dim after a period of disuse.But the main draw for this unit is the WiFi access.  With this you can usual your tablet or smartphone to control the unit, even while you’re away.  You can also lock out the screen so nobody else can fool around with it and you can monitor energy usage.  In fact, I’m still playing with mine as you read this.One neat feature is that you can use internet weather information to set the thermostat for future weather.So, is it worth it?  Let’s review the pros and cons:Pros:*  Easier to use than one might think.  Once you have the basics the rest follows.*  WiFi access.  This also means you have a larger screen (probably) with your tablet to work with.*  Have more than one A/C running in your home?  This can coordinate with other similar thermostats to maintain different controls in various areas.*  Pleasant, if not attractive, interface.Cons:*  Costly.  Face it, it’s an electronic touch-screen unit with WiFi that has a price tag in the tablet arena.*  Don’t have the right wiring?  That’ll be $30 extra, please.*  Those with fat fingers need not apply.  Screen real estate, unless you use your tablet via WiFi, is slim.So, it all boils down to convenience and aesthetics in the long run.  If you need a Plain-Jane thermostat, this isn’t it; however, if you need more control over your HVAC and enjoy the gee-whiz gadgetry, this is the puppy for you.

Most natural products in this category utilize salts and minerals to dry up the oily, acne prone areas and this one fits the bill, although it’s categorized as all natural (and it does fit the bill, there).Past products I’ve tried have usually resulted in redness in the area directly after application with a gradual drying of the acne.This is no different in that respect.  In fact, you can physically see the salt and mineral residue once it dries.  Use it enough and you’ll have flaking skin in the application area within a couple days.But does this work?  To a point, yes.  It does dry up minor acne and helps in the healing process; however, those with overly sensitive skin may find that the first applications may exacerbate the acne before clearing it up.  If you can live with this then this product is for you.I am one of those with sensitive skin and usually have problems with acne on the shoulders even though I’m in my 50s.  In this area I don’t care if the problem gets worse before getting better, especially if the minor inconvenience of a little redness early on results in the acne disappearing quickly.There are a couple points to keep in mind:*  This does result in dryness in the treatment area so do have a moisturizer handy or risk flaking skin.*  It does sting, probably due to the salts used, so be aware of this.*  Instructions recommend leaving it on a few minutes, usually around 10, so this isn’t a spot treatment you can apply and forget about.  You do have to wash it off and then put a moisturizer on.*  As I’ve found out, make sure you wash your hands after usage.  Nothing like rubbing your eyes with salt residue still on your fingers to wake you up quickly.*  It’s rather pricey compared to chemical based alternatives already on the market.Although a decent choice for those desperate to rid themselves of persistent acne, I’m a little offput by the rather high price; however, it’s probably not too much more expensive than some products I’ve seen hyped on TV so the choice is largely personal.

My father has used a CPAP for years but has found that if he shifts to the side or attempts to sleep in offset positions his breather hose can kink and shut off or restrict his airflow.This pillow helps to alleviate most of those problems, especially when he decides to sleep on his side.  The hose now falls into the pillow groove and most of his problems are solved.From a construction standpoint, this is roughly the size of your standard bed pillow but is built in with blunt instead of tapered ends and it probably weighs about twice as much as you’d expect to normally see (due to dense construction).  It’s also on the firm side but the memory foam does give way and cradle the head without too much irritation.There are a couple things to watch off for, though.  First, the CPAP must be adjacent to the pillow so the hose falls into the canal.  If the machine is above or below the person’s head, the hose may go off to the side (landing partially in the groove with some of the hose on the pillow itself).Secondly, there is no easy way to use a standard pillowcase with this pillow.  To do so blocks the groove and makes it nearly impossible for the hose to find the groove.But those considerations are minor in comparison to the relief of not having to worry about a kinked hose.

It’s hard to get overly enthused with shower curtains, with most being nothing more than polyester sheets with holes in top, but this one does have a couple extra perks.First off, the top is hemmed for added strength.  Doesn’t sound like much, but I’ve had curtains where the manufacturer’s idea of hemming was to add embossed eyelets around the hook holes.  Takes no time for the unhemmed ones to rip apart up top.Additionally, the bottom is also hemmed and done in such as way as to avoid bunching.  If you’re unfamiliar with that problem, it’s when the curtain decides it’s no longer going to stay flat and instead opts to gather together in a couple areas leaving others exposed.Finally, the fabric is just heavy enough that this stays flat when pulled to the maximum length.  It also has a nicer-than-usual textured finish that’s better than the slick, “plasticy” feel you get with some polyester makes.Not a bad choice in shower curtains, especially if you have a family shower that is used often.

The best way to describe the construction of this unit is by stating it looks like your standard medical walker minus one side.  Instead of the center bracing holding the missing side it’s used as an extension that goes underneath a mattress for support.  In addition, there is a slightly shorter, outward swinging, extension used as a means of getting up from a bed.  Up top is an elastic pouch, of sorts, that can be used to hold books, water bottles, remote controls, etc.With that said, does it work?Assembly is simple enough with what appears to be aluminum tubing that fits together nicely and does seem stable.  The part that goes underneath the mattress is also comprised of tubing and looks to be a couple feet in length (it appears to be roughly half the length of a twin size bed, side to side).I gave this to my 90 year old father who uses it as a stability device when getting out of bed or when he needs to reach for something on a dresser near the bed.  So far it hasn’t moved much even though he puts his full 185 pounds on it.About the only fault he has found is the swing-out extension.  Since it does swing out and doesn’t lock into position, it more or less relies on its rubber feet for stability when under weight.  As such it can move just a little bit until the rubber foot grabs the surface so be aware of this, especially if you have tiled floors where the foot might come to rest on a crack instead of a full tile.Overall, a good product for those who need assistance getting out of bed.

My girlfriend uses this nasal spray all the time and swears it’s the only one out there that will alleviate her severe allergy symptoms.Word to the wise, though.  This spray comes out in a metered dose and while it may not seem like much, volume-wise, don’t be tempted to put another shot up there as a “just in case”.  That’ll probably result in some pounding headaches, as my she discovered when this was a prescription item.  Even with a properly metered dose she still gets the occasional nose bleed, so be aware of that!Now if that price would come down a bit; however, be aware that some coupons do exist online to make the financial bite just a little less toothy!

As vacuum cleaners go, it's kind of hard to get excited by a basic household tool, but some are better than others in this category.This unit does come with a few perks, a few of which I'll discuss here:1.  A 30 foot cord.  Chances are you'll be able to do a few rooms before having to find another plug.  In contrast, most cleaners I've come across stop at around 9 feet.2.  Easy to remove and clean filters.  Beats having to fork out big bucks for replaceable filters that clog to easily.  If you're into counting, I found 3 filters that should be cleaned with one outside the dustbin and the other two inside.3.  A combination sweeper/cleaner attachment for hardwood floors.  May not seem like much, but running a beater bar over laminate flooring is a surefire way of guaranteeing they'll be scratched.4.  The body detaches from the handle and wheel assembly to act as a canister unit.  Not necessarily a new technique but it's novel given that many vacuums today assume you don't mind manhandling a bulky unit up the stairs.Without getting long winded, I'll break my additional comments into the Pro and Con categories:Pro:*  Easy to assembly.  Essentially attach the handle and hose plus attachments and you're off to the races.  No screws or assorted fasteners to lose, it all clicks together.*  3 year warranty.  Most come with 1 year.*  Built solidly.  One of the few cleaners I've come across where the attachments didn't fall off during a normal vacuuming session.*  Lighter than it looks and much lighter than my comparably-sized Shark.*  Very good suction and beater bar action.  You can tell you've vacuumed over carpet with this unit because the bar tracks are readily visible.*  Although it's pretty much standard today, I still like the auto-height feature.  Makes life a whole lot simpler when you go from padded to unpadded carpeting.*  Easy to empty dustbin.  Remove the bin, hold it over the trash can and push the bottom release button.  Since it's almost a perfect cylinder in design with no protrusions, the dirt and hairballs just come sliding out.Con:*  No swivel head?  Really?  This means repositioning either the vacuum or yourself to get around table legs and the like.*  Short hose means you better not have something too high or too far away if you plan on using the canister or attachment functions.  A couple of times I had to hold the canister high in order to reach a ceiling corner or I'd have to stretch in order to reach all the areas in a laminate flooring area.*  Something jam up the beater bar and it won't rotate?  Use this method to unjam it -- call Dirt Devil.  Yep, that's actually in the manual.  Good thing, too, because I see no way of accessing the beater bar by removing a bottom plate.  Mine hasn't jammed yet but I can only wonder what it takes to disassembly this one.*  The only way to stop the beater bar is by putting the unit in the upright position or removing the main assembly for the canister function.  This means you can't run over laminate flooring without the "swipe" feature attached (the bristles could damage laminates).  How about a switch?*  Horrible cord setup.  The cord wrap sits way too close to the main hose and it's impossible to wind the cord and not hit it several times.  Definite redesign in order there, Dirt Devil.Overall I'd give this a very good rating.  The price is competitive compared to other over-hyped and over priced models and it does the job just a well.Update 1/3/15:  What engineer at Dirt Devil decided to put an informational sticker on the front of this unit that cannot be removed with anything short of jet fuel?  C'mon guys, this thing is put on worse than any dealer sticker I've ever had slapped on the back of a car.  Make it removable!

These are inexpensive hooks as an alternative to the more pricey, name brand products you usually see.  If fact, these sort of look to be a knock off, of sorts, but the price definitely makes them attractive.Installation is easy, just attach the tape and hook to the wall with removal just as easy -- pull down on the bottom tab until the whole assembly pops off.About the only downside I can see is the weight limitation of 1 pound per hook.  Usually, this means the hooks can hold twice that weight before dropping but my framed picture weighing in at 1.5 pounds put obvious stress on the hooks (the picture didn't fall, even after an hour, but I could see bowing).Otherwise, they are good for keys and the like.Of note, read the instructions and wait an hour or so before testing these as it takes that long for the tape to set properly.

I’ve tried these in the past and they do seem to work, but I never actually owned one of my own (merely used them somewhere else) until now.Most of those I have tried looked like silver soap and were purposely designed to look like the standard bars you see in stores.  This one is different in that it actually looks like a mini football, so to speak.  It’s sleek and slender and looks a lot more fashionable sitting next to a sink; however, the picture you see in the description might give the impression it’s larger than it is.  In reality, this is about the size of maybe two mini-soaps you might find in your average hotel.Fashion and sizing aside, these metal soaps do seem to work, especially with those who work with smelly foods such as fish, cheese or onions.In fact, I’ve had a couple users tell me they’ve found secondary uses such as deodorants and for the removal of cigarette smoke from hands.  I’ve tried one as a deodorant and it did seem to work for a couple hours before the sweat finally won the battle.Oh, and learn a lesson from me.  Don’t set these near a window on very warm or exceptionally cold days as the metal will inherit that temperature and you might find yourself with a hot potato or an ice cube, neither of which feels great to the initial touch.

Let's review the specs.  For $500 you get a 10.5 inch screen, ultra thin body with high resolution screen, a stated 9 hour battery runtime, around 10 ounces in weight and 3GB RAM.The new iPad?  Nope, it's the new entry from Samsung, the Galaxy Tab S 10.5.But let's be realistic -- it's designed to compete with the iPad in an attempt to topple the latter from its throne so comparisons must be made in that respect.As compared to the iPad Air, this unit has a slightly larger screen and maybe weighs a bit more, but otherwise they are nearly identical in these areas.  Both also sport robust construction although a few I know that compared this to the iPad state the Apple version has the sleek aluminum structure; however, there is no faulting the Samsung.Unfortunately, both do share a similar trait -- forgo a case and you also forgo grip.  Both are so light and thin they are literally a drop accident waiting to happen.And while both tip the financial scales at identical pricing, the Samsung has a few upgrades.  First, you get 3GB RAM instead of the usual 1 for the iPad, then you'll notice the rear camera has a flash and an 8MP rating as opposed to the lower resolution iPad version (with no flash), and, finally, you get a micro-SD card slot (something Apple has been ignoring for years).However, it's the screen that will amaze.  AMOLED technology means colors are bright and blacks are, well, eerily black (almost new car, shiny black).  This is quite a contrast from the iPad's more sedate screen, although both are still amazing considering the technology from the earlier tablets, but the truth remains that side-by-side, the Samsung's screen really stands out.In fact, after a short while I had to tone down the brightness some as this unit will actually light up a room.  Nighttime discreet is not in the cards here.Performance-wise the Samsung gets the newer Android 4.4 OS which has a bevy of improvements over previous versions, too many to mention here.  Let it suffice to say that speed is not a problem here and I enjoy the interface over iOS versions which don't allow main screen widgets and much in the way of related animations.  In short, if you desire an OS that allows for streaming news and interactive widgets, this is the puppy for you.However, there are some quirks here.  Android allows for folders to be created on the screen to house multiple apps and this is done by either moving apps on top of each other (ala' Apple) which creates a new folder or by holding a finger on the screen to bring up a submenu to create a folder; however, Samsung tweaked this procedure and has made it so the only way to create desktop folders is by holding an icon until a menu appears on top of the screen and then scooting the icon to that area to create a folder.  Time consuming and somewhat unnecessary.Samsung added one perk to the mix, though -- a fingerprint scanner.  Swipe your fingerprint at the center bottom of the screen when prompted and it'll open the  OS as if you entered a password (word of caution -- remember the password in case your finger doesn't pass muster).  Although initially impressed, it some became apparent it had about a 40% success rate and is not for the impatient since it requires a slow, methodical swiping of the finger.Sound reproduction is an ongoing problem with any tablet unless you opt for the headphones but Samsung hit it here.  Sound reproduction is great.Performance, unfortunately, does come at a cost, though.  Although rated at 9 hours of battery life (down from an original estimate by some of closer to 11), those ignoring the battery saver functions built in will find themselves seeking an outlet at closer to 7, as in my case.  To be fair, I was running videos and jumping all over the internet so your mileage may vary.  For those that sometimes ignore the battery warnings, there is a power mode that turns the screen from color to B&W and shuts down all but the essential apps.  Hopefully you don't have to use this mode much since you're getting down to the critical stage by that time but you can technically turn it on any time.On that power topic, I really couldn't find much that would cause this unit to lock up or slow down.  Even higher end, memory eating, games didn't seem to bother it much nor did forgetting to shut down the last 15 apps I opened while hammering away at another.  Guess that 3GB RAM does help a lot.So, are there any downsides here?  As with any tablet, including the vaunted iPad, there are faults:* Price is steep and encroaches on Apple territory.  Given the option of the Apple or Samsung at the same price, the vast majority chose the former.* Accessories?  What accessories? Few companies are producing cases and the like at this time and you can easily dump anywhere from $40 on up at Samsung's site to get cases which, oddly enough, seem to be lagging behind the release date of the tablet itself (although I may has misread that).  Because of the odd screen size (larger than the industry standard of 10.1") you chance of making one of these fit into a generic tablet holder is about nil.* No 4G (or 3G for that matter) yet and capable models will not be out until later this year.  Oops, that's a biggie.* 16GB for main memory?  Really?  Yes, the Samsung does have a card slot that can accept up to 128GB, but not everything transfers to these cards (especially some apps) and transfer rates from these cards are still slower than the included drive.  Offer options here, folks.* Bloatware galore, and gimmicky stuff at that.  Fortunately, most of it just sits there and does nothing until you command differently; however, I was hoping those days were gone when tablets came out.  Problem is, some of that 16GB onboard is occupied with this stuff but I do have to commend Samsung for leaving what appears to be the majority on their website for download if desired.And, finally, there is the processor.  Instead of opting for the Intel Atom tablet series, Samsung opted to stay with the newest Enyxos quadcore version.  While wholly capable and probably just as appropriate as the Atom, the Intel name does carry cache over what was chosen.However, all things considered, Samsung could have a hit here, especially with those users not quite accustomed to Apple's version of "take it or leave it" iOS and lack of SD card support.  For the same price as a base Apple unit, Samsung buyers get more RAM, an SD card reader, the Android OS, and cameras with flash and better MP ratings.Update:  There have been a couple pesky little items that have cropped up that don't necessarily merit a drop in rating but should be kept in mind:*  The charger is just as bad as the old Apple iPad pre-Lightning version; however, it's even smaller and more fragile.  Mine is already starting to show signs of fatigue and there's no way of gingerly putting one in.  I can see this as an accident waiting to happen.*  Email notification is nothing short of lacking.  I have it on push yet this model is always behind my Apple  by at least a good couple minutes.  In addition, I'll delete an email only to have it suddenly reappear in my inbox.  Hmmm, something isn't right here.  Had to finally ignore the installed Samsung app and put in another.

In the literal sea of tablet offerings in the 7 to 8 inch class, it takes a lot to impress and it appears Asus is trying its level best to do so.  The real question is, have they succeeded?Boasting an Intel quad core Atom processor and a high resolution screen playing the newest Android 4.4 OS, it appears Asus is attempting to stand out in the $200 crowd.But can they succeed?  Previous MeMO versions sold at the big box stores did okay but were nothing spectacular and the tablet field is inundated with offerings that cost less (or more) so the competition is tough and standing out is even tougher.  Making matters worse for this field is the Apple iPad Mini which comes in with a higher price but a larger cache.For starters, this does pack the Intel processor and the newer OS, but Asus adding their own OS overlay called ZenUI, a design in which the start screen packs a lot of information that you can personalize; however, to be truthful there is only so much you can pack into such small real estate.The Asus also has a screen resolution normally found on larger screen units which does result in bright colors, vivid pics and non-stuttering videos plus you get the ubiquitous dual cameras, front and rear, but so does just about everybody else.Unfortunately, in an attempt to lengthen battery life, Asus took the low road and set screen brightness so low that even at maximum you're still pretty dim.  Readable, but still a bit dim.As for aesthetic qualities, they could best be described as minimalistic.  If nothing else, it's a flush, compact unit with nary a protrusion anywhere.  Buttons are flush mounted yet easily located and the rear surface is dimpled and easy to grasp and the only noticeable bumps on the front consist of the outside case border around the glass.  Otherwise it's smooth sailing, literally.Note to manufacturers -- it's nice to offer tablets in wild or sedate colors, but don't make an issue about it -- 99% of us are going to bury these in protective cases and only superheroes with x-ray vision will ever notice.In my testing I did find overall operations to be snappy and downright quick.  Battery life was a reasonable 7 to 8 hours which is about 1 hour shy of stated ratings.  In my experience this is about standard with manufacturer specs being about 1 hour off real world testing.  Video fluttering was nearly non-existent and apps flew open nearly as quickly as I could tap the icons.What probably helps the most here is the inclusion of Android 4.4, aka, Kit Kat (considering the logo is the Android robot made to look like the candy bar, one can only wonder what Google had to pay for those rights), the newest and fastest incantation in the Android line.  It adds tweaks and gizmos galore that will keep the average geek occupied for a while.And this is where the Asus outshines the Apple Mini -- the OS.  While iOS is a worthy competitor it lacks on-screen interactivity and widgets, in general.  Android has design and spark with vivid interactivity and the high resolution screen of the Asus helps a lot (although detractors state its overall specs are light, they fail to realize this is small package delivering the screen quality of a larger notebook).So, does the MeMO have any faults?  There are a few but they are relatively minor:* Who thought of moving the camera to the right edge from the center mounted variety found on earlier models?  This means users may get hands or fingers in the way (especially in landscape mode) and all older cases will no longer work even though the unit may fit.* Music and sound reproduction, although highly touted by Asus, is acceptable but not outstanding.  As one would expect, much better with headphones but as a standalone the sound is barely passable (and made worse by adding a case).* Screen brightness is limited and possibly too much so.  Even turning off the battery saving features didn't make the screen too much brighter.So, is the Asus a good buy?  In the $200 category, most definitely so.  Sure beats the competition in most respects and going any lower in price is a sure bet on disappointment.Update, 09/25/14After 4 months am I still enthused by this model?  Sorry, I had to drop a couple stars for the following:*  Every once in a while but at least twice a week, the speaker starts crackling and popping.  It goes away in a couple seconds but it makes no sense in that I'm not using the speakers at all in most cases.  It most recently did it in my public library when I had the unit muted.  This does not bode well.*  Waking up from sleep mode is dicey.  Sometimes it will, sometimes it won't and it's getting worse.  Occasionally a gray screen will appear and hang around for 15 or so seconds before my home screen shows.*  Going back to the home page from any app is equally perplexing.  More often than not the icons are nowhere to be found.  Fortunately, if I hang around long enough they will reappear.It appears my initial enthusiasm for this unit has been somewhat tempered by recent events but for something that's just a few months old you can see my concerns.Update, 10/10/14The problem mentioned in the previous update got so bad the unit started to become unresponsive.  So much so, I thought it had died when, in fact, it had gone to a gray screen.Finally talked to a guy at a local office supply store who is something of a tech and he mentioned customers had been griping about this problem, too.Turns out the tablet isn't bad, but a recent Android update has literally butchered the Zen UI that's included with this model and I guess the manufacturer hasn't quite gotten around to correcting it yet (if they are aware of it at all).  As a result, icons disappear on a random basis and getting the unit awake from sleep mode is anything but graceful or quick.Here's the workaround.  Install the Apex Launcher offered in the Play Store and when given the option make sure this launcher takes over for the Zen UI.That problem is now solved.  Icons come up instantly and waking up from sleep is back to a couple seconds.As for the popping noise, it still comes in every once in a while but the sound works fine otherwise.  I won't ding on that for now until I'm sure the update didn't do that, too (again, that problem didn't surface until the update).

Over time my tablet has replaced my laptop for most functions including writing reports, reviews and papers.Since I haven’t mastered the fine art of screen typing and dislike the thought of losing half my screen for that faux keyboard, I’ve opted for the separate Bluetooth keyboard and decided to give the Sharkk a try since the price is reasonable compared to Apple or Logitech options.Once it arrived I was pleased to see that it’s well built with an aluminum bottom and plastic top end with an overall size best described as ¾ of an iPad 2.  As for weight, my postal scale shows it as 8.3 ounces so this in combination with almost any tablet will have you going out the door at less than 2 pounds (lighter than almost any laptop).Out of the box it took about 2 hours to charge the battery (mini USB cord included so if you have charging blocks from just about any tablet this can be plugged in and used with those) and then it was off to the races.Pairing is a breeze -- turn on the power and push the connect button (which is just a tick too small but I’d guess it’s designed that way to avoid accidental activation) and within seconds your tablet or computer should have a notification of pairing attempt.  Pairing attempts worked just fine on my Apple desktop, iPad 2 and Samsung Galaxy tablet.Beyond that you’d expect it to be typing as usual, but there are a few perks and quirks here:* There is a hump on the back top that, I guess, houses the battery and wiring.  Also provides a slight pitch to the keyboard so it’s easier to type on versus the flatter units that look good initially but get tiring after a while.  That’s a plus.* Backlighting, and plenty of choices at that (you can cycle through the colors by pressing a lightbulb button and the arrow keys); however, mine only stayed on a short period and then would go out.  Positive for the backlighting but a ding for the limited amount of time in which it works.  Of note, this is great lighting that illuminates all the keys -- there is no mistaking one for another.* Due to size limitations, this is a netbook sized keyboard so you can expect some cramped typing.  While this unit may be good for students and casual typists, I would have to revert to my larger units for extended sessions.* Thanks for the velveteen cover, but maybe a plastic or aluminum top sleeve would be more appropriate.  While nice, the included cover appears to offer little more than cosmetic protection.* Power button is on the bottom.  Should be on the top or side if possible and the current placement means you have to lift the unit to turn it on or off; however, the auto-off function after a minute technically means you could just leave it on all the time (it reactivates with a simple tap of any key).For the price, a completely functional and reliable unit for the casual typist.  Certainly beats those silicone varieties sold at flea markets that have mushy keys!

This version of Colgate is a combination of whitening and fluoride protection, something that is all the buzz at the moment.While this toothpaste does have a pleasant taste and does leave a long-lasting sense of freshness, it does seem a little “pasty” in that this stuff is thick (really thick).  Best as I can figure it’s an attempt to make it adhere to the teeth a little longer but plan on scrubbing the sink if any falls there while brushing (and don’t let it dry or you’ll have the dental equivalent of caulk).As for whitening abilities, that’s tough to tell.  I’ve already been using this product and I’m sure it does aid in whitening to some degree, but if you’re an older person like me who drinks way too much coffee the effects may be limited.  Also, if you’re looking for the same type of white you might get from the dentist or those strips you find in stores, you might want to keep looking.Still a good choice, though, and you have the Colgate name to back up the product which is reassuring.
Well made and just perfectly balanced for the person using a double edged blade for shaving.  So much so, I bought one for my father, too.

This is a substitute for butter, not a butter topping.That aside, I'll just state it's a better alternative to some other butter flavored products out there that are either too light (usually the "misting" spray variety) or go on in globs (the squeeze margarine types) thereby ruining my popcorn.And while this does succeed as a topping it does have its shortcomings, to wit:*  It's oily and very much so.  Have dry, chapped hands?  No for long you don't.*  The butter flavor is what I call a "hint".  You can sense it's there but you sort of have to find it.*  It's expensive -- much more so than the other buttery alternatives I mentioned earlier.Although I don't pop my corn using the old kettle method, I do believe this would be better used in that capacity which would cut down on some of the oil left on the popcorn while leaving some of the flavor intact.  For microwave popcorn, there may be better alternatives.

I've seen where quite a few soft drink companies have gone to these smaller cans and that's fine by me -- I like a smaller drink in lieu of the larger cans that can go flat before I finish one.Flavor-wise, it's what you expect from Coke -- always a consistent product with no variance from one to the next.My major gripe is the price.  Can for can, these are more expensive than the 6 packs of 12 ouncers -- somewhat goofy if you get right down to it and while some may say the price difference is minimal and justified due to the extra cans, it still doesn't make up for the fact that the cost per ounce is still more and that math doesn't sit well with me.

I'm not a big fan of instant coffee but I'll use it when traveling (I dislike paying big bucks for glorified swill) or if I'm in a hurry and don't feel like messing with wet grounds and filters.Instructions claim 1 to 2 teaspoons will do the trick but I'll add a caveat to that -- 1 is weak and 2 will peel the enamel off your teeth.  1.5, at least for me, if the proper mix.  Those liking really strong coffee can jack it up to 2 but I found that to be bitter.  1.5 teaspoons makes for a decent cup of coffee that I can dress up with creamer.One ding I will give is the jar design.  The top is a partial twist style, i.e., it twists either way and then pops off.  Instead of rigid plastic this one uses a flimsier design that buckles when you go to remove it.  I can smell a break coming any day and I believe a standard twist cap or even a push-on compression cap is a better choice.

I love popcorn but I love highly flavored fresh popcorn even more.  That being said, this group of add-ons is tops.  Buffalo Wing and Ranch are my favorites but I'm not hot on the Kettle Corn, possibly because it's a little heavy on the sugar.Those with heart conditions may want to go light on these -- all but the Kettle Corn are heavy on salt (but low on calories).Next time I'll check my out my favorite, Jalapeno.  Just enough heat to make things interesting.

Probably one of the best detergents out there for cleaning ability, consistency of scent and consistency of the product.  No matter what, Tide cleans with (generally) less detergent needed than the competition (who may recommend half a cap when a full one is actually necessary to get the job done right).My only gripe is the price.  Guess we are paying for the commercials but this stuff routinely runs nearly twice as much as the lesser varieties from equally large companies and in a tough economy that hurts.However, there is no denying this is one of the best detergents.  Clothes do come out clean and fresh smelling and that earns at least 4 stars.

It does what it is supposed to do.  I am using a standard 802.3af PoE switch to send power and data down a network cable.  At the other end of the network cable, this device separates the power from the data and converts the power output to 12 volts.  It has been active for over a month non-stop and has had no problem whatsoever.

I got this at a brick and mortar store Oct 3rd since Amazon didn't have any stock.[UPDATE Oct 30, 2015]: Logitech recently made an announcement about the surround sound.  The headset appears as a Stereo device to the operating system as an apparently unavoidable side-effect of moving to a new driver model.  Logitech claims the surround sound works as intended.  User experience tells us that it only works in a small number of games which provide the option to force surround audio output.  The overwhelming majority of games only produce stereo sound for the headset because that is what the operating system tells them to do.Logitech has made it clear that this behavior is as designed.  I may be foolish for it, but I still carry a glimmer of hope that Logitech will realize their mistake and make it right.  Until then, I encourage everyone who is stuck with a headset past its return window to download Razer Surround software.  This is a virtual device driver which will provide proper surround sound support to any headset including this one.  It isn't perfect and it isn't what you paid for, but hey, it is better than nothing.[END UPDATE]Pros:+ Comfortable to wear despite clamping fairly tight on the head.+ It has a power switch, not a power button, so you can more easily tell if it is on or off by looking at it or feeling it.+ Good sound quality.  I'm no audiophile but I think it sounds better than the older G930 headset did.+ Programmable G-Keys.  I use one as a push-to-talk key. For me, this is what really sets Logitech's gaming headsets apart from the competition.+ If this headset has an auto-shutoff feature, it hasn't bothered me yet.+ No random headset disconnects yet like I always used to get with G930 headsets!  I will update if this changes.Cons:- The current driver bundled with Logitech Gaming Software 8.74.80 has a serious bug.  The headset appears to Windows as if it only supports Stereo input, so games and other apps only send stereo audio, not multi-channel surround as they are supposed to.  According to a thread on Logitech's support forum, this bug is affecting all their surround headsets, not just this one, so I have faith that it will be fixed in a future software update.  Until then, it loses a star on my review.  Obviously this bug is not affecting everyone, but it is not yet clear why some are affected and some or not.- The volume wheel and G-Keys are smaller, further back, and harder to tell apart than they were on the older G930 headset.  This is probably because the earcups have removable faceplates on this model, so they couldn't put controls there like on the G930.- Forget about using it wirelessly with a cell phone for phone calls.  You have to plug the phone in to the headset using an included 3.5mm cable if you want to use it for a phone call.  There is a headphone jack on the USB transmitter which you can connect devices to, but the headset's microphone signal is not forwarded through this.Other notes:* The decorative lighting is enabled by default and takes several hours off your battery life.  You can dim the lights or turn them off in Logitech Gaming Software to lengthen the battery life.

I had this lamp for a few months, using it only rarely, and while it worked it worked well.  Then a week ago, an ordinary zap of static electricity from my finger destroyed the lamp.  About 10 seconds after touching the lamp, I began detecting the distinct smell of burned electronics. Then the lamp came on all by itself and began cycling through its color temperature modes.  I unplugged it and took it apart to investigate.  The circuit board had a badly burned chip, and the heat had even begun to visibly melt a spot on the plastic enclosure.  This, in less than 30 seconds before I unplugged the power.  (see the photo I added)A lamp built to be touched should be more resistant to static electric shock than this.  This could have been much worse if I had left the room before smelling it.The lamp went into the trash and the seller, Angella's Lamp, kindly provided a full refund.  Interestingly, the seller seems to have now recycled this product listing to sell a different lamp while retaining the customer reviews from the old lamp.  I imagine Amazon doesn't care, given that Amazon regularly lumps together product reviews from completely different products anyway, but that seemed worth mentioning.

The display is in Celsius and as far as I can tell there are no adjustments possible for brightness, calibration, or temperature format (so it can't display temperature in Fahrenheit).  No power supply is included, and you must wire it yourself to a 12 volt power source.  Accuracy is very good.  It measures within a fraction of a degree of my hot tub's built-in thermostat, and should make a nice backup temperature monitor for the tub while I am on winter vacations.  The only problem is the display flickers in my security camera's view, but this is common for simple LCD displays so I cannot fault it.

It took a lot of force (jumping up and down) to snap the pieces together, but the steps are very durable.  They are not uncomfortable for bare feet, and I have not had a problem with the steps getting slippery.

I first applied this nearly 3 years ago to stop a leak on an asphalt shingle roof. At some point in the last year, the sealant failed and the leak returned.  It had obtained a yellow tint, cracked like scorched earth, and much of it was missing, probably carried away by wind and water.  This is at 43 degrees (north latitude, not temperature), where winters are cold and snowy and summers are hot.  Since I don't have a better option right now, I ordered more and applied it the other day.  This may become a thing I do every year or two.

I wasn't expecting much from a quadcopter this cheap but it has been fun.  I flew it nearly to death before discovering there were 3 flight sensitivity modes.  Little did I know the default setting is very subdued!  Press the left control stick inward to switch between sensitivity levels.  The right stick, when pressed, makes the next motion result in the copter doing a flip!  I also discovered this late.The copter comes with 4 spare blades but I got a pack of multi-colored extra blades from a 3rd party.  The 3rd party blades are compatible but I feel like their pitch is weaker and they break easier.  Notice that there are actually 2 different blade types -- all 4 are NOT the same.  2 blades are designed to rotate clockwise and the other two rotate counter-clockwise.The batteries in the controller (not included if I recall) are going to outlast the quadcopter.  After several hours of total flight (and crash) time, the copter is getting weaker and more jittery.  Less fun to fly this way.

Knowing nothing about this movie beyond its name, I thought it would be a traditional Bible story.  That perception lasted less than fifteen seconds.  I'm not sure whether the writers set out to anger religious folk or if they just cared nothing for accuracy.  It tells the story of Noah, more or less, but the omissions and deviations from the Old Testament version could fill a book.

I put 6 of these across the surface of an mSata SSD that was exceeding 90 C during normal operation.  These heatsinks, aided by a cooling fan, have the same SSD running just over room temperature now.

I have a very specialized use for this fan.  I use it to cool the bottom half of a Gigabyte Intel i7-4770R Mini PC Barebones GB-BXi7-4770R, which is a very small PC with a 65 watt CPU in it.  This fan is a perfect fit because of its rubber feet, fan grilles, and large size that make it a perfect base for the little PC.It gets seriously hot inside that mini PC's case, partially because the bottom half of the machine doesn't have a cooling fan.  My mSata SSD was reaching temperatures in excess of 90 C, and the system crashed periodically.  When one stick of RAM and the 2.5 inch hard drive I had in there failed, I decided it was time to do something about the lack of ventilation.  So I removed the bottom of the case and placed it on this fan, having it blow air up into the casing.  I also added some small copper heatsinks to the SSD: Cosmos ® 8 PCS Copper VGA RAM Cooling Heatsinks cooler + Cosmos Cable Tie.  The SSD now runs at half its previous temperature and the system is much more stable.

Scotch Super 88 is the good stuff.  If you do not know what you are looking for, you can easily be fooled by other electrical tape brands that simply do not perform well.  I often use this outdoors on radio towers and it gets a lot of direct sunlight, wind, rain, snow and ice.  No problems after several years.  The tape stays where you put it and does not fall apart like some of the cheaper alternatives.

Pros:+ Powerful CPU included while maintaining a low price+ Fairly light weight and easy to carry.+ Fans, CPU, motherboard, Optical drive, and RAM stick all pre-installed.+ Great for a 4-drive NAS server with enough CPU power for additional services to be run (e.g Plex, Minecraft, etc)+ Intel network adapter built in, not some junky Realtek.Cons:- Only 4 HDD bays, despite having room for at least 2 more.  More HDD bays and SATA ports would have been appreciated.- No option to buy without a RAM stick.Other thoughts:I run FreeNAS on it with 4x WD Red 6TB hard drives.  The FreeNAS OS runs off a very small USB flash drive I plugged in on the back.  I love the fact that I can't really build an equivalent system any cheaper, and with this, much of the assembly work is done for me.  I added more RAM (2x 8GB and 1x 4GB), Crucial brand Unbuffered ECC, for a total of 24 GB of RAM as recommended for FreeNAS to perform well with this storage capacity.  And it does run well.  The RAID-Z2 I built with this is an order of magnitude faster than my old 4-disk RAID 5 arrays that I have used in the past.  When properly configured, FreeNAS is so much better I do not think I will ever build another storage server with onboard RAID again.
No memory errors after a few days and nights of testing.  Used in a Lenovo ThinkServer TS140 70A4001LUX along with an extra Crucial 4GB chip to increase the total RAM to 24 GB.
No memory errors after a few days and nights of testing.  Used in a Lenovo ThinkServer TS140 70A4001LUX (comes with 4GB) along with two 8GB chips to increase the total Unbuffered ECC RAM to 24 GB.
This was purchased as a gift to replace old, loose kitchen scissors that could not even cut wrapping paper anymore.  The new shears work perfectly and will be useful for years to come.

I bought this shovel 4 years ago to clear my front porch of snow, and finally broke it this weekend when attempting to dislodge 6 weeks of heavy, packed snow into more-manageable chunks for my underpowered snow blower.  The shovel was being used as a pry-bar to break packed snow into smaller bricks and was overstressed such that the blade of the shovel split just below the curve.  The handle was more than strong enough for the stress, but the flatter part of the blade was not!  I bet, had it been made of aluminum or another metal, it would have bent rather than snapped.  But the shovel is almost entirely plastic and just could not handle the stress.I was happy enough with the first one that I have ordered a second.  It is light and durable as long as you don't try to push it past its limits.

This replaced the over-two-years-old battery that my Galaxy S3 came with.  I let it charge overnight (12+ hours) and then unplugged my phone the next morning.  24 hours later it was still at 90% (only some light usage), and 30 hours in and it shows 86%.  The previous battery would have been stone dead by this point.  I finally plugged it in at 7%, 8 days 48 minutes after taking it off the charger!  Now, to be fair, I don't use my phone often.  A couple minutes a day is typical, so almost all of the time was spent with the phone idle, and sleeping.  But I do have it connected to WiFi and I run the Life360 app for GPS tracking in case I lose the phone, so I can go find it.  Bluetooth and NFC disabled.The battery adds significant weight to the phone, and when you use the provided (soft) case it is about the size of an Otterbox Defender case.  Several other reviews say you can modify an Otterbox Defender to fit this battery, so I might do that with mine.  I tried the ZeroLemon Zero Shock case today, but it adds too much extra bulk and I absolutely do not like the feel of the Zero Shock case so I switched back to the case that came with the battery.

0:30 Mins I have attached a video capture from the camera, which demonstrates the sensor resolution and frame rate.Pros:+ Most affordable thermal camera ever built and sold, by a very large margin.+ Image resolution is much higher than typical "low cost" (under $2000) thermal cameras, including the FLIR One.+ Very light and compact, yet sturdy+ Works with Samsung Galaxy S3, Galaxy S5, and Galaxy Tab S (although the app on the Tab S has frustrating screen orientation issues, it is usable).+ Easily capture still images and video clips.+ As of the December 2, 2014 app update, the temperatures are no longer offset by nearly 100 degrees, and appear to be more-or-less accurate.Cons:- Low frame rate.- The video skips a frame or two whenever the camera runs its self-calibration (coincides with a soft clicking noise)- App is buggy.  I have seen video corruption, black screens, and crashes.  These are thankfully uncommon, and can be fixed by restarting the app and/or reseating the camera in the Android device.- Accuracy of temperatures is questionable, as uniform surfaces appear as a gradient.  Supposedly Seek Thermal is working on solutions to this.- As of the December 2, 2014 app update, the emissivity selection control is visible, but seems to have no effect on anything.- No integrated visible-light camera, and the support for overlaying your Android device's normal camera is still very crude.Other thoughts:* Camera makes a soft clicking noise every few seconds when powered on.  The documentation explains this is a normal part of the ongoing calibration process.

I bought this cable when trying to troubleshoot an HDMI handshake problem with my projector.  I thought all the shielding would make for a more reliable connection.  But instead, this cable only added to my problems.  If I wiggled the end plugged in to the HDMI source, it lost connection.  Every time.  I ended up plugging the old cable back in, which doesn't have the same problem.I do not know if the cable is defective, or if it is just a little bit incompatible with the HDMI source socket (e.g. not able to plug in all the way).It is not worth the trouble to return this cable, or it would be going back.

I normally used a powerful PC hooked up to my projector for streaming TV and movies.  I did not think a tiny little box like this could provide a good playback experience compared to a PC.  The Fire TV exceeded expectations in all regards.The first thing I noticed was that everything on the Fire TV runs buttery smooth.  I thought it would be tedious to scroll through TV shows and movies on the Fire TV, but it runs very well and there are practically no loading times when scrolling through Amazon's content.Amazon's Instant Video service dominates the user interface.  I really would have liked to see more complete integration with services like Netflix, but instead these streaming services are hidden away inside their own apps.  I fully understand why this is.  Obviously, Amazon wants their own content to take center stage.  But more than that, it is extremely difficult to integrate with 3rd party content providers at all, especially if you are going to dictate to them exactly how everything is going to work.  After trying a Roku TV stick, I appreciate this even more.  Speed issues with the Roku stick aside, Roku integrates all the services together better, but the interface feels relatively unpolished.  It is as though Roku had to design for the lowest common denominator.I should also note that I immediately wired the Fire TV with ethernet, and never tried it on WiFi.  WiFi is the cause of so many network problems that I don't think I would have bought Fire TV if it had not posessed an ethernet port.

Pros:* Good looking design and finish* Large, sturdy top.* Large open shelf.* DrawerCons:* The drawer is a bit noisy* The drawer can't hold much weight* The corners are not very rounded on top.Other thoughts:The shelf is about 3 inches taller than the top of my mattress.  I worry that I will bump into the edge of it with my face when rolling out of bed or reaching for a glass of water.  I can't really blame anyone but myself for this, since the product dimensions are accurate.  So I added a foam pad to the corner nearest the bed -- the kind intended to keep small children from bumping their heads too hard.

I am used to working with Scotch Super 88 electrical tape, which is black.  This feels like a slightly lower quality, but is still preferable for when you want the tape to blend with white objects, or when you want to color-code your wiring.
I got this for one of the Intel NUCs that didn't come with its own power cord.  It works, and the product matches its description.

I got this for a Gigabyte Brix system that records 24/7 for a couple of security cameras.  I only put on a constant load of about 100-200 KB/s typically, but it has been running for over 2 weeks without any problems!

I've tried several different pizza sauce brands in the past year or two and so far these are the only ones with a lid that is openable without a can opener.As for the sauce itself, it is more tomato flavored and less spicy than some other brands.  The sauce is less viscous (less thick) than other brands like Muir Glen, making it easier to pour from the can.  Unfortunately, of all the brands I've tried this is my least favorite flavor.  It isn't a bad sauce, but I don't particularly like the flavor of raw tomatoes and this sauce seems to be based on that more than others.

I managed to get these at just $7.50 per bulb, shipped, in a 6 pack.  This makes them by far the most cost-effective dimmable LED bulbs I could find.  And I suspect they produce less heat than much of the competition, since there is a lot less of an external heatsink on these than on a lot of other brands.I had no issues with flickering or noise when used with my Evolve z-wave dimmers.  I only wish they could increase the lumen output to be comparable to a 100 watt incandescent, but without increasing the size and heat generation!

Some of them have nicks in the metal, but for the price I can't really complain.  Each screwdriver contains a small flat-head, phillips head, and a hex head (in the end of the casing opposite the keychain).  One of the screws on my glasses comes loose every few weeks so it is great having one of these with me wherever I go.

This worked with my "headless" Gigabyte Brix Pro GB-BXi7-4770R to solve the problem where remote desktop applications like VNC and TeamViewer would show only a black screen when connected to the Brix.  Apparently lots of PCs have this problem!If your headless computer suffers from the same problem, there is a temporary workaround you can try:  Uninstall the display adapter in Windows' Device Manager and reboot the PC.  This causes Windows to load a generic driver which allowed VNC and TeamViewer to work for me.  I couldn't set the screen resolution to 1920x1080, but I could access the system which is better than nothing.  Once I got this device, I was able to use 1920x1080 resolution and reinstall the full Intel driver.ALSO IMPORTANT to note is that Intel will soon be releasing a driver update that supposedly fixes this problem, and when they do it will likely make this Display Emulator unnecessary.

I got the monitor early (early March 2014, about 1 and a half months before Amazon availability) from a South Korean ebay seller.4k is fantastic to have on the desktop.  I can fit more of everything on this monitor, and it really helps my work to be able to see more lines of code at once without having to scroll.  But enough of my babbling about how great it is to have more screen space.Pros:* 4k (3840x2160) native resolution @ 60hz, costing under a grand. Finally!  Woohoo!* Excellent color reproduction despite using a TN panel.* Good Picture-in-Picture (PIP) support.* Still usable without DPI scaling by the operating system, though you might have to sit close to read text.* Monitor is surprisingly thin and light compared to my previous 27 inch 2560x1440 monitors.* No dead or stuck pixels.Cons:* It doesn't work properly with my Win7/Nvidia PC unless I disable Aero glass.* Noticably more input lag than my other LCD monitors, but at the same time a lot less than a Seiki 39 inch 4k TV @ 30hz.* Has color distortion at odd view angles due to the TN panel it uses.* Occasionally a small graphical glitch will appear on the screen for a split second.  It is hardly noticable but suggests a minor connection problem.* Often when I boot up at the start of the day, the monitor is detected as having a max resolution of 1920x1080 or 2560x1440.  I have to power the monitor on and off, sometimes more than once, to fix this.* A couple times a week, at random during normal use, the monitor BLACKS OUT and goes completely unresponsive.  It has been doing this for the entire month and a half that I've owned it.  Basically the screen goes black, the power light turns off, and the power/menu button does not respond at all.  It does not recover by itself.  The only way to recover from this is to unplug the monitor's power and plug it back in.Other thoughts:* I have tried multiple displayport cables.  The monitor behaves the same regardless.* You can connect two HDMI sources and use them both simultaneiously.  One feeds the left half of the screen and the other feeds the right half.  There is no border between the halves, and they run at 60hz.  You can also have the displayport input use only half the screen if you want, and have HDMI feed the other.* I wonder if buying it early direct from South Korea is the reason I got such a flakey unit.* I have some alternative power bricks (14V 4A) on the way.  I am hopeful that these will resolve my blackout problem, and will update this review in a few weeks with my findings.

Other reviews have covered most of the basics, so instead of duplicate all that, I will provide a few answers to some questions I originally had:* 16 watts maximum power draw with the CPU under load - Measured with Kill-o-watt meter (also, equipped with 2x2GB Crucial RAM and a Crucial m500 mSata SSD)* BIOS has the ability to power on the PC automatically after power loss.* Ubuntu and Windows 7 both run smoothly despite the low-budget nature of the PC.

For the past year or two, I've been putting together my own pizzas rather than buying them frozen.  It is more work and more expensive this way, but they taste better and must be ... hmm ... less unhealthy ... than a typical frozen pizza.However I still haven't found a pizza sauce I can say "wow" about.  I know you are out there somewhere, sauce!In fact I prefer Eden Organic Pizza Pasta Sauce over this, as this Muir Glen stuff is too thick to spread just by tilting the pizza and letting gravity do the work (just how lazy am I?).I am no food critic, but this tastes alright.  It is Organic, too, which is always a plus.  But most importantly it is readily available at a fair price, unlike the Eden Organic sauce lately :)
I changed to this switch from a 16 port gigabit Trendnet switch that had a tendency to inexplicably stop passing traffic through certain ports.  This one hasn't had any problems yet.

The concept is simple.  You can try hands, fingers, twisted-up dishrags, rags wrapped on the end of a spoon, whatever.  Nothing reaches the bottom of a tall cup very well to give it a good scrub.This does.'nuff said.

Pros:+ Works with dimmable LED bulbs without flickering. (not all LED bulbs are dimmable)+ No issues working with Vera Lite control unit.  I can control the brightness as a percentage from 0 to 100% with 1% "resolution". (for 1% resolution in a Vera UI5 scene, go to the advanced tab for the scene).+ Small orange LED on front helps you find it in the dark.+ Only a very quiet buzz when on.  Can't really hear it unless it is silent in the house and you stand right next to it.Cons:- When you press the "on" button, there is about a 1 second delay for the lights to turn on, and another second for them to reach full brightness.  Similarly, it takes some time for the lights to dim to off when you press the "off" button.  Mostly it is the "on" delay that bothers me but I'm sure I will get used to it.Other thoughts:* A quick push of the top or bottom of the rocker turns the lights on (to the previous brightness) or off.  A long hold brightens or dims.* Minimum brightness (1%) is not quite enough power to turn on some LED bulbs.  Some of my bulbs won't turn on until I go to 7 or 8%, though they will stay on if I go back down to 1%.*** Important Installation Notes ***I installed 3 so far in a manufactured home constructed in 2001 by Nashua homes, and in every case I had to do some work to make it work.  In fact I was lucky to be able to do this without seriously tearing things apart and running new wire to half the house.  I am no electrician, but I now know enough about house wiring to be dangerous.The best way I can explain it is to say that these Evolve dimmers expect the light switches to lie in between the breaker box and the lights.  In other words these dimmers expect there to be two bundles of wire coming to the switch.  One bundle (lets call it bundle A) comes from the breaker box and the other bundle (B) goes to the lights.  Bundles A and B each contain a black wire, a white wire, and a bare copper wire.  The black wire from bundle A is called "line" or "hot" and the black wire from bundle B is called "load".  The white wires are "common" and the unshielded copper wires are "ground".  As far as I can tell, this is the minimum necessary to properly wire the Evolve dimmers.Unfortunately, this is not how the switches in my home were laid out.  The lights are between the breaker box and the switches, so each switch only has a single bundle of 3 wires: ground, line (hot / black),  and common (white).  Under normal circumstances this would have meant I had no choice but to return the evolve dimmers.  Fortunately in every situation so far I've been able to work out an alternative.My bedrooms each have two light switches right next to each other, intended for each switch to control a different bulb in the ceiling fixture.  Since the power comes in to the light, and I have two bundles of wire going to the switches, I was able to repurpose one of those bundles to pass power through the junction box in the ceiling and down to the switches.  The other bundle could then carry power back up to the light fixture.  This took some rewiring at each light fixture but once I knew what I was doing it was very easy.  (I really recommend you do not attempt this if you don't know what you are doing, or if your state/local laws require a licensed electrician for all electrical work!)My kitchen was more complicated.  I had a single switch and only a single bundle of wires to work with.  But I had an outlet 4 inches away on the same wall which belonged to a different electrical circuit.  I was able to disconnect the kitchen lights from their original circuit and run a new piece of romex wire behind the wall between the outlet and the switch to provide a power source for the switch.Lastly, my home was built with all-in-one switches that didn't need to be installed in a junction box.  Like most wall receptacles, these dimmers do require a junction box for safety (and for mounting to), so I had to cut the holes slightly larger and install old-work junction boxes at each switch location.All-in-all the installation was more than I had bargained for, but luckily it worked out.

The surround sound feature is a complete scam.  The "surround driver" is now available (about a month after product release!), but all it does is add two virtual surround modes which tweak the way your audio plays.  The headphones remain a stereo (2-channel) audio device regardless.I even tested in a surround-capable game by throwing a grenade, immediately turning 180 degrees, and throwing another.  The resulting two explosion sounds were indistinguishable despite one being in front of my character and the other being behind.  This is no surprise, as the game is obviously outputting 2-channel audio to this 2-channel device.  You can't convert a 2-channel audio source into 7.1 positional audio just by slapping the Dolby name on it.  This is insulting.I have tried Wireless PC gaming headsets (with virtual surround) from Logitech, Creative, and Corsair, and all of these do surround sound properly.  They present 5 and/or 7-channel audio devices to the operating system, and they all do a fair job of recreating positional audio.  They can do this because they actually receive multi-channel audio signals.  But Turtle Beach falls way short.  The Z300 headphones only present a 2-channel audio device to the OS, and the surround sound features are 100% faked.  This is a very disappointing imitation of the surround sound available on wireless headphones that cost half as much.That aside:Pros:+ Good build quality.+ Microphone is very adjustable and removable.+ Volume control on the headset.+ Mic monitor volume control on the headset.+ Strong bluetooth audio support.+ Good sound quality+ Long battery life+ Clear voice status messages (i.e. "Powering On", "Powering Off", "Game Mode 1", ...)+ Average wireless range, with no cutouts when using it normally at my desk.Cons:- Outrageously high price tag for a 2 channel headset. (at least double what it is worth)- Advertised as a 7.1 surround sound headset, but it is only stereo.- Earcups are not deep enough.  My ears touch the inner padding (the stuff with the turtle beach logo) which is mildly irritating.- No configurable audio presets.  Just 4 game modes accessible via a button on the headset, plus the two gimmicky Dolby audio modes provided by the so-called "surround driver".

Pros:+ Great day image quality.+ Fair night image quality (see cons below).+ Excellent build quality and physical design, including the mount.+ Small physical size.+ Low power consumption.  I've seen just under 3 watts with IR LEDs off, and about 5-6 with them on.+ 802.3af Power over Ethernet (PoE) supported (power injector not included). They can run off of standard 12v power adapters if not using PoE. Depending on seller, these may or may not come with a power supply at all.+ Feature-packed firmware with web interface that works in Firefox and Chrome too, not just Internet Explorer.+ Integrated motion detection with ability to record to a network drive (but no SD card with this model).+ FTP support, including scheduled image uploads.+ Configurable Wide Dynamic Range (WDR) support improves detail in shadows and bright areas.Cons:- Much noise in night video when lit only by the integrated IR LEDs.  This can be reduced by tweaking Noise Reduction and WDR settings, but additional lighting is necessary for a truly clean picture.- Noise levels increased significantly at night when WDR is on.- No SD card support.Other thoughts:* These cameras have been gaining in popularity over the last 6+ months as one of the best values in security cameras this year.  A google search of the model number will find several forums where the camera is discussed.  Snapshots and videos can be found, too.I have 9 of these cameras - all purchased elsewhere.  They are great little cams!
