I got my HMZ-T3W from the Sony Store, but I must assume it is the same version being sold here.  Amazon's product description, at least, is for the HMZ-T3W at the time of this writing.Pros:+ Compatible with most eyeglasses, including mine.  Nearsighted people with glasses will need to wear them with this.+ Does not even touch your nose if you don't want it to.+ Wireless worked perfectly for me, but you can alternatively connect the battery pack to the processing box via HDMI and use it wired.+ Privacy.  Other people are unable to see the screens while you are wearing it, even if they try to peek around your head.+ Included earbuds sound good and feel high quality.+ Includes lots of extra rubber earpieces for the earbuds (different shapes).+ Compatible with most other headphones via the 3.5mm jack+ 3 HDMI inputs.  You can switch between them with the on-screen menu or by pressing the INPUT button on the processing unit.+ Reasonably light weight.  The T3 is the lightest Sony HMZ head-mounted-display yet.+ 100 - 240V power supplies, meaning they can be used in most other countries without converting voltage.+ Looking down, you can see below the device pretty well, allowing easy usage of keyboard, mouse, gamepad, or remote control.+ Compatible with nvidia 3D technology for stereoscopic games and 3D movie playback.+ You can choose over/under and side-by-side 3D formats through the on-screen menu, or leave it on auto mode if the application explicitly supports 3D output.Cons:- Difficult to position the viewer to get a clear, sharp image across the entire screen(s).  If the previous models were worse, I feel sorry for the owners of those models.  Having your eyes closer to the lenses does help.- Only 1280x720 resolution like the first 2 generations.  It is still a good looking display, but surely Sony could have upped it to 1080p by now.- HDMI pass-through only functions when the viewer is OFF, so you can't use the pass-through port to mirror your display with another device.  This is stated in the Startup Guide, and I also verified it myself.- The optional bottom rubber light blocker (included) presses into my nose uncomfortably.  It is also a bit tricky to attach.Other Thoughts:* The input connector to both power supplies (battery charger and processing box) is Volex VAC7S which is reasonably common.* The field of view is about as large as it can get while still allowing you to see all corners of the display.  To get much larger, it would need bigger lenses.* I submitted a customer image including the full box contents.

I was fearful that there would be something wrong with these chips.  That they would crumble in my fingers or taste like shoe rubber.Fortunately, my fears were unfounded. The chips are just as sturdy as any major brand tortilla chip and there is no unpleasant taste.  In fact, the only difference I taste between these and any other [yellow GMO corn] tortilla chip is that these aren't salty.  And that doesn't bother me.  Not even a little.Now, this did not affect my review, but I should mention that 2 of the 12 bags were open all the way across the top upon arrival.  I imagine this is rather common when shipping sealed bags of air (by air!).  Amazon support nonetheless took me at my word and gave me a partial refund for the open bags.

Pros:* Battery life seems to be as long as advertised.* More responsive than I expected.  Scrolling and dragging things around is smooth, making the touchscreen a pleasure to use.* Screen resolution is a good match for the size, so you don't have to apply any scaling to make things usable.* Light weight* Better than average speakers* Included keyboard dock fits well* I have verified that micro USB OTG adapters work, allowing you to use a USB device without attaching the keyboard dock.  No drivers required.  It just worked instantly.* I can output 1080p to my projector using a micro HDMI to HDMI adapter.* I have experienced no hardware or software glitches in the 5 days I've had it.Cons:* MicroSD card reader is slow.  Benchmarks maxed out at about 23 MB/s read and write on a SanDisk Extreme 32GB card that tests much higher (80 MB/s) in other devices.  See the customer images I submitted for full benchmark results.* MicroSD card sticks out a bit, making it less than ideal for a permanent storage upgrade.* Battery drains at about 0.5% to 1% per hour while sleeping. For comparison, my 3rd generation iPad loses no more than 4% sleeping for 24 hours.* Nearly half the storage is unavailable.  About 35 GB free space when new.* Shipped with dead battery and took 4 to 5 hours to charge to 100%.* Included charge cord is short.* The touchpad on the keyboard dock is pretty bad.  Clicks are loud and responsiveness is poor.Conclusion:It is a great little piece of hardware at a fair price ($400).  There are some shortcomings, but nothing critical.  I would definitely recommend this tablet to others.  The bottom tier Surface Pro with a keyboard cover is over $1000 and there isn't much it would do for me that the Asus T100 can't do just as well.

I chose this over other turners because it has a very long handle and can grip hamburgers for easy flipping and temperature measurement without making a mess out of them.It cleans very easily with a scrubbing sponge

I bought this for my Asus T100TA tablet so I could connect a USB device without using the keyboard dock.  It worked perfectly on the first try!  The connections are nice and tight, and not loose as I had feared from reading some of the other reviews.I can also confirm that the Micro USB plug is a little longer than standard so it doesn't go in all the way.  This is probably so the device will be more compatible with protective cases without modification.

A little larger than I remember them as a kid, but just as good!  They taste exactly like Atomic Fireballs, also made by Ferrara Pan, but these are much smaller and softer.  These are less of a choking hazard for little kids than a full-size jawbreaker.

This cartoon is nearly as old as I am, but Disney aired it plenty when I was growing up.  Whenever the show came on TV, you would have to pry me away from the TV with a crowbar.  All other cartoons were merely adequate time-fillers.But what, specifically, do I like about this cartoon?  Everything!  Every episode was full of adventure, exploration, some fantastic new invention, or keeping the bad guys from taking Scrooge's money.  All topics of great interest to a growing boy.  Even the theme song is great!

These shells taste more or less like any off-the-shelf taco shells by Old El Paso, Ortega, Western Family, Taco Bell, or whatever happens to be in style in your local supermarket.  Except these shells are organic and according to the nutrition facts label they contain only 5mg of sodium per serving (2 shells).  For comparison, a low sodium diet still typically allows for 1000 to 1500 mg of sodium per day.  Assuming it is correct, this sodium content barely registers on the scale.Now if only these guys made tortilla chips the same way.  Oh, wait.  They do!

My house used to be a relative disaster of WiFi connectivity.  I previously ran two separate access points (APs) to get full coverage, each from a different brand, using different SSIDs, and as such they had to be configured on each device separately.  It was up to the device to switch APs.  This rarely worked as desired.  Occasionally, one of the APs would need rebooted to make it pass data to a wireless device.I bought a UniFi system because UniFi APs provide an entirely different kind of experience.  One built for enterprises that don't have the time or patience for the sort of nonsense I describe above.Basically, you install the UniFi controller software on a PC and give it an SSID (a network name) and password.  Then you start plugging UniFi APs into your wired network.  They appear in the UniFi interface as unmanaged APs.  You can adopt an unmanaged AP with a click or two and within moments that AP joins your network, extending its range.  Then, no matter how many APs you have adopted, your wireless devices will see them as one single network.  You connect to that network and then you can roam freely and the APs will work together to automatically switch you between APs as you go out of range of one and into range of another.  As long as you remain within range of one of the APs, you will stay connected.Now, since I had not bought the Long Range version, I figured the range on these would be similar to an ordinary home router.  Boy was I wrong.  I think I could put one of these anywhere in my house or garage and have usable WiFi everywhere else.  But just to be safe, I installed two of them -- in the locations I had kept my old APs.  The third AP is still in the box :)

It has 5 gigabit ports that can power most Ubiquiti gear (any that runs on 24 volts).  These use passive, non-standard PoE, so be sure you know what you are buying.  These get quite hot when several devices are being powered through them; moreso than any standard PoE switch I've used.I bought two of these to replace a rats nest of separate injectors, cables, additional switches, and power bars.  One of the switches works perfectly, but I've had trouble with the other.  On two occasions I have needed to unplug the switches to rearrange the networking gear in my garage.  On both occasions, the troublesome switch booted up but was unable to pass any data through the main 5 ports.  I could access the web interface through the management port only.  The solution on both occasions was to unplug the switch for a few hours and plug it back in when it had cooled off.  Once it starts working, it doesn't stop working unless I power cycle it while hot.Anyway, I've been running them for several months now and have had no performance issues besides that which I mentioned above.  All in all, these are nice switches to have if you need to power a lot of Ubiquiti devices in one place.

With this, I was able to replace six 8-port switches and reduce clutter in my garage which serves as a hub for my network camera hobby.  18 of the 10/100 ports are in use, 14 of them using PoE, and 3 of the gigabit ports are in use.  No problems at all with connectivity or transfer speeds.  According to the web interface, I use about 50 watts of PoE during the day and just under 100 watts at night when all my cameras turn on their IR LEDs.The web interface uses a ridiculously slow web server.  When loading the administration pages, it can't seem to send faster than 10 KB/s and it appears to only allow one active network stream at a time.  This is connected via gigabit ethernet but the web interface pages load almost as slow as if they were hosted via dialup!  Minus one star for that.  Fortunately, the web interface isn't something I foresee needing to use very often.Coming from a consumer background where network switches are almost always silent, it is important to note that this one is not.  It has at least two fans and they are most definitely audible.  This isn't something you'd want to put in a room where silence is valued.

I needed an hdmi switch that would let me easily switch between my Oculus Rift dev kit and another HDMI display without reaching down under the desk to fumble with cords.  This does the job.Pros:+ Small+ Lightweight+ Metal for sturdinessCons:- Bright lights- Strange compatibility issue.  One of the two switches I ordered causes display corruption when plugged in to one of my monitors.  Fortunately this configuration is easily avoidable since I have two switches...

I am a software developer who had a game ready to launch since March when the Kickstarter rewards were supposed to be shipped.  Even though I backed them on the first day of their Kickstarter, I didn't receive my OUYA until near the end of July (about a month after it became available here on Amazon!).  No, I don't live on a remote island somewhere.  I'm located in the lower 48 states of the USA, so there is no excuse for the absurdly long delay.[Controllers]When the console finally arrived, I quickly discovered that the controllers leave a lot to be desired, as one of the first setup steps is to enter your account information (and mandatory payment information!) using an on-screen keyboard.  The controller's touchpad is among the worst I have ever used, due mainly to the ridiculous acceleration and immediately noticable input lag.This leaves the D-Pad and analog sticks for navigating the on-screen keyboard.  These controls are generally much more responsive but still suffer from intermittent input lag while playing a game.  The analog sticks are surprisingly okay, but the D-Pad is terrible.  It is way too easy for you to accidentally move diagonally when you intended to move just vertically or horizontally using the D-Pad.  It is in fact easier for me to be precise using the left analog stick to navigate both on the on-screen keyboard and in games where I have the option.Despite their many flaws, the controllers are significantly more expensive than wireless Xbox, Playstation, or PC gamepads.  They should probably cost half as much.** FYI, you can plug in a USB keyboard to greatly ease and accelerate the setup process.[Console Hardware]The console itself has a nice appearance.  It is small, attractive, quiet, and simple.  The guts of the console aren't very fast, but I suppose you really can't expect too much from a computer at this price point.[Software]The OUYA software is remarkably simple and there doesn't seem to be that much to it.  Basically you have a "Discover" section where you go to browse and download games, and a "Play" section where you go to play games you've already downloaded.  There is a little more to it than that, but nothing particularly noteworthy.As a developer (and user), I'm a little irritated by the behavior of the menu button in the center of the controller.  If you long-press or double-press that button, the game EXITS immediately and you are returned to the OUYA menu.  This wouldn't be such a big deal, but there is no other convenient pause / menu button on the controller, so games typically use it as their normal pause or menu button.  This means if you are not careful pressing it then you could be in for a nasty surprise![My game]It isn't released just yet, and I mention my game only to aid in sharing my experience as an OUYA developer.  I do not mean to advertise here, so I won't even mention the name of my game, but I will say that it is based on the old classic "Bomberman" so it plays on a 2 dimensional grid.  As such, it uses very simple logic and the system hardware requirements scale in direct relation to the size of the game world.I had intended for the game to support a configurable world size so that players could really take advantage of a 1080p display by zooming out and having a huge world.  On my development machine, I could scale the world far beyond any reasonable point without making the frame rate even quiver below 60 FPS. But it turns out that even at the modest default size, OUYA can't maintain a steady 60 FPS once bombs start going off.  This was very disappointing, but not entirely unexpected.The reason for the further delay in releasing my game is partially my fault, and partially OUYA's fault.  Back in 2012, I created two accounts by accident. (I know, I know.  How do you accidentally create a second account, right?)  One way or another, my user name and my game got configured on different accounts and I didn't notice until I was about to submit the game nearly 3 weeks ago.  So I submitted a support ticket asking to have the accounts merged and I haven't had a response yet.  Not a peep.  Not even an automated "we're bogged down right now" message.[Conclusion]The OUYA may be small and good looking, but it performs even slower than I expected.The controller is garbage. Expensive garbage.Support is so laughably slow that I have to wonder just how many other people are having a problem with them too.

This is an interesting book. I never paid a lot of attention to the Food Pyramid. It always sounded weird to me. I'm old enough to have grown up with the 4 Food Groups, where we were told to eat some of each of them. But I was as confused as anyone about how all of the different diets could all work when they were so different. Not only does she go into why we got stuck with the food pyramid, she also explains how all those different eating systems could all work, but for different people She also explained a lot about how to read scientific papers, and includes a few, explaining afterward all the "big words" that frankly make those documents unreadable for anyone outside of the scientific community. It isn't the big words so much as all the abbreviation that you don't get explained.This is a very readable book. The author has a sense of humor where appropriate and also can be deadly serious when that is what we need. I'm going to look for more books by her.

I like these a lot. Obviously they aren't as pigmented as crayons costing three times as much, but you can get a good idea if you like this medium with a good range of colors at a reasonable price. The colors are beautiful. They go down nicely. They dissolve in water well. Basically they do what they are supposed to do without frustrating you. Like I said. I like them.

My intention is to use the pages in the book for collage, but I am going to be reading it first. I started with my birthday. It doesn't have the exact day, but I was born at an interesting time in world history and just knowing what was happening that week from the perspective of the fog of war was interesting. I know how WW II worked out but the reporters writing that week did not.It was also interesting to see how the first page of a newspaper changed over time. One thing that caught me right away was how the headline changed from belonging to the entire front page to belonging to just one story. And pictures from drawings to black and white photos to full color.Literally the history of a full century in a book from a perspective of the people who were living it.

From the photo this looked like it was an interesting single piece. It turned out to be multiple bits of music which is much more useful for art journaling. Especially for backgrounds. I'm very pleased with this purchase.

This works on my 4th generation Kindle, and it works very well. You can search, and you can watch all your subscriptions on the Kindle, which I just love. I have had no problems with it, or either of its earlier versions.

I bought this when I was in rehab recovering from surgery. One of the things I had to do to be able to go home was warm something up in the microwave and safely get it to the table while using a walker. This fit the bill/It locks shut so you can heat soup without it splattering all over the microwave as long as you push the vent button. It can stay locked all the way to the table. If you actually have a hand available to take it to the table, which I did as soon as I graduated to a cane, you can get it there with the stay cool handle.This thing is just wonderful. I still heat soup up with it although I now have no cane and two hands available, just because it does such a good job.

I am pretty sure these are actually supposed to be women's socks for extra large feet. The size chart says for size 8 to 13 shoe. I wear a women's size 10 and the socks were so small I couldn't begin to get them on. If they are actually for a men's size 8 to 13 shoe, it is even worse.
I can use this punch. I wasn't sure I could use any punches. I'm 73 and I have arthritis. It makes perfect circles and it makes them easily. I'm very happy with it.

This is my third year with an Englebreit calendar. Yes, it is mostly the same pictures as last year, but there have been some new ones every year too. I love her sense of humor, and the quotes she uses. It just makes me happy.
This sits under my desk making it very easy to get at my paper stash. If you have a huge amount of paper you would probably need more than one of these, but just one works for me.

I made the mistake of buying oil based poster paint markers and my white pen didn't stay white on my Art Journal pages. With this set all the colors stay the color they started out as, especially the white. Love them.

I bought this, my FOURTH Kindle, because I wanted a dedicated book reader. My 3rd Kindle is one of the Fire HD tablets and it is almost 2 years old, so I'm babying it until the next version of the color tables come out.It does exactly what it is supposed to do. It lets me read books even in places, like my sun room, where glare is sometimes a problem. I have not taken it outdoors, but I bet it does that well too. I keep the light on, and I can easily go a week without charging it. Leave it plugged in overnight and it is good to go for another week.

I bought this scissor so I could fussy cut paper for collage in Art Journaling. It does an excellent job. The blades are sharp from the top to the tip. It has a very tiny turning radius so you can literally make a 180 degree turn without removing the scissors. But if you have to remove it, you can also get a perfect cut using the tips.My only problem was getting it out of the packaging. So far this isn't something that Amazon has asked me to comment on the packaging. I don't know where the manufacturer thinks these scissors are being sold, but can you say overkill. I almost could not get them out.

I bought this book when it was on special along with two others in the same series. The first book had to deal with first book in a series problems. Setting up the world and explaining what is going on with all of the people. I think this is the third book. I read it second and am reading what should be the second book now.I would read the first book first, but frankly you can follow along out of order with this series pretty easily. There is some movement in the lives of the regular characters, but it isn't all that much. This may not be true if the series gets very long, however. But basically this is a series where the mysteries have most of the emphasis. And I like that about it.So far both books have been well written and pretty much page turners, with none of the problems in logic that a mystery series could have. It is a paranormal mystery series, but it is more how the two detectives deal with being on a unit that specializes in supernatural crimes that makes it paranormal than anything else.Basically I have enjoyed reading what I've read, and if there are more I will be buying them.
The card worked just as it was supposed to. I like the upgraded software. And the price was much less than Silhouette sells it for.
I love this book. The projects are clearly explained and they are just adorable. I plan on using the book to make some small Christmas gifts.
I am happy that I could get these pads in a small size. Because they aren't permanent, I prefer to be careful where I use them, so I don't need the big pads. I'm happy with my purchase.
I am happy that I could get these pads in a small size. Because they aren't permanent, I prefer to be careful where I use them, so I don't need the big pads. I'm happy with my purchase.

This is the greatest ink pad I've ever had. Now, it has been years since I've done much stamping, but I do have one Ranger Archival pad as well. Both are permanent. Both will stamp over most things, but when the Ranger Archival pad won't stamp over something and stick, this one will. It dries beautifully. And I need to buy more colors of this stuff.

This turned out to be a slightly shinny cardstock. It is just a bit thinner than regular cardstock. I had no problems putting paint on it, or gluing on it, both of which I wanted to do. I have not put it through my printer at this point so I can't review that part of it.So why only 4 stars? Because I believed I was buying a matte paper and it isn't a matte paper. It is satin rather than shinny, but it isn't matte.

This is the first book out on this subject, and we got lucky. It is a very short book, about 48 pages, but it is a very complete book on the subject.In fact, it included almost every technique I had found on the Internet after months of extensive searches, including one I had seen only in a paid class.So yes, no doubt some reviewers will tell you that you can find all of this on the Internet. (I'm the first reviewer, so there aren't any of those yet.) But it is all here in one place and it is organized very well.If there is a problem with the book it is really a problem with the publisher and the kind of book this publisher produces. There is very little text. Almost everything is in pictures. It is so well organized that the pictures do tell a wonderful story. However, all of the photos are very small.Still, all of the information is well organized, and it is all in one place in a book that is very colorful, and you don't have to spend hours watching YouTube videos to discover the information.Recommended.There is another book on the way. There is no way to decide if it will be a better book, or a worse one. There is no way to know if it will include new and different techniques, although I hope it will. In the meantime, I'm extremely pleased with what this book includes.

Can one be in love with a stylus? Don't have a clue, but I think I am. I like the multiple size tips. I actually use the smallest one most of the time. I have big fingers for a woman and find that there are times my fingers can't make proper contact with the spot that will make a web page, especially on Amazon, move to the next wanted page. But with this stylus, I can.

I love Sudoku. I love it on paper but I like it a lot more in this digital version. And I've spent way too many hours playing it. Everything works. It does not freeze up on my Kindle Fire. It is just too much fun.

I bought this because I needed a rolling cart with drawers deep enough to hold 2 oz paint bottles. The two lower drawers are more than deep enough for that. I've got larger bottles of media in the lowest one right now. I had bought another brand of plastic drawers before and wasn't all that happy with it, but this brand is different. As a result I've bought several other organizers from IRIS and I've been happy with all of them. They make an excellent product.Even full, I can manage to move the cart so it can be moved out of the way when the room I'm using as a studio needs to be used as a bedroom. And I am not the strongest woman out there. The cart does not complain about being moved and I'm not afraid it will fall apart if it is moved. The wheels are there for a reason and they do what they are supposed to do. I am very happy with the cart after several weeks of using it.

I'm not using these for their normal use. I use them to spread glue in mixed media and to get the air bubbles out of thin paper that I am pasting down. They might be good for their normal purpose, but they are amazing for what I am using them for.

Can I say how much I love this journal? Heavy paper that doesn't move when I get enthusiastic with the water. A small size so it isn't intimidating. I'm pretty sure Strathmore intended this range of journals for beginners because they are so up front with what kinds of paper is in each one and what size it is. I have a larger journal with mixed media paper that is thinner but which I also love.It doesn't matter if you are a beginner or an expert. This journal, and the others in the range are safe to buy, and not all that expensive. You will not be disappointed.

This is a great ink pad. The color is also excellent. I didn't want a black pad. I thought a dark brown would be more useful in what I was doing and it was.There is not much one can say about an ink pad, except that this one does its job and does it well.

This is a very inexpensive and cheap Kindle book on making your own stamps. I'm not a Textile Artist, but what she teaches works for Art Journaling on paper as well. Her instructions are clear, and the fact that it isn't a physical book doesn't matter because you don't need it handy when you make your stamps. Definitely worth buying.

This is an incredibly short book for the price, but PACKED with information. She didn't have much room, but she used every inch of what she had to explain her methods. I have not tried any of them. I bought the book during a period when I truly had no idea what direction my creativity would take me after being too ill to do anything but read for several months. And I moved in different directions from the one this book would have taken me.The only problem with the book is that it is so short and so packed that it is a bit overwhelming.

I've decided I hate dabber bottles. I bought several colors thinking I would like being able to dab paint instead of brush it. The problem is that I have not been able to make the bottles work. I've seen tutorials on how to make the paint flow. It doesn't work for me.On the other hand the paint is quite beautiful and the color is great.

This pencil works as it is supposed to. It is easy to draw a straight line with it with one stroke which is easy to remove from the fabric once you are finished with it. It is white, so it only works on dark fabrics. I wouldn't mind a medium color to work on light fabrics, but I haven't gone looking for it.Quilters have a problem. Frequently we need to mark the quilt, but most markers have a down side. As far as I can tell the only down side here is that white doesn't show up too well on white fabric.

You have to understand what this book is. It is not a book written from a devotional point of view. It is a book written from a scholarly point of view. It is not a book trying to debunk religion, but it is a book that asks you to read what you are reading from the point of view of the original readers of the book, and to understand what the original intent of the individual books of the bible had in their own time.I learned a lot from what I read. I already am of the opinion that people wrote the bible, so figuring out what those people were trying to say made sense to me. But on the other hand, as a believer, I was glad I wasn't also trying to deal with an author who was trying to convince me all faith was nonsense.If you believe in the inerrancy of the bible, you won't be happy with this book. If you believe it was a book written by people over a 1000 year period, who had their own agenda, and who wanted to the people of their own time, you just might like what this author has to say.

I wanted thread that would stand up to glass beads when I embroidered them onto a small quilt. I liked having multiple colors. I ended up using the beige because that worked best for the particular project I was working on. I was impressed with both the product and the vendor who packaged the needles that came with the thread so carefully that there was no way they would be hurt in shipping. I've reviewed the vendor in the correct place, but since it is unlikely you will be buying this thread from anyone else, it makes sense to mention it here too.

I was put on this product by a neurologist because I was having night cramps. He looked at the other medications I was taking and realized that two of them were leaching out my magnesium. But you have to be careful with magnesium. You can end up with bad bowel problems if you are not careful. I was told to purchase this particular brand because it is slow release meaning that you can take it and not have bad side effects.

I did not expect to like this product. I couldn't see any reason not to just use copy paper until I used it for the first time. This paper is much thinner than copy paper. It holds together very well while you are using it, but a simple tug will make it fall apart at the seam lines when you are ready to remove it. It is transparent enough that you can see the stitching lines when you hold the paper up to the light as you are placing the fabric. It folds sharply so you can cut away the excess fabric. Basically it does its job. Recommended
This is one of my favorite coffees. I was very happy when I realized that I could order it from Amazon at a reasonable price because none of my local supermarkets carry it.

I probably play 2 or three games every time I pick up my Kindle. At this point I'm playing at the "Advanced" level but there are at least 2 additional higher levels I can progress to. One thing I liked when I recently went to Advanced was that the hint area literally walked me through a more difficult way of finding the next number that I needed to place teaching me something I did not already know. I know when I advance up to a more difficult level that will happen again.Play is smooth. You can place the number notes yourself, or the app will do them for you. You can choose when to check for errors and what to do about them when you find them. In hundreds of games it has never crashed or locked up the Kindle.
I already owned the smaller version of these clips, so I bought the big ones too. I like both sizes. They do the job beautifully in places where pins are annoying.

Most of the reviews that say that these socks run small are from men with larger than usual feet. When the socks arrived it turned out that the manufacturer makes (or possibly made) an Extra Large intended for those sizes. But a Large should have fit a woman wearing a size 10 shoe. And they were a little tight brand new. After washing them, they are obviously smaller than they were.I'm giving them 2 stars because if you manage to get the correct size, these are very nice safe socks.

They recently upgraded the Kindle app. They took out all of the information on the first page, including the humidity and the wind speed. They removed the ability to see a larger piece of the country on the map. If I could go back to the old version, I would.I hate the changes they made.

This might be a great knitting bible for one part of what is becoming an huge knitting world, but it just doesn't work on the Kindle. In fact most craft books don't work well on any of the Kindles I've had. I'm on my third one. The currently one is the larger Fire, and it still doesn't work.In addition I found all of the projects in this book pretty worthless.

What this basically is is the story of one woman's grief and what she did when it was time to come out of it. And if you are grieving, or know that you will be grieving, reading the stories of others is useful. Recommended.
I don't care if it has been over half a century. This is still pretty scary stuff. But worth reading anyway.

I am one of those people who has never managed to learn how to do crossword puzzles. I like puzzles and do a lot of them, but I find that with the right app, I will do puzzles of types that have never worked for me.This is an excellent app for a beginner. I go through the puzzle and put in the words I know. I might stop and not come back until another day at that point and try a second time. But the third time I can ask to have the puzzle checked for mistakes, and I can ask to have the mistakes shown to me. I can ask for clues, one letter or one word at a time. There are some words I will NEVER get no matter how long I try. But there are a lot of words that I will get if I have one or two letters to work from.

I am currently reading book 5 in this series having devoured the first 4 in just a few days.The place is the desert in Utah, and occasionally, in some of the books, Salt Lake City.  The people are a fringe group of the Mormon church that still practices polygamy. We meet two of the main characters in this book, a young medical student and his even younger sister. The young man has been sent by his father, from Canada, to investigate what is probably a murder. The girl is there to meet two of the men her father is considering for her husband.And it begins. Each of the books has its own story, but there is also an arc, especially starting with the second and third books. We get to know who the good guys are and who the bad guys are, and what we learn builds from one book to the next.This is not my normal kind of book, but it is very well written, as is the entire series.

I like Logic Puzzles, so I got this app in addition to the one I already had and liked so much. But there are some real problems with the app, so I can't recommend it. First of all at least one of the puzzles has a bad error. You are told someone IS something, but in reality he IS NOT that something. Which means you will lose the puzzle. If you can't trust the clues to be correct, you can't play.The other problems with the app aren't deal killers. When you choose the yes answer, all of the nos are not put in for you. You have to put them in one at a time yourself. That is just frustrating, but it isn't a deal killer. If you hit the X instead of the DOT when you figure out an answer you get a buzzer. That is OK. It won't let you put in a wrong answer. But if you have already put in the DOT for that line and try to put a second DOT in, it is because you've mistakenly hit the DOT instead of the X. Do it 3 times and you are shoved out of the game.The various parts of each game is shuffled every time you play, so remembering the answer from the last time won't help you. That is good. But sometimes the hints just cancel each other out, and that is just silly. There is also style in creating clues, and you get some really dumbly worded clues in this app.I stopped playing well before I'd tried all the games. Too many bad clues to even continue.

I think I prefer quilts that aren't quite so over the top as far as tiny little pieces go. Still, the author did provide a lot of good information. I think the problem here might be me, but it also might not. I'm unlikely to make any of these projects and this is a project book.

I use this app almost every day. I'm more likely to look at Facebook on my Kindle than on my computer. I can even comment with a sentience or two because that function works pretty well too. And the whole difficulty of scrolling down the page in the web browser on the Kindle is not an issue with this.If you use Facebook, and you have a Kindle, you need to get this app.

I love this game. I have bought 3 sets of puzzles for this game. One of the things I love about it is that you can play each puzzle as often as you want to because you can clear the board and start them over. And I've done that. I started out very slow, but I now do them at a pretty good rate. I will almost certainly buy at least one or two additional sets pretty soon.

I've been taking this brand of fish oil for years now. I used to buy the box of 90 from Amazon. This bag of 120 costs about what the box of 90 used to cost. Same product. Same brand. Same packets. Cheaper and automatic because I took a subscription. I really did not need to have a box. The bag works fine.

This is a great resource for anyone aged 10 or older to start learning the basics of Python. My child has expressed interest in this subject, so I thought this was a basic, fairly inexpensive way to test her interest. The book is well laid out, and realistic in its objectives. The examples are explained in a manner that it easily understood without being patronizing. I really enjoyed this book and I'd recommend it for kids and adults who want a concise book that gives you a basic understanding of Python without being overwhelming or pretentious.

Before I was using the Commuter series to protect my phone but this is an alternative. If you're looking for a slim, sleek case that you can change the look of frequently, this may be the case for you. I like the fact that the design can be purchased from Otterbox or you can use the included design as a template to make your own. I think it's a bit pricey for what you get, especially when compared to the increased durability of the Commuter series, so I removed one star.

Warren the 13th and the All-Seeing Eye is a charming illustrated mystery with a touch of scary, but only in a good way. Warren the 13th is the heir to a once grand hotel that became shabby and empty after his father died and his lazy uncle became his guardian. The hotel supposedly has a secret treasure, the All-Seeing Eye. Warren's new Aunt, Anaconda, is desperately seeking the Eye so that she may regain her witchly powers and do all sorts of evil things. Warren is a sweet, hard-working lad who does his best to take care of the hotel while attempting to avoid his nasty aunt and her punishments. As Anaconda searches for the Eye, events unfold that lead Warren to discover more about himself and the secrets of the hotel. This is a fun read, charmingly illustrated. My only issue would be the recommended age of 10 and up as I think it's best suited to the 8-12 year old crowd.

The color is a nice, deep eggplant and uniform. Unfortunately, the color tends to run/bleed for the first couple of washings so you do have to be careful. The shape is unusual, being that they're square rather than the more traditional rectangle. I think they make great napkins or scrubbing cloths, not so great as drying cloths.

I selected these because I like the dark eggplant color and I needed something bigger than a washcloth, but not as big as a towel to use with my foster kittens. So far these are getting the job done admirably. The color hasn't run in the wash and although there's been a small bit of shrinkage, it wasn't excessive. My towels are soft on both side and they're perfect for bath time or to deal with other messes. I'd definitely purchase more of these in the future if needed.

As others have stated, once we did the experiments, the whole kit seems more like parlor tricks than science. However, my tween had fun completing each project. The directions were easy enough to follow, although it would have been nice to have a list of 'extra' supplies needed on the outside of the box in case you were purchasing it for a gift. It was a fun, educational way to pass a rainy afternoon.

When this first arrived, I didn't have a chance to read it so I left it on the counter. A few days later my tween daughter came up to me and asked about this book. She had seen it lying there, picked it up and wanted to talk. Although she reassured me that she wasn't a victim, she said she could see that it would be helpful for kids who are bullied. She liked the quizes and said the format was easy to read and engaging. Her only complaint was that is almost too easy to read and a bit on the short side. She said she'd recommend it to kids her age.
Larger than expected but works as advertised. Too big for my foster kittens to climb in and out of the until about 6 weeks or so, but perfect for their mama.
Easy to clean, affordable and small. Perfect for kittens. Would purchase again

This is a great compromise if you want to add a little warmth to your pet's bedding area, without worrying about cords or electricity. I've been using it for my foster kittens and they really like it. It isn't soft and snuggly, but they don't seem to mind as long as they're warm. Would definitely purchase again in the future.

Sleek and stylish but very much functional. This will be the 6th battery backup that I’ve owned and used. By far it’s the best, this is due mostly to the form factor. The other backups were formed like small squares about the dimensions of a deck of cards but twice as thick. They didn’t fit in next to my phone very well always leaving a large bulge in the bag or pocket they were in while it charged. With this unit it is almost the height and width as my phone but much thinner so it slides right into the carrying pocket or bracket for my phone. This makes its on-the-go use so much easier. The brushed aluminum look hides scratches and dings, making it less of an eye sore.The charging cable that comes with it is a little long for me but not overly so, allowing a little leeway if you need to have them in separate pockets. By using a USB port, you can easily replace it with any after-market snubby cord or the charge cord that came with your device.I’ve used this back up on a Galaxy SIII and on three of the newer 7 inch Galaxy Tabs. In each case the charging was quick till about 80% and then tapered off, total charge time of maybe 30-40 minutes. Off a single recharge I could completely power all of the devises from 12% and have enough for about a 10-20% charge on a second device. I only used the 2.4 amp slot and only on one device at a time.The only reason for the 4 stars vs 5 is that the casing is not seamless, the front of the backup could very easily develop dings and snags that could lead to opening if dropped or slammed against things in a bag. Since it is designed to be portable in places that are remote enough not to have a wall charging option it should be a little more rugged than a wall charger. Overall, this is a minor quibble and I'm pleased with this charger.

Even though this is technically the 3rd book in the Nantucket Brides trilogy, it works ok as a stand-alone book. It's still best if you read it after the other two though. Hallie is a newly graduated physical therapist and when the opportunity arises to basically start fresh on Nantucket, she jumps on it. She's helping Jaime Taggert, a wounded man with scars both physical and emotional. Throughout the book, they learn to trust and love, helped in part by the two sisters haunting Hallie's new home. There are references to characters from the two previous Nantucket Brides books, as well as previous Jude Deveraux novels. It's a fun summer read and feels like visiting an old friend. If you're a Jude Deveraux fan, I'd definitely recommend this trilogy.

Although the form factor is cool, the execution is just 'meh'. It's a one shot at a time type blaster, which isn't considered to be as much fun in our household. Also, the darts didn't fly fast, far or accurately. This might make a fun toy for someone who doesn't engage in Nerf war or battles but overall, it rates a solid 'meh' from us.

This is one large super soaker and I'm not sure that's a good thing if you're purchasing for a child. The 'wow' factor of this super soaker seems to be that you can attach it to a hose and have a continuous stream of water. Unfortunately, it leaks like a sieve when attached to the hose and you can't really move around or the quick release adapter will snap off. Also, you have to have the compartment filled with water in order to use the hose; otherwise you're just standing there waiting for the compartment to fill up while everyone else is shooting you. When full, it's rather heavy and works in a similar fashion to other super soakers in regards to spray pressure and distance. I think this will become 'Dad's' super soaker for our household, leaving the other guns for my daughter and friends.

I mistakenly thought that this was a book for kids to teach themselves to code, instead it's for you to help your kids learn to code. Even so, it's been a big hit in our household. My spouse was as eager to jump in and get started as my 12 year old. The first night they zoomed through chapters 1 and 2 with my daughter proudly showing off her programs. They've been methodically working their way through the book and both are still enthused. I think having visual and colorful examples are helping to keep her interested. It's also teaching and emphasizing the importance of paying attention to detail and following directions carefully. I'd hesitate to recommend it to kids much younger than 10, but for kids 10 and up, it's a great resource and family project.

While the parents in the room thought the game was a bit blah, the children were enthralled. As other reviewers have noted, there's not a lot of strategy involved; it's mostly luck. On the positive side, it's fairly easy to play beginner or advanced, the illustrations are sweet and it's good for kids to work on their matching type skills. On the con, there's not much challenge and little strategy involved. I can see this being brought out at sleepovers, but it's not a hit for family game night.

If you're a person who likes a variety of scents, this might be the perfect pack for you. I received 6 different scents, ranging from Cherry Pie to Olive Oil. The packaging wasn't the greatest, as the bottles looked like they had been tossed into the box. Thankfully, none of my selection arrived broken or leaking, but I have a feeling that was luck more than anything else. The bottles are a bit larger than your average $1 a bottle liquid soap, although the price per bottle seems a bit higher too so it evens out. Cherry Pie and Mango were the definite hits in this household, while Olive Oil and Almond were definite nots. The soap itself cleans well and the scent isn't too overpowering after you've rinsed your hands. The not testing on animals is a definite point in company's favor and I'd consider buying the Cherry Pie and Mango versions alone. I don't think I'd purchase this particular variety pack for our household as too many of the scents were blah or disliked.

This is one of those haunting books that linger in your memory and appear at sudden moments. Fig (Fiona) has a schizophrenic mother and this affects everything about her childhood. She uses magical thinking, hoping that if she does 'it' right, that her mama will get better and be normal. The book follows Fig from childhood to adulthood and is frankly, rather heartrending. It's a tough read, and it may be best suited for older teens/adults. I can't say I enjoyed it per se, but it is memorable.

Invisible is book two in the Twixt series, after Indelible. I read Indelible first, and I'm glad I did. You could read Invisible as a stand-alone, but I believe the relationship between Joy and Ink is much more understandable with the back story of the first book. In this sequel, Joy is no longer bound to Ink, causing the council to fear her. As she navigates her changing relationship with Ink, her family and friends, she makes decisions that force her to grow up. I really enjoyed the secondary plot of her brother's secret and how the author explored Joy's relationship with him. For the most part, her relationship with her best friend was well done, especially one particular conversation between the two girls. I think Joy made some rather idiotic decisions in the middle of the book, but that makes her more realistic, not less. Even though I had never heard of Dawn Metcalf before, and I'm not the target audience, I'll definitely be keeping an eye out for Insidious, book 3.

Now that I’ve gotten the hang of using my cast iron skillets and roasting pan I figured it was a good time to move on to the next staple everyone says is a must have, the Dutch oven. While it is cast iron, the care for this unit is much different. Unfortunately you’ll either have to self-educate yourself about it or make a costly error. The instructions that come with the Casserole are basic, meant to cover La Cuisine’s entire line, making them overly general and not very helpful to someone who is purchasing their first enameled cast iron. For the most part they say what a lot of other reviewers have said, you can put it in the dishwasher, but it’s better to wash by hand. Also counter to all cooking instruction I’ve read up to this point, you can’t heat it up without something in it, apparently it causes the enamel to release from the cast iron if done repeatedly. I have spent less than $20 for a Lodge 10 inch cast iron skillet and the instructions were much more detailed.Overall I am impressed with the results I’ve been able to achieve. Until now I’ve had to use a cast iron skillet to sear the meat for my roast, use a large pot to par-boil the vegetables and a crockpot slow cooker to make it a meal. Now I can do it all in one, in a quarter of the time and with much less clean up. What used to take 7-8 hours now takes a little more than 2 with slightly better results.Clean up is a snap, you can use soap but you still have to be careful fully rinse and completely dry it before you put it away. I’ve read that the non-stick gets better with time, but only if you don’t use an abrasive scrubber or cleaning agent. Water, vinegar and some soaking time on the stove is all I’ve had to use so far and the results have been very pleasant.

A Brighter Tomorrow: My Journey with Julie is another nice addition to the new American Girl Beforever line. This, like all the other 'My Journey' books, is set up in a choose-your-own-adventure type format. In this story, a modern girl who's recently moved to San Franciso travels back to the 70s and meets Julie. Both girls are experiencing the big 'D', divorce, and the book emphasizes family and feelings. To me this is the least historically educational book of the line, mainly because the setting is so similar to present day. The one aspect that I really enjoyed about the other books in the series was that your child could be learning a little bit of history with the story. Julie's story, (except for the fact that she can't play sports at school), seems lacking in this regard. Also, like the other books in this series, you're directed the AG website for an ending, so be warned. Don't get me wrong, it's a sweet story, and I think it would appeal to a reluctant reader. Most especially if your reader relates best to a more modern girl rather than someone from hundreds of years ago.

We used this with a twenty pound turkey this past Thanksgiving. My husband had no problem using this tool and thought it made transferring the turkey a breeze. I have much smaller hands, and it was hard for me to lift the bird with one hand. If you have the strength to use this device, it's a definite help. If you struggle with transferring the bird due to hand strength, you still may need a second hand.

This reminds me of those movies you loved as a kid, but as an adult you watch and wonder why in the world did my parents let me watch that? If you suspend pretty much all disbelief about the probabilities that children will be able to do everything they accomplish in this book, this will end up being a fun, fast-paced read that you'll devour in one sitting. My tween daughter thought it was great, although she made sure to reassure me that she knew those types of crimes were wrong and not to worry about her following in their footsteps. Some sensitive readers might not do well with the father's death in the beginning of the story, but if you're looking for an enjoyable read, this is it.

The Roar of the Falls: My Journey with Kaya is another nice addition to the American Girl Beforever series. These books are set up in a choose your own adventure type format, although overall I think there's fewer endings than a traditional cyoa book. In this book, our unnamed modern girl is supposed to be a leading a gardening project while she struggles with shyness and a lack of self-confidence. While gardening, she discovers a shell, which when she makes it into a bracelet transports her back to the past. She meets Kaya, a young Native American girl living on the Columbia River in the 1700s. By making different choices, our modern girl experiences a variety of different adventures and meets Kaya's friends and family. I hadn't read much about Kaya previously as my daughter was more interested in other AG characters. This story definitely left both of us wanting to learn more about Kaya and her world. As with the other Beforever books, there is endings which direct you to the website but that's really our only complaint. I think these books are a great way to give children a brief introduction to various American Girl characters, without buying a complete set of books.

Set 10 years after Not a Drop to Drink, In a Handful of Dust shows us Lynn and Lucy settled in their small community. Lynn has raised Lucy as her own, and their affection for each other is evident. Unfortunately, their lives are soon torn about by an outbreak of polio and the sudden destruction it brings. Lucy may be a carrier, so they set out to California to escape what's left behind and in search of something new. Their journey takes them across the Midwest, through the Great Plains and over the mountains. In this book Lucy is the central figure, rather than Lynn and I do think it suffers a bit from that. Lucy's life has been easier than Lynn's at the same age, and I just didn't find her as compelling a character. That being said, this is still an excellent read. Both characters are very believable and it's refreshing to see a positive relationship between a young woman and her mother figure. Although I think you could read this without reading the previous volume, I wouldn't recommend it. The first story is excellent on its own and fleshes out the two characters. If you choose to read these books, you won't be disappointed.

I was worried that Golden Son wouldn't be as entralling as Red Rising; thankfully, I was not disappointed. Picking up two years after Red Rising, we follow Darrow as he navigates the political intrigue and danger of being a Gold in society. Although new characters are introduced, the author didn't forget Darrow's friends and enemies he made during Red Rising, deepening the relationships or feuds. The only thing I disliked was that the book ends on a cliffhanger and I'll have to wait for the third installment. If you liked Red Rising, you shouldn't be disappointed. Golden Son is enthralling, fast-paced and leaves you craving more.

My daughter and I have read the majority of the new American Girl Beforever books, and I have to say, this one is probably my favorite. Our modern girl fails a test at school. With her dad working far away and her mom going to school and working, her grandparents are helping out at home. Her grandparents deal with her failing the test in a firm, but fair manner but she's still feeling sad mixed in with missing her dad. When she rubs an old, family coin, she's transported back to 1864, where she meets Addy. Addy is an escaped slave, living in Philadelphia with her mom. Her brother and dad were sold, and they had to leave her baby sister behind. Right off the bat, our modern girl is faced with the discrimination and the daily trials of being black, even if you're free, during the Civil War time period. Even though my daughter had read books about the civil war before, I think one did a good job of making history seem more real and vivid. My only complaints were the fact that you may be directed to the American Girl website to finish a particular storyline. Also, this book seemed to have fewer endings than others in the series. Overall, this is a good book to introduce your child to Addy and her time period without investing in a whole box set or buying the doll.

Catch the Wind: My Journey with Caroline is good way to introduce a young reader to the American Girl books. It's set up in a choose your own adventure type format with a good amount of historical facts and tidbits. I like the fact that a child can read these books to see what character appeals to them most, before committing to a 6 book set that may or may not be fully read.Basically you read along as a girl whose mother, a Navy doctor, is about to deploy. She's upset/sad/scared for her mom and a little bit resentful of having to take on more responsibilities around the house with her mom being gone. Her mom gives her an antique, family compass that when held a certain way, takes our unnamed girl back to the past. She quickly meets Caroline and then the adventures begin. The story is set during the War of 1812. By making choices at certain turning points, there's a good variety of different adventures to read. Not as many as you'd find in a classic Choose Your Own Adventure book, but enough to get a rough understanding of Caroline's time period and some history.This is a quick read, and I didn't like that there was an option to take you online to finish the story. Not everyone has access to a computer or tablet. It also disrupts the flow of the story to have to put the book down, log in, find what you're looking for, etc... My daughter liked the variety of endings; although it wasn't her favorite story of the Beforever books we've read so far. I think this has to do more with the fact that she hasn't had much exposure to Caroline before. A girl more interested in this specific time period may absolutely love it.

A Plague of Bogles is the second book in the series, after How to Catch a Bogle. In this story, Birdie is living with Miss Eames while Alfred the bogler has moved residences, trying to leave his bogler past behind. Jem was let go from his position and is trying to eek out a living in and on the mean streets of London. Thankfully, fate intervenes and Jem becomes Alfred's new bogler boy (on a probationary status) while Alfred and co. try to find out where a massive surge of bogles is coming from before any more children go missing.This book picks up fairly recently after How to Catch a Bogle ends and, like the first book, is rollicking fun. You don't have to read the first book, but I think doing so deepens the stories and the characters. It's a bit on the dark side, especially when they discover exactly who is feeding the bogles and what the bogles are being fed. I don't think it's too gruesome though; my tween tore right through both books and she's the sensitive sort. The characters are well described, as is London. The story is catchy and fast-paced. Overall, this is a fun series that's a little bit scary and a lot of 'can't stop reading, must finish'. The ending definitely hints at a third book to come and I'll be looking for it.

This is a nice, straight forward drill book. I really liked the drill finder in the beginning of the book to help you easily skim down the available drills so you could quickly compare. Drills were also broken down into types such as dribbling drills or shooting drills to make it even easier to find a specific drill type easily. The included diagrams are basic, but effective. The related drills tip for each drill is also a nice bonus, in case you want to add a bit of variety to keep things animated. More experienced coaches might find it a bit simplistic, but I think this would be a great resource for a new coach or a parent who wants to work with their child at home.

I'm a happily married Spanish man named Héctor, but who wouldn't be tempted, que?  Unfortunately, my approach caught me in a time loop initiated by the idiot science intern working in the experimental laboratory on the top of the hill: it was I who put the boobies on display in the first place!  After three days of looping in a way that would make Novikov himself proud, I was forced to (albeit, extremely indirectly) kill the poor girl to save the life of my wife.Granted, it's the intern's fault for turning on that damned machine, not mine. This merkin is beautiful, functional, and of the highest quality.  However, it needs to be kept coated in Jheri Curl at all times to retain its shiny appearance.  This issue caused significant problems for me when the Pepsi commercial pyrotechnics lit it on fire.  My genitals were scarred to the point that no hair remained (neither mine, nor the merkin's), and so I had to get a second merkin.  I eventually decided upon a Caucasian-looking merkin with straighter hair and no need for the Jheri Curl.It took me a while to recover from my injuries, as well.  While in the hospital burn unit, I took large doses of prescription medication which led to a snowballing dependence on painkillers, and this fueled increasingly bizarre behavior both on and off stage.  The high mercury content in the skin-whitening agents used for masking penis vitiligo didn't help my sanity any, either.  Eventually Los Angeles County incorrectly accused me of being a pedophile, I nearly went bankrupt from uncontrolled spending, and I died from general anesthesia given to my by a doctor so stupid he tried to resuscitate my emaciated corpse on a suspension bed.  And it all started with just one curly merkin.Ultimately, I'm glad I made the purchase.  However, I advise the sellers to add a warning about these possible side effects.

My dog has been missing her husband and dildo for a little over three weeks.  Unfortunately, most people can't understand canine speech patterns like I can.  They just smile down at my dog as she desperately barks for help!  It's so depressing.Well, our long wait is finally over!  With this shirt, my dog can spread the word about her missing husband and dildo even when I'm not by her side. The unusually tiny picture printed on the shirt is just barely large enough to read (you have to squint a little), but not too large to be obtrusive.  To top it all off, light cyan is my dog's favorite color, and she simply adores useless pockets on her backside as random crap falls out of them with every step she takes.In short, this is is exactly the product we've been looking for.  God bless you, T-Shirt Frenzy, for your Nostradamus-like insight into this common form of suffering surely experienced by dogs around the world.Now only if I could find a shirt lampooning my cat's HIV infection!  Baby steps, though.  Baby steps.

New Oreo-flavored Oreos are the latest thing in self-referential snacking technology!  By eating the creamy center first, which is itself composed of smaller pieces of Oreo Blizzard cookie, you'll learn to appreciate the arbitrarily-large consistency of Nabisco's latest tasty confection.  (Although the experience might seem incomplete, please remember: no crunchy snack biscuit can be both consistent AND complete.)These delicious recursive treats are about as close as you can get to the set of all sets without breaking all of mathematics.  Even famed logician Kurt Gödel might not have starved himself to death if he'd had these in his cupboard!  Don't trust Zeno of Elea: these cookies will only stay on store shelves for a finite period of time.  Do yourself a favor and grab a bag while non-infinitesimal quantities last.In summary, each Oreo Blizzard cookie is every bit as awesome as an Oreo Blizzard cookie.  Five stars (one for each star in this review).

The tree looks nice with gum drops, but there's a selling point they missed: the size of the display/toy is simply perfect for little kids' fingers!  A child's dainty digits can fit into all the nooks and crannies of the tree, which makes it much easier to load (or unload) the tasty treats.  Essentially, using the tree is much easier if you have access to kids, and any toy that encourages child involvement is sure to be a hit with the whole family!To top it all off, the tree is expertly designed to allow sweet drippings from each treat to flow down the branch-work to the plate below, where they are collected.  The crimson rivulets and copper-scented puddle which form when used in this manner make a beautiful and functional addition to the tree's credit.My only criticism: it would be nice if this item could be sold in tandem with a covering bell jar.  Flies will take to the puddle almost immediately, and the odor is less than pleasant once the fluid begins to coagulate.  But again: it's perfect for kids' fingers!
Very scratchy, very painful.  Butter did not help much.  Worse still, tiny crannies catch and yank hairs.  Would not recommend.

For years I used actual tampons to smuggle liquor, and it was a difficult learning process with trial and error.  It took several tries to discover that unused tampons hold more liquor than used tampons.  However, the technique was still problematic as I would absorb the alcohol too quickly.  Once I realized you could siphon the booze orally, things went much more smoothly.  But if you don't add the food coloring you can get caught, and if you do add it people look at you very strangely (which doesn't make much sense to me given the current popularity of vampires in the media).Well, this is definitely the best method for using tampons to hold liquor that I've seen.  Not only does it hold several ounces of liquor, completely eliminating the inconvenience of drinking a tiny amount of alcohol before arriving at an event, but it also looks much more natural to tilt a tampon container directly against your lips: significantly less sucking and munching draws less attention, oddly enough.We truly live in an amazing time.  I can hardly wait to see what's next, but my fingers are crossed for a douche-related solution...!

I'll admit, I was skeptical.  Could I wear my iPhone awkwardly around my neck while bike riding?  While rapidly downhill skiing?  While golfing, as each swing causes it to comically spin around my neck until my hat pops off?  Would it magically hover in midair as I strike a rakish pose, leaning sharply to the side in an expensive business suit?  Would the phone somehow always directly face the camera?Well, these hilarious photoshops have convinced me!  With the Lanskin lanyard skin case, I can do virtually anything and my iPhone will always be there around my neck, connected by two white lines crudely drawn in MS Paint.The only downside: wearing the lanyard may cause your iPhone to look a little less attractive due to image compression.  However, I really don't mind.  This way I get some "Sweet Bro and Hella" Jeff credit for the jpeg artefacts.  Five stars!

I too have been spammed by the author (under the address of review73@aol.com).  All you have to do to see that this book poorly written and extremely unfunny is to "look inside" at the preview.  Go ahead, take a look.  You'll be stunned by how bad the portions of the book are which the author is actually willing to show you for free.Even though this is a work of intended tongue-in-cheek humor, it is neither parody (it has nothing to do with genetics) nor satire (it has no large analogy to make, as far as I can tell).  Further, the author apparently has no idea what a "gene pool" actually is, which is kind of important if you want to use it as a basis for humor.  Example, from page 2: "The human gene pool is the summation of all that has happened or learned since the earliest form of bi-pods [sic] first stood on the earth."  Sorry...that's not "humorously" wrong, that's just uneducated.Nearly all of the "humor" in the book preview comes from the author insulting the audience, which is tiresome after the first few pages.  Again, check out the preview...you don't actually have to purchase the book to see this.  (Thank you Amazon!!!)  Oh, and the stale pun name "O.E. Vey" appears on every other page.  So if you've read this and looked at the preview and buy the book anyway...well, maybe you prove the author's only point: the reader should be thinned from the gene pool.

I never took Niacin but as a supplement it has properties that help the cardiovascular system and it dilates all vessels in the body enhancing the oxygen exchange. I don't suffer from any heart related disease but I take niacin just for well being.Niacin, or vitamin B3, as it is also known, is involved in over 50 metabolic processes that are meant to turn carbohydrates into energy. Besides providing energy to the cells from the entire body, niacin is also responsible for the integrity of these cells. Further on are listed some of the processes niacin participates in:• Antioxidant effect• Blood sugar control• Decrease of cholesterol levels• Detoxification• Production of adrenal hormones• Production of hydrochloric acid in the stomach• Production of sex hormonesWith Niacin comes the niacin flush. The first time I took one of these pills, I became red like a tomato and hot like fire. Honestly it was a scary moment but it lasted only for few minutes and then everything was back to normal.I understand the flush is a normal effect and some people may be more reactive than others. I've learned that if I take niacin with a drink in the morning I'll get the flush but if I add something solid, I will not.No complains about the product.Vitamin B3 will also turn fat into energy, as it is also involved in fat metabo

I have owned a Vitamix for over a year but cleaning it is not easy task, specifically when you need to reach the bottom of the container and work your way around the blades. The residual buildup has been harder and harder to remove from the blades and around this area.I’ve read about some how-tos to remove buildup it by letting the Vitamix with white vinegar all night but the results were not satisfactory.I came across this special Vitamix wrench which I received few days ago. Here some tips on how to use that may be helpful.Removing the bottom of the Vitamix with it is quite simple but a bit tricky:- Turn the container upside down on top of a fabric.- Insert the wrench on the circular piece at the bottom of the Vitamix which will be facing you.- Unscrew it turning it counterclockwise.- After you remove it notice the blade piece there.- Tap gently on the blade piece several times with something non-metallic (I used the bottom of a wooden screwdriver).- The blade piece won't come down easily, at least on my case because it was the first time I remove it. Keep on tapping.- Eventually it will fall over the fabric you placed under the Vitamix earlier.Now finally you can really clean up your Vitamix.So I wonder, why this cheap wretch doesn’t come with a $500 blender?

Flaxseed provides many benefits for your health. Benefits of flaxseed, due to its Omega 3 content. Flax seed is most highest natural foods that contain Omega 3 among other foods, you only need 1 to 2 tbsp of it to meet daily requirement of Omega 3 (although I don't think it should be a replacement for fish based omega 3).Clinical studies suggest that flaxseed oil and other omega-3 fatty acids may be helpful in treating a variety of conditions.High cholesterolPeople who follow a Mediterranean diet tend to have an increased HDL, or "good" cholesterol level. The Mediterranean diet emphasizes fish and healthy fats, such as olive oil, and has a healthy balance between omega-3 and omega-6 fatty acids. Whole grains, root and green vegetables, daily portions of fruit, fish and poultry, olive and canola oils, and ALA (from flaxseed, flaxseed oil, and walnuts) are also part of the Mediterranean diet. Red meat and saturated fats are not part of the diet.However, whether taking flaxseed or flaxseed oil as a supplement can help lower cholesterol is up for debate. Some small studies show it has beneficial effects on cholesterol levels, but at least one double blind study found no evidence that it lowered cholesterol.Heart diseaseEating a diet rich in fruits, vegetables, whole grains, nuts or legumes, and ALA rich foods may substantially reduce the recurrence of heart disease. One of the best ways to help prevent and treat heart disease is to eat a diet that is low in saturated and trans fat and rich in monounsaturated and polyunsaturated fats (including omega-3 fatty acids from flaxseed and fish). Evidence suggests that people who eat an ALA rich diet are less likely to suffer a fatal heart attack. ALA may reduce heart disease risks through a variety of ways, including making platelets less “sticky,” reducing inflammation, promoting blood vessel health, and reducing risk of arrhythmia (irregular heart beat).Several human studies also suggest that diets rich in omega-3 fatty acids (including ALA) may lower blood pressure.However, it’s not clear whether taking flaxseed oil as a supplement would have the same effect on heart health.Sjogren’s syndromePreliminary evidence that suggests taking 1 - 2 g of flaxseed per day can improve the symptoms of dry eye in people with Sjogren’s syndrome. Sjogren’s syndrome is an autoimmune condition where the immune system attacks glands in the body that produce moisture, like salivary and tear glands.CancerStudies suggest that flaxseed oil may help prevent the growth of breast tumors. In one Canadian Study, researchers discovered that flaxseed oil prevented breast tumor growth, likely through ALA content. Source: Flaxseed oil | University of Maryland Medical Center

I have finished my first bottle and I can notice any difference at all.Like many of you, I have purchased this product to help with joint pain (in my case elbows and shoulders).I used to take the joint products from Costco but I left them because they contain titanium dioxide and magnesium stearate (if you don't know what they problem with these substances are, Google titanium dioxide cancer).Anyway, I searched for a product that will not contain any toxic substances.I came across with this product and I decided to give it a try although I have never heard of the brand and there is very little literature about the brand on the internet.I tried the recommended dosage, but after 2 weeks I increased it by a factor of 2. I have had one of these for about 6 years already. I pull it out for those cold nights when you need a little more heat in specific spots.I'm surprised that after so many years it still working well.I also have the "Presto HeatDish Plus Parabolic Heater" that you can buy at Costco. Side by side and at a much lower prices, this unit provides more heat.I was reading some of the other customers' reviews complaining about how difficult is to turn on and off the unit.I'm not so sure where the problem is. To turn it off, just press the on button. To turn it off. Hold and press the same button for 2 seconds.The thermostat has multiple settings organized in 2 groups: Low and High. Each one of them can go from 60-85 in 5 degree increments. To me that is enough. The Low and High settings are a great idea because you can control how much electricity the unit will consume.We have had a tough winter in the Washington DC / Virginia area so I decided to purchase another one of these units.The two combined have allowed my central heating system to work less (consuming less of the high voltage the central system uses) while maintaining the most important areas of our home warm enough.The unit comes with a fan that helps circulating / distributing the heard evenly.In my opinion, the unit is a keeper.

I purchased these trying to replace my old Altec Lansing MZX206 MUZX Headphones with Mic and call function (Old Version).With so many reviews I felt that I could give them a try.The pros are that these are cheap, they seem like they will last, they fit nice to the ear and the mic works with my iPhone 5s.The cons (actually the only one but is a deal breaker) is that the sound coming out is horrible.My music sounds "dull". I downloaded this game for my 7 year old daughter. Initially it seemed like an interesting game for her to develop her imagination.
