The sound is inconsistent, and voice levels vary a great deal from segment to segment; there is also a lot of background noise from the paper, water, etc.  The camera work was also frustrating - she would be describing something to watch for in the technique, but it was still a wide shot and we could not see what she was specifically talking about; there are random overhead shots, and sometimes she is gesturing to something that is off-screen.I was frustrated after viewing; frankly I think it would have been a fabulous article in a magazine with basic info on the various techniques, but it just doesn't work as a DVD.

It at least started off in an interesting way - chef Darcy has just had her restaurant go up in flames, and she goes to stay with a friend for a little while... and then meets Mr. Ridiculously Perfect.  The mountain man - artist - perfect stand in father - community go to guy, blah blah blah. Seriously, he was a cardboard cutout, not a character.Even the "problems" were cheesy and tied up entirely too quickly.  And the ending?!?  Dylan is having a hard time getting Darcy into bed (due to external circumstances, not her protests), so he decides he might as well propose?!Don't waste your time on this book.

I like an eclectic mix of chairs in our dining area, and this very affordable, so I took a chance. It's not terrible, but the biggest disappointment was that when you attach the seat, the two front legs are noticeably larger, so there's about a 1/2 inch "overhang" from the legs on the side of the seat.  We tied on an oversized seat cushion to hide the issue, but just FYI if you're planning to use them "bare"

This show has a great premise, props, and sets, but the storytelling misses by a lot. Too many of the characters, especially the Nazis and Japanese, are one-dimensional, hackneyed villains. There is no nuance here as there is in a show like The Americans.There are also way too many torture scenes. We get it. There's no need to show it over and over again.It's more like a one note blockbuster Hollywood movie than exceptional TV shows like Breaking Bad, The Americans, etc. I was really looking forward to this one, but I'm bailing, not binging.

Wow. These are nice. Years ago I purchased much lower priced Skullcandy buds, but they've really upped their game with these.I tested them on a laptop and first used it for a Netflix movie. The sound was as good as my expensive sound bar that I use for the TV. Then I tested them with music. Again, great sound...made me want to listen to music all day.The buds paired well and are as comfortable as any I currently own.I'm a middle-aged woman, so I was amused by all the pot references, but I doubt anyone will be upset by it.I review so many earbuds that I end up giving away a lot of them. I will NOT be giving these away.

I believe the manufacturer contacted me about reviewing this product because I previously reviewed The Motherhood Collection washcloths. These are nice washcloths, but The Motherhood Collection is superior because of the great packaging, size (they're larger), and overall soft feel.These are, as I said, still very nice but it does seem like a copycat. Also, the manufacturer needs to hire a better English translator. Here's an example of the enclosed card (signed "A father from China"): "Father.son concern about sound growth of your baby every day, pass father's temperature and love to yours and bring your life endless joy and warmth."NOTE: I received a sample in exchange for a review.

This is a great pair of earbuds that comes with a functional case, charging cable, and replacement rubber earbuds. It easily paired with my iPad, and I was pleasantly surprised at the sound. VERY NICE bass sound.This is one of the better under $30 earbuds out there.NOTE: I received a sample in exchange for a review.

This scratch concealer is made for scratches in the glossy clearcoat on your hardwood floors. And for that application, it works fine. It covers up the white and makes the scratches much less noticeable.My hardwoods have a satin finish on them that is thinner than a high gloss clearcoat, and this product does not fix scratches in wood. I suspect it might have worked but my satin finish is so thin that all my scratches are into the wood. They do recommend that if you have a scratch deep enough into your wood to first treat that with a wood touchup marker and then apply this concealer over it.The only reason I gave it four and not five stars is that they don't make clear that this is the for the glossy finish that a lot of hardwoods have. Just not mine. It works for what it was intended. It's just a narrower use than I thought.NOTE: I received a sample in exchange for a review.

Kudos to the package designer on this product. Lots of thought was put into this. Maybe too much. For example, the replacement rubber ear buds are stored in the box rather than the usual plastic bag, and while it looks cool they're not as accessible and, frankly, I prefer to get rid of the box, especially since you also receive a case AND a bag.In terms of sound, they're adequate. Not the worst and certainly not the best. But they look cool, and I really like the wire-like cable.NOTE: I received a sample in exchange for a review.

I really like the look and sound of these earbuds. For the price, they are a great deal.The box is simple but compact. It comes with a charging cable, earpieces, and instruction manual (very faint and difficult to read). The black and blue design is cool and elegant, and I was able to pair the earbuds quickly with my iPad. I did have trouble opening the charging outlet before my wife finally used a needle to open it, but I got over the irritation when everything worked well after that.The bass is very good, and I think most people will be quite happy with these earbuds.NOTE: I received a sample in exchange for a review.

I'm a firm believer in insoles, and these are impressive. They appear well-made and definitely make my boots more comfortable. I like to buy my boots a little larger, so I can use insoles because they make a big difference when you work on your feet.They're well worth the investment if you own work boots. I especially like that they have the one year guarantee because insoles often wear out (start fraying) in a short time.

I am a Hillary fan. Bigtime. So I found this HRC Presidential Playset amusing. The whole thing is very tongue in cheek and should delight all ages, though it'd certainly be a great gift for a young feminist who is now growing up in an era where a woman president will not be such a big deal. Finally.The set is already pretty complete, but you can also go to a website and get additional dolls and other bonus goodies (though nothing was available when I checked--everything should appear once the book is released).

This is a very cool set of 6 small (dishcloth-size) washcloths. You can dry, polish, and scour with this variety assortment, and they all do an excellent job, especially the scouring ones.The only thing I didn't like about them was that they were bound together with many of those super-annoying plastic tabs that must be cut with scissors. The result was small fabric tears and unraveling. PLEASE stop using these stupid things.

These are basic wired headphones that don't offer bluetooth or a microphone. However, they do offer excellent sound. It's perfect for my old school mp3 player that I use for music and podcasts when I work out. I was very surprised at the quality.NOTE: I received a sample in exchange for a fair and honest review.

This was super easy to set up and use. The instructions are clear and easy.This allows me to use my car stereo (on a 2005 Toyota Corolla) to connect a bluetooth device and play music, podcasts, etc. through the device. It will also allow one to use a bluetooth cellphone to make calls, answer calls, etc.The sound is okay, not great, but not terrible either. This is the second such gadget I've tested, and this one is superior as there's less static and better sound.NOTE: I received a sample in exchange for a review.

This is an inexpensive thermometer that's versatile and easy to use. It's especially handy to have around the holidays. Although we don't consume meat, we have used it for making candy and homemade mozzarella cheese (tasty!). It's accurate and fun to use.NOTE: I received a sample in exchange for a review.

This can be used for more than meat, but it's a great tool to use when grilling. You definitely don't want to take chances with uncooked meat.This is a versatile kitchen/grill thermometer that is very easy to use. The instructions aren't great, but after some trial and error you'll be glad you have it.NOTE: I received a sample in exchange for a review.

This is an old school, simple toy that is inexpensive. In fact, it's surprising it's as inexpensive as it is because it is well-made and constructed of silicone.It's not complicated, and though not as versatile as other toys, it'll suit most people's needs.NOTE: I received a sample in exchange for a review.

This toy does not have all the bells and whistles and comes with an odd battery that may not be easy to replace. It's somewhat small which may (or may not) please some. It's best for those who enjoy penetration but will also work for those who don't.It is well-made and simple to use.NOTE: I received a sample in exchange for a fair and honest review.

You will need to supply your own AAA batteries (2), but this is a versatile toy that is well-made. It's more suitable for those who enjoy penetration, but it's not a bad tool to have in your toy box.NOTE: I received a sample in exchange for a fair and honest review.

These towels looked dark in the images but turned out to be a very light faded gray. Definitely not as attractive as I thought they'd be.They're also lightweight and not really suited for use as a towel. They feel and look fairly cheap, like something that would come from a dollar store. I will be probably use them to place cooked dishes on.

These worked very well. No problems so far.The look is modern and 21st century. Maybe a little brighter than what they replaced, but not a significant difference.NOTE: I received a sample in exchange for a review.

I really like these coated seeds because you can keep an eye on them and see when they germinate. It took about a week and half, but they did germinate.You will need to use a lot of this to make a difference, but if you have a small area this is a good bet for you. I will update as time goes on and report back on how well the grass does.

I LOVE the look of these vintage bulbs!!!!!I used them in a somewhat inexpensive torchiere, and they really upscale the entire look. The bulbs give off a warm yellow glow, and despite being 60 watt, they throw off a fair amount of light.Although somewhat expensive, they should last a long time. And they look special and lovely.NOTE: I received a sample in exchange for a review.

We're down to just one dog now. This guy is still pretty active, but he's getting up there.The biggest problem he has is his weight. He's a little heavy, and while I want him to get to a healthier weight, I also want him to like his food.Fortunately, he's not picky. I wasn't surprised when he ate this like a treat. He loves food and particularly likes new tastes. He seems to be particularly delighted with this flavor and ate a bowl of it dry without complaint. I plan to rotate this with other dry (and wet) food, but so far I'm pleased with it.

This is a nice, well-made, substantial brass bracelet that is almost unisex in its design. The soft gold color of this brass is very nice. You can tell this piece is crafted with care. It comes in a nice gift box.I like this plainer design in a bracelet. I tend to wear multiple bangles, and this fits in nicely with my other pieces. The reason I gave it four out of five stars is because I think the price is a little bit high. However, this is a quality piece of jewelry in both feel and look. The fact that it's handcrafted, high-end contemporary design may make the price a little higher.All in all, very happy with this bracelet.NOTE: I received a sample in exchange for a review.

This is a quality product from a quality company. You pay a premium for Watersmart Plus Coating Technology; however, it does protect the grass seed and hold in water which makes establishing the seedling go much smoother with less effort upfront.The seven pound bag says it'll cover 2900 square feet which is plenty to overseed high traffic areas and fill in thin spots, so this bag does go a long way. Germination happened within the five to ten days. All in all, an easy way to overseed--the coating protects the seedling and allows them establish than plain seed.Looking forward to my refreshed lawn.

While the jury is still out as far as the serum's long-term results (and the claims are, frankly, dubious), I like this product.First, the bottle is pretty. I don't particularly like pink, but this one is attractive and solid. Second, although the product goes on a bit oily, it takes only a small amount of time to blend into my skin. Third, my face felt smooth and soft and, yes, moisturized, after using.Finally, while I might use other products for anti-aging, I like this fine as a moisturizer.

I mainly wear long-sleeved shirts in all seasons. In the past, most of my purchases have been at Gap. The quality seems to have been going down, so I was ready to try a different brand.This is a shirt I like a lot. It fits great and seems well-made.It is a bit sheer, but other than that, this is an inexpensive alternative to pricier shirts.

I've used bags like this before, but this one is superior. It's larger and holds up much better, for one thing, and it's also versatile. It can be used to make nut milk (or coconut, rice, etc.), cold brew coffee, yogurt, cheese, sprouting, ghee, and more.I'm excited about the possibilities.NOTE: I received a sample in exchange for a fair and honest review.

Wow. These are really, really nice!I was surprised at the quality of these sports sunglasses. I plan to use them for cycling, and they'll work out great.The quality and workmanship is high. In fact, they exceeded my expectations. By a lot. They also come with a nice case.It is a little nervewracking to change out the lenses (they feel like they might break), but once I got the hang of it, it went well.They're not only functional, but they also look coolNOTE: I received a sample in exchange for a review.

This was an easy-to-use gel that felt refreshing when I applied it to my eye area. Although I don't see much difference in terms of dark circles (I've had these most of my life), I do find the gel made my skin feel soft.This is not a miracle product, but it's a good eye moisturizer that will make your skin feel good.NOTE: I received a sample in exchange for a review.

I've used several of the Xen-Tan products, and this one is my favorite. It's the easiest to use, and the results are quite good.The scent is pleasant, and the "tan" is convincing. This is a much better solution than unhealthy tanning beds or expensive sprays. This is the best alternative if you want a healthy-looking tan year-round.

Although it's billed as an anti-aging cream, this appears to be an expensive moisturizer marketed to men.The product has almost no scent (I wouldn't have minded more scent). The biggest issue I have with it is that it goes on thick. Very thick. It was finally absorbed by my skin, but it took a while. Also, I've used lots of anti-aging creams, and my face usually feels quite soft and dewy after applying. This one, not so much.It's not bad as a moisturizer, but it's not my favorite.

Let me start off by saying that this is a very attractive timepiece. It's rose gold plated over a stainless steel body. You can see the movement in the front, and the back is open as well. It's amazing how many parts and pieces go into this, and it's really interesting to watch it work.This is a very large and substantial watch. It's thick and heavy to hold all the inner workings. And there's something to be said for a really pretty watch to dress up in.It comes nicely presented in a gift box. And the stainless steel deployant clasp mechanism is a nice touch.Having said all that, the instructions that came with this watch appear to be for a different style watch, so I'm having trouble setting the date and 24-hour mechanism. I was able to set the day of the week mechanism through trial and error. I went to check the website for additional instructions, and it appears to be down.There are three buttons on this watch, but I'm unable to adjust one of them. This could be user error, but there's no way for me to know since I can't find accurate instructions.I'm not sure this watch ever sold for anywhere near $755 on account of the band not being a very nice leather. Also, the fact that it comes with an instructional, cheap-looking leaflet rather than a booklet.However, if you're looking for a nice, interesting watch, consider it. I think of it, though, as costume jewelry. I really wanted this watch to be a little higher quality than it was. But you can tell by looking at it that it took some time to put together, and, again, it's very intricate and pleasing to watch the self-wind movement.

This is an easy way to get magnesium into your diet. I've used Viva products in the past, and this company is serious about research and safety.Magnesium is an important supplement because studies show that most people do not get enough magnesium through their diet--and it plays an  important part in maintaining the body. Especially as we age.I don't usually complain about the size of the pills, but these are very large. It could definitely present a problem for people with small throats.

UPDATE: Found another use for these great gloves. Used them while exterior painting. The gloves fit great and kept the paint off my hands and nails.ORIGINAL REVIEW:These are great for the kitchen. I occasionally need to use gloves when making bread, veggie burgers, falafel, etc. These enable me to protect my hands and nails and also ensure food safety.I never gave much thought to using vinyl gloves in the kitchen, but now I'm not sure I can live without them.

These are impressive bluetooth headphones that are relatively inexpensive and still have a great sound.The headphones fold (that's a nice feature) and are sweat-resistant if I decide to use them when I work out. They're comfortable and lightweight.Of course, the important factor is the sound--and it exceeded my expectations. I was able to pair it (after a few tries) with my iPad. I was also able to pair it with my PC...but couldn't get them to work with it, which was disappointing.Still, these are cool headphones. They come with a carrying bag (my wife thought it was so neat she's already run off with it), user manual, USB charging cable, 3.5mm to 3.55mm cable, and some stickers. They appear to be marketed to someone younger and cooler than me, but this middle-aged woman admires this product too. I especially liked the thorough user manual.

This is a whole lot of Hershey's chocolate. It's an assortment, so there's four varieties of goodness--Hershey's Milk Chocolate, Reese's Peanut Butter Cups, Almond Joy Candy, and Kit Kat. That's a 90-Count Snack Size Assortment Box...almost four pounds.Wow. Yes, the smart thing would be to wait until Halloween and hand them out to the kiddies, but these are way too tempting. Seriously, though, I like the small size and the four flavors. If I can limit myself to two bars a day, I'll get my daily chocolate and not gain lots of weight.My box arrived in great shape. The candy is fresh and unbroken. And I'm in chocolate heaven.

As we age, old injuries (and new ones) start to take their toll. Most of us have aches and pains, and this is a product that is designed to help.I experienced no itching, and though I can't say it worked miracles there does seem to be some pain easing. It may be the placebo effect, but who cares?This is worth a try if you're dealing with chronic pain.NOTE: I received a sample in exchange for a fair and honest review.

The purpose of this gadget is to enhance the sound capability of your PC or laptop (Windows or OSx). You simply plug the device into a PC USB, and the device automatically loads the necessary software.There's a headphone output and a coaxial digital output. Both are 1/8 ". Probably the most amazing thing about this device is its size. It's about the size of a flash drive and has an aluminum casing, so you can transport it without too much worry about damage.It will definitely make the sound quality increase while also increasing the flexibility of dvd, cd players, etc. It essentially turns your analog sound into digital sound.So far it's working well. It comes with a carrying pouch, Micro DAC, USB extension cable, coaxial digital cable, and the user guide. Unfortunately, the user guide is skimpy, and you may need to turn to other Internet sources to really understand how this thing works.

This is a very good idea. I have been using melatonin for some time now to help with sleep--and it's been wonderful. Many times, however, my wife and I are also dealing with pain at bedtime, mainly because of sore joints and muscles. So combing glucosamine chondroitin in a supplement could be a very good thing.It will, of course, take some time to determine if the supplement works, and I will update at a later date, but I am eager to give this a shot. It's especially good for middle-aged and older consumers.

These are well-made, inexpensive pruning shears that work quite well. I usually buy the more expensive kind that require sharpening, but I was pleasantly surprised at the quality of these.They require little effort and cut effectively. They are perfect for the home gardener.NOTE: I received a sample in exchange for a fair and honest review.

I was really hoping the picky dog would like this, but he won't touch it. The other dog--he'll eat anything--loved it, of course, and ate every bit he was given.I do like that the ingredients are healthy. I also like the small size of the kibble.

I like the plainness of this planner. It doesn't call attention to itself. I also like the classy added touch of the ribbons.While I doubt anyone needs the Contacts page, there are some useful features. I especially like the large blocks for each calendar date. I also like the Notes section at the back. I plan to use the planner as a journal, and both of these features will make it easy.It is cheaply made--the cover is essentially cardboard, and one corner is already crimped after going through the postal service. Also, I wish the planner started with the last quarter of 2015--I want to start using this planner today.

I have been buying Gap underwear, but the quality has decreased. I never really thought about Fruit of the Loom panties, though I do love their t-shirts.These fit well and are flattering. And they're reasonably priced. I'm not sure about durability, but I am very pleased with these.

Yes, it does work. Is it painful? Hell, yes.Is it worth it? Hmm. The jury's still out on that.I may use it for a while, but I'm guessing I'll go back to my razor. I used one of these years ago and figured that enough time had passed that it would work without causing tears.Seriously, it's the 21st century. No one can make one of these that doesn't hurt?

We use the garden hose frequently, and this is a great addition. It is sturdy, well-made, and effortlessly performs the function it was designed to do.This gives us a lot more flexibility with the hose, and I heartily recommend it!NOTE: I received a sample in exchange for a fair and honest review.

These sound great. I plan to use these with my iPad. They paired fine with it, and I'm impressed with the quality.I had wanted to use them with my PC, but, though I was able to pair them with my bluetooth, I was not successful in getting them to become my default sound source.I'm also not happy with the instructions. The print is so small to be virtually unreadable. How about in the future simply providing instructions through an online link? That way I will always have the instructions at the ready--and I'll be able to read them.NOTE: I received a product sample in exchange for a fair and honest review.

I have to be honest. I did not expect this product to do much for me. I do use anti-aging creams on my eyes and have been pleased with the results of some, but I've never used anything quite like this.I looked at the instructions and didn't like the idea that I'd look like a football player for about eight hours. Frankly, the mask looked gimmicky, but I gave it a try.I showered and applied the masks, not really liking the look at all. My face is small, and the masks covered a wider area of my face than in the illustration. Still, I left it on for about seven hours or so.During the time it was on, the mask was slightly uncomfortable but not horrible by any means. When I removed the masks, not expecting to see much change, I was astonished at how much better my eyes looked.This stuff works. It is expensive, but I suspect it's similar to what you'd get at a spa, so relatively speaking, it's not too expensive, about ten bucks a treatment.NOTE: I received a sample in exchange for a fair and honest review.

We have pets, and we have some carpet.While I really like the clean scent of this product, I don't think it cleans pet stains any better than our other carpet cleaners. Still, if nothing else, the scent gives the illusion that the carpet is clean. Sometimes that's the most you can hope for.

I am trying to replace old technology with new. I have lots of 20th century extension cords that I'd like to update with safer, better ones.This one is great because it does have safety features--and also offers surge protection. It also offers right angle plugs...few things are more frustrating than outlets that only go one way.I feel so much better with something like this than old-fashioned extension cords that make me nervous.

We haven't had a thermometer in the house for years, so when I was offered this product I jumped at it.The thermometer is very easy to use. The instructions are small print, but the information is clear and useful.I don't get sick very often, but it's nice to know that when I'm feeling under the weather I can easily check my body temperature. I've used other products from Vive, and they're reliable and effective.NOTE: I received a sample in exchange for a fair and honest review.

UPDATE (10/2/2015):I finally let the older dog try these. He doesn't have lots of teeth, and he turns down lots of food. Very, very picky Shih Tzu. After days of showing no interest in this product, he asked for it, got it, and handled it like a champ. Not only has he been able to eat them, he now loves them. I don't know for how long, but this one also has Henry's seal of approval--and he usually doesn't like anything.ORIGINAL REVIEW:I thought these would have the soft texture of jerky treats, but they're much harder, more like a biscuit. Because of this, they won't be appropriate for all dogs, especially older ones who might have dental issues.Still, this is one tasty treat that is easy to break apart (which I like) and easily eaten by most dogs. Davy, our JackChi LOOOOOVES these treats.The container is quite large, and the contents should remain fresh for a long time. I also like that it's grain-free and made in small batches.Davy and I are very happy with Perfect Canine Beefy Dog Treats and recommend them.NOTE: I received a sample in exchange for a fair and honest review.

My JackChi loved this. He took it into his room and immediately went to work on it. I did supervise, of course, to make sure he wasn't swallowing big pieces.Although he's a small dog, it took him less than ten minutes to devour it. I thought it might take the entire day because that's how long rawhide chips can take. So, for this dog at least, it is not "long lasting."

I usually buy dollar store freezer bags. They're fine, but these are superior.They're thicker and have a stronger locking mechanism. It's up to you on whether you want to pay at least twice the price, but if you need a freezer bag for something important, I recommend you use the name brand bags.

This is a product I didn't know about...and didn't realize how much I'd love.We use lots of essential oils in the household, and this device works great with those oils to make the house smell pleasant. It was easy to get it set up and working. It is quiet and unobtrusive.Normally, I can't stand wood-like things that don't look anything like wood but cheap plastic. However, this one is much more stylish than I expected. It matches a lot of genuine wood bowls, vases, etc. we have in the house.So far we've used wintergreen and peppermint and been quite pleased with how well this thing works. It'd be great in a bedroom, bathroom, kitchen, meditation space, etc.NOTE: I received a sample in exchange for a fair and honest review.

These are inexpensive earbuds that work great. They resemble Apple earbuds and work at least as well, if not better, than them.Considering they are less than ten dollars, this product is a great value--and an easy way to replace Apple earbuds. I'm very impressed.NOTE: I received a sample in exchange for a fair and honest review.

The scent is subtle and not overpowering. The bags are better-made than the cheaper brands I usually buy.One of the best things about this product is the compact size of the box. We have limited space, and this does not take up much room in the pantry.

This is perhaps most appropriate for someone young. It arrives nicely packaged in an attractive little cloth bag, so it'll make a great gift.The bracelet itself is dainty and quite lovely.NOTE:  I received a sample in exchange for a fair and honest review.

My wife has told me that I can not add any additional electronics to the entertainment center or PC setup. This is my workaround. And, frankly, it's inexpensive enough that I can buy one for every room of the house!It's not the most powerful surge protector in the world, but it does give me flexibility in the setups.I also HATE the packaging--the plastic is essentially stapled to the card. It doesn't have to be this way, Coleman.In addition, we live in a childless house and have no use for the sliding safety covers. I know it might be required, but it's annoying.Still, this solves a real problem I've been struggling with, and I'm happy that it's available.

There's lots to love about this product. The first thing you notice is that the packaging is first-rate. Lots of thought has been put into the box and how each washcloth is displayed.The second thing you'll notice is how soft these washcloths are. While they are designed for babies, these can be used as everyday household cloths. You can definitely give yourself the spa treatment with them because they're that special.I like that they're made of bamboo and have no dyes, chemicals or anything that might cause an allergic reaction.These would make a great gift, either to someone you adore--or to yourself.NOTE: I received a sample in exchange for a fair and honest review.

I have used several of the XEN-TAN products now, and I'm sold. I'm a pale-faced, middle-aged woman who burns more than tans but do like the look of tanned skin.I received a mitt with mine--and I strongly recommend that you purchase the mitt because it makes your life a whole lot easier. I also recommend that you get someone to help you if you want to be extra sure that you get all the areas covered--and evenly.It definitely produces the illusion of a tan, and I recommend it.

I'm always a little worried when I use a self-tanning product because it's so important to apply it correctly--and, even then, the results can vary.This is an easy-to-use product that worked well on my skin. I did receive a mitt, and that did help, but the product is designed to be easy to apply. I don't normally tan easily, but this made me look tan and healthy.

Sometimes we get real serious about pizza, and these are a couple of great tools when that mood strikes.These are similar tools that are used in pizza restaurants and have the durability of professional-grade instruments. The pizza cutter cuts the pizza effortlessly. (Be careful--the blade is SHARP). The peel does what it suggests--it allows you to remove a hot pizza (on an oven rack) with a shovel-like tool.These do take up lots of space (and don't fold), but they are specific tools that will definitely make our lives easier when we get in the pizza mood.NOTE: I received a sample in exchange for a fair and honest review.

This is a well-built lamp that has a strong light and is easy to operate.One of its best features is a USB port, so you can charge other electronic devices. This is a great thing to have, especially if you use this lamp on your computer desk.Still, the lamp seems overpriced for what you get. Also, I disagree with the company's description that the lamp is "stylish." It's really kind of ugly, frankly.

Both dogs willingly took these treats and devoured them. That's a good sign.These are bite-size cookies, but for small dogs you can further break the snack apart to make it even easier to eat.I like the ingredients (yogurt, apples, bananas, oatmeal, barley, brown rice, etc.) and believe this is a wholesome, healthy snack.I would like the package to come in a resealable bag because the freshness won't last long in the summer heat. I transferred the treats to two freezer bags, but it'd be nice if the manufacturer added this feature, especially at this price.

I wanted this to work better than it did.First, it was really difficult to open the package. It never endears me to a product when I have to spend too much time trying to get a product out of a package without injuring myself.Once I opened the package, I found the product to feel cheap and flimsy. Frankly, it also didn't work as well as I wanted. The angle is awkward for me, and it was not efficient in smoothing my nails.It was nice that the battery came with it, but I don't see myself using this much. I'll stick with nail scissors and emery boards.

We seem to go through lots of socks in this household.This is a 6-pack of socks that fits well and appears well-made. I like the color varieties.The socks only reach the ankle--not the calf--but I am able to wear them with shoes and boots with no problems.NOTE: I received a sample in exchange for a fair and honest review.

This is a comfortable sleep mask that is easy to adjust and wear. This is the first one I've used that is more molded to most people's faces, and it fits better.It does not come with a case or any extras, but the price is right, and the product works the way it should.NOTE: I received a sample in exchange for a fair and honest review.

This is a good value.I used less tp than usual, it lasted a long time, and was strong enough to suit my needs. It's also soft enough for me.I don't have lots of space in my linen closet and really appreciate that this tissue is compressed.

UPDATE: I also tried the ginger ale flavor and liked it very much. It is very zingy (strong carbonation), and the taste is sweet and refreshing. I like this flavor at least as much as I like the black cherry.ORIGINAL REVIEWI avoid soft drinks because I think they're unhealthy and can do long term damage to those who drink them for years. I don't drink lots of soda anymore, but I do occasionally get a craving for a can, especially my favorite, black cherry.This is a good alternative for me. This is a 0 calorie drink that uses stevia as its sweetener. It comes from a plant as opposed to a chemical lab. Since I've tried to eliminate most artificial sweeteners from my diet, I am happy that more companies, including Zevia, are using stevia.The first thing I noticed when I poured my pop was that the beverage is clear. It surprised me, but I quickly realized it meant that there were no artificial colors. That is a big plus. In fact, there's also no GMOs.All in all, I'm happy with this product. It's refreshing and tastes quite good.

Works great to control my frizzy hair.I'm picky about hair dryers and not every small dryer has worked for me. This is a mighty little dryer that is not very large. It's a little heavier than my previous dryer, but it feels solid and has really good power.The buttons make it versatile, and you can adjust the dryer to exactly what you need in terms of heat and speed. It also comes in dual voltage, so you can use it outside the US.This one's a winner. Again, very seriously reduced the frizz in my naturally curly hair. I am very, very pleased with this quality hair dryer.

This is a great commercial quality machine; it's exactly what you use at your local fitness club. It's the gold standard by which all other ellipticals are judged.The mechanical aspects of it are beyond reproach from every point of view. This is a work horse, designed to take any degree of punishment, engineered with great precision. Everything works flawlessly.I generally do a manual program work out, setting the resistance and varying the cross ramp to engage different sets of muscles.So what's not to like and why only four stars?Simply stated, this thing is not too bright. For a machine at this price point a much more sophisticated control is in order. Maybe this one can do some of the things I'd like it to, but if so it's certainly not evident, even after poring over the manual in detail. So it's either deficient or exceedingly user unfriendly.As noted, I enter a repetitive manual program for each workout. There should be a simple learn mode that allows the last workout entered to be retained. Similarly, it should be possible to enter parameters for a default user; I renter my weight and age each time. And what would really be nice would be if it would be possible to retain and export workouts to a PC based fitness program. Even inexpensive scales increasingly have bluetooth or wireless capability. Why not this over $ 6 grand behemoth?If the brains of this brute contained more intelligence it would be close to perfect.

For people who are reasonably fit it's a stretch to justify the purchase of this neat looking gizmo.My problem is not so much the price (it's a well built piece of equipment) or the challenge of assembling it (not as tough as some suggest). It's just that for me most of the stretches are either ineffective, or not as good as comparable ones accomplished on the floor.Here's my rundown:Stretch 1 - Lower Back: This is a good one that I do daily. It really works an area that needs to be flexible to prevent all manner of other problems. No argument with this one.Stretch 2 - Hamstrings: It's OK but not as good as alternatives on the floor.Stretch 3 - Gluteals and hips: This is a good one; no problems here.Stretch 4 - Hips legs and back: Like number 2 no real advantage over the floor version.Stretch 5 - Inner thighs and groin: Excellent!Stretch 6 - Upper Back: This one does nothing for me. I skip it.Stretch 7 - Shoulders: Like 6, virtually useless.Stretch 8 - Quads: Not too different from the stretch you would do without the machine. No apparent value added...So all in all it's a mixed bag, worthy of 3 stars only. But it does look interesting among the other equipment in the gym.

Adam Rubin and Daniel Salmieri, creators of Dragons Love Tacos, Those Darn Squirrels and various other kids lit high jinx have come up with another one to get the whole family chortling at story time.This time the protagonist is Raccoon, a perennially hungry (for pizza, that is) and clearly very clever varmint. As we learn on the opening page, "All he wants in life is a pizza".There is a  myriad of reasons for this, particularly following from "...the gooey cheesy-ness, salty pepperoni-ness, sweet, sweet tomato-ness, and crispy, crunchity crust" of Raccoon's favorite dish.Problem is, every time our furry hero tries to help himself, he's chased off by broom wielding adversaries.The action culminates with Raccoon crashing a secret pizza party, using his natural coloration to blend in with the other masquerading guests. But it's too good to be true, and out come the brooms one more time...As always, Salmieri's illustrations are outstanding and evocative. They're the perfect complement to the zany text.Enjoy!

This great book presents a prismatic and at times kaleidoscopic view of a very grand swath of almost everything. Well, not quite everything, but an amazing cross section of interesting and obscure material is fair game for author Caspar Henderson.In the introduction, he explains what he was up to as follows: "I have tried to look at a few ways of being from different angles and, through 'a wealth of unexpected juxtapositions,' explore how they are like and unlike humans (or how we imagine ourselves to be) and also how their differences from and similarities to us cast light on human capabilities and human concerns".That pretty much sums it up.The book is organized as a abecedarium, with 26 (actually 27) chapters, (there are two for X) each one nominally dealing with a creature whose name begins with that letter. I say nominally, because the subject of the chapter is nothing more than a gateway into a labyrinth of free association that at times will almost take your breath away.To provide a flavor of this, here's one sentence from each of the chapters (one X only this time)...1. Axolotl - Three or four thousand years ago in Mesopotamia people imagined that a being called Oannes, half-man and half-fish, rose from the sea to teach wisdom to mankind.2. Barrel Sponge - Even if we accept the idea of deep time as a reality, it is still hard to understand because its dimensions are so far outside our normal cognitive range.3. Crown of Thorns Starfish - The drug addict, drunk, wife-shooter and writer William Burroughs used to tell a story about a man who teaches his anus to talk.4. Dolphin - Spinner dolphins of both sexes sometimes engage in orgies of more than a dozen individuals, known as `wuzzles'.5. Eel - Moray eels have a second set of jaws deep at the back of their throat which shoot forward at high speed, grab the prey and rapidly protract backwards again, pulling the prey down into the oesophagus as the animal closes its mouth.6. Flatworm - Death has always been a looming presence, a lurking silent interlocutor behind a bewildering variety of masks, with whom we have an intermittent but unending dialogue in our heads.7. Gonodactylus - "The sun", wrote Galileo, "with all those planets revolving around it and depending upon it, can still ripen a bunch of grapes as if it had nothing else in the universe to do".8. Human - As the tale goes, Orpheus makes such beautiful music that the birds and beasts are enchanted, the trees and rocks dance, and even rivers change course in order to get closer to him.9. Iridogorgia Pourtalesii - The DNA in a few thousand people, joined in a single chain, would reach the nearest star.10. Japanese Macaque - Japanese macaques have long red faces and eyes that are close set like those of George W. Bush.11. Kiripha-Ko and Thikili-Ko - It would be nice to have animal company that is not under our thumb and has more charisma than the cockroach, the super-rat, and other "super species" which, some predict, will dominate a degraded future environment.12. Leatherback Turtle - In the karesansui, or Zen gardens, of Japan, rocks and vegetation are arranged in gravel or sand which is in turn scored with lines and patterns.13. Mystaceus - Each species of jumping spider taps out its own distinctive dances of intimidation and seduction - three or even seven-act shows that combine features of a semaphore, flamenco, and South African gumboot dancing.14. Nautilus - Alfred Tennyson anticipated Wells: The hills are shadows and they flow / From form to form and nothing stands; / They melt, like mist, the solid lands, / Like clouds they shape themselves and go.15. Octopus - Perhaps the most significant role for a cephalopod in Greek and Roman myth is as an inspiration for the Scylla, a monster that seizes sailors between three sharp rows of teeth mounted in each of six heads at the end of six long necks.16. Pufferfish - Prickliness, toxicity and ferocity have served the Pufferfish well in the exuberant but ruthless ecosystem of the coral reef.17. Quetzalcoatlus - At the time of writing, films of wingsuit `flight' available online include Grinding the Crack by Jeb Corliss and Sense of Flying by Espen Fadnes.18. Right Whale - The males compete not by fighting but by trying to out produce each other in the sheer quantity of sperm that they pass to females in frequent and promiscuous couplings from their prodigious testicles (each one of a mature male's pair can weigh half a tonne, or about 550 lb - the largest of any animal).19. Sea Butterfly - Sea butterflies are pteropods: sea snails that swim by flapping pad-like `feet' which have grown into wings.20. Thorny Devil - Moloch was a Canaanite god who in John Milton's account was smeared with the blood of human sacrifice.21. Unicorn: Goblin Shark - Like the Wuggly Ump, its other habits are obscure.22. Venus's Girdle - If squeezed they yield but then return to their original shape like gumbles, the fictional creatures in the neglected Australian children's classic, Bottersnikes and Gumbles.23. Waterbear - In a half joke, the cosmologist Stephen Hawking calls humans a `chemical scum', so tiny and insignificant are we in the vastness of space.24. Xenoglaux - One of the most striking European works of art may be Francisco Goya's etching in his Caprichos series, `The Dream of Reason Produces Monsters', in which a sleeping human figure (perhaps the artist himself)is mobbed by owls and bats with terrible eyes.25. Yeti Crab - `Panspermia' is not, as it may sound, the name of a distant planet in the 1974 soft porn shlockfest Flesh Gordon, but a perfectly serious scientific idea.26. Zebrafish - Voltaire admired the English but he barbed his praise: "Do not, while in their company," he wrote "express surprise that they have such pretty children".See what I mean?Unexpected juxtapositions, indeed.My highest recommendation...

So sings Dylan in a beautiful solo piano version of When I Paint My Masterpiece that closes out this collection.And so it is. The haunting, unadorned and authentic work that appears on Another Self Portrait certainly seems like a masterpiece as over and against what was actually released in 1970.Dylan's unfortunate later penchant for not releasing some of his best work (think Blind Willie McTell and Foot of Pride from Infidels) seems to have gotten underway at this time. In this sense, Greil Marcus inadvertently had it right in asking, "What is this ____t?" in the famous 1970 Rolling Stone review of the original Self Portrait. The release at that time of the honest, unadorned traditional songs that we now hear for the first time would have been a tour de force. Better late than never...Anyway, setting revisionism aside, let's look at this current and excellent release.Of the 35 tracks, the majority are from the Self Portrait sessions. These include versions of songs that were released, heard here without the often ill advised overdubbing, as well as a number of other songs in a similar spare style that should have been released, but were not. Apart from the Self Portrait material, there's some great stuff from the New Morning sessions later in 1970. In addition, there are several alternate versions of Nashville Skyline content, a couple of great live recordings from the Isle of Wight, and a smattering of other work from the 1967 - 1971 period.Here are a few of my favorite cuts:Went to See the Gypsy - The demo version with just Dylan and David Bromberg on guitar is faraway, haunting, and wistful. It sounds true to the lyric in a way that the urgent delivery of the released version misses almost entirely.Pretty Saro - While Bob is known for many things, I've always felt he was at his best singing love songs. This one is astonishing; a mellifluous and lyric expression of lovesick longing. Anyone who says that Dylan can't sing should listen to this. His voice here manages to express something that is almost inexpressible.These Hands - Johnny Cash covered this great Eddie Noack number; why didn't Bob's beautiful version make it onto Self Portrait?Working on a Guru - A hard driving 12 bar blues with - in a sublime irony - George Harrison delivering guitar riffs sounding more like Mike Bloomfield than the Maharishi following former Beatle. Dylan calls out, "Play it one time", and then, obviously having a whale of a good time, "Play it again". Harrison laughs a lays down an additional series of hot licks.Copper Kettle - Stripped of the syrupy orchestral and choral overdubs this song is a revelation. There's a raw power here, almost completely absent in the original. As Dylan sings "Don't use no green or rotten wood. It'll get you by the smoke" he emits a guttural growl that'll make your hair stand on end.I know I'm going to be listening to Another Self Portrait a lot. It's that good...

This is indeed a pocket guide. What this means is that it fits in your pocket. Really.It's tiny - 3 x 5 " of plastic laminated spiral bound information. Section tabs allow you to quickly get the info you need to bag that bass.I've been striking out in my pursuit of largemouth bass all summer long. So I bought a bunch of books trying to nail the theory in the hopes that this would improve the practice. This one, tiny as it is, is one of the most useful.I really do refer to it while on the water, and my success rate has picked up accordingly. Just don't expect a weighty tome...

Prior to installing these DU-BRO's there was a jumble of fly rods in the corner. The lines of one got tangled with the others. It was a mess.Now everything is lined up neatly; the entire quiver is arrayed and ready for action. Albies busting - grab that nine weight rigged with the intermediate line and go. Bluefish biting - there's a rod set up with shock tippet on the wall, ready for immediate action.What could be improved?The glossy finish looks cheap. It would be nice if there were a matte option and more color choices than basic black and white.And mounting screws should be supplied. I happened to have some that worked. Had this not been the case it would have been big time aggravation.Otherwise a very good product, definitely recommended.

Riedel is a fine company with a long tradition that generally makes excellent glassware.Even though I've rated these with 3 stars only, there's nothing really wrong with them. They're well proportioned for savoring big wines, and are durable enough for careful dishwashing. Quality of the lead free glass is also excellent.So what's not to like?I personally don't care for certain design details that follow from the modern production methods that have been used.The traditional method of making a wine glass results in an organic look, in which the bowl, stem, and base flow together as a single entity. In this process, the three elements come together while all are still hot out of the furnace, and are shaped through the skills of an experienced glass blower.In contrast, these Riedel glasses are produced in an automated assembly process. Each glass has five components; one blown (the bowl), one extruded (the stem), and three molded (the base and joiners). Riedel's choice of a fluted (ribbed) stem and little ziggurat shaped joiners draws attention to this composite nature, and makes for an overly fussy appearance.These are my opinions - some may disagree. But, as the Romans would have put it, "De gustibus non est disputandum".

That's the objective of wearing one of these.I do a lot of solo fishing, often in waters with a pretty heavy swell. On a few occasions, while casting to a bunch of busting albies, I've almost landed in the drink. If this were to happen and I hit my head on the way down, the result could be disaster.But the idea of wearing a bulky PFD just doesn't cut it.The solution: this hydrostatic self inflating unit. It's expensive, but worth it for sure.Other auto inflate PFD's use a salt sensing trigger system. These cost less, but in tough marine conditions, are prone to false alarms. Morphing into the michelin man while fighting a nice fish would not be a good thing, and the aggravation of repacking the vest is something you'll want to avoid.This unit is very comfortable and easily adjustable. I wear it all the time...

This book is an absolute masterpiece.Award winning author and illustrator Simms Tabak retells thirteen tales from Eastern Europe, originally told him by his grandfather. The venerable Zayda is pictured on the frontispiece where we learn, "He brought these stories to America from his little village in Poland".The book begins with a series of Yiddish aphorisms, to whet your appetite and get you into the mood. Examples:* A wise man knows what he says and a fool says what he knows.* A shlimazel believes only in mazel.* From the lowly potato you get the choicest latke.The book ends with a glossary to help make sense of the aphorisms and to understand all that lies between. Some important Yiddish terms that are explained:* Chutzpah - nerve;* Meshugge - crazy;* Zhlub - oaf.The stories themselves are masterfully told, and illustrated with a vivid richness that only Simms can conjure up. Several made me roar with laughter. It's hard to describe how evocative of Yiddish idiosyncrasies all this is; suffice it to say that the agony and the ecstasy of life in the shtetl comes through loud and clear.Even when your kids get tired of it, this is a book you'll want to keep for yourself for reading over and over again.

This is my go to rod for a lot of fishing situations.Lake Champlain bass and land locked salmon, Pulaski steelhead, hefty pond dwelling browns and rainbows, northern pike, schoolie stripers and smaller bluefish, this rod handles 'em all.One of these and a four or five weight will cover pretty much the full range of eastern fly fishing opportunities.The Orvis tip flex taper provides fast action and works great lofting big bass bugs, or casting into a stiff New England breeze. Build quality is second to none as befits a rod of this price category. And the warranty is unbeatable. Send the broken pieces back, no questions asked, and a replacement or perfect repair reappears in days.Highly recommended.

I'm glad I didn't have to read this book to my kids. It falls into the category that would get old very quickly.Hildy is a sow. Moose is, you guessed it, a moose. They are the best of friends. Winston (not Winton, more on this later) is Hildy's cousin. He is a boar. As it turns out, as he notes in one of his attempts at humor, he his also a bore, a socially inept know it all from the city. The storyline involves the city slicker's visit to his cousin in the country. It doesn't take long for him to alienate Moose as well as all the other good old folks with his pompous and overbearing demeanor. In the end, however, Moose helps Winston to come down to earth, reconciliation follows, and all is well.The trouble is, none of this is very interesting or engaging. Black and white illustrations which would be fine in a vintage book don't add much zest to a bland and plodding text. Here's an example of the action:"'Knock, knock,' Moose shouted. 'Anybody home?'The vacuum cleaner stopped. 'I'm in here' Hildy called.Moose walked through the front hall to the living room.'Careful,' said Hildy. 'I just waxed the floor.'"Who cares! Vacuum cleaners and waxing the floor - are kids going to relate to this stuff? I think not...The whole thing seems like a lukewarm effort at best. This extends to the editing as well. Hence on page 50 we read, "Moose parked the car. Winton took his suitcase out of the trunk".Winston is one of the three main characters of this book. I would estimate the book has about 2000 words. You'd think if it was subject to any kind of pre publication review at all a typo like this one would have been caught.Is it a big deal? No.Is is a good book? Also, no. But in light ot the edifying and worthy themes of inclusiveness and redemption I'll give it three stars.

This is a clever device. It weighs you, feeds back your % body fat, takes your pulse, and displays the level of CO2 in the vicinity as a proxy for air quality. Then it sends all of this information to an app on your phone or tablet, where you can track your progress (and that of family members or others) and display the data in a variety of formats.After a couple of days, though, I sent it back.The biggest problem for me was slight inconsistency in back to back readings; a scale that sells for $ 150 should be totally accurate each and every time.If you're doing an elimination type eating plan, deviations of plus or minus tenths are important, and if you can't be certain from one weigh in to the next, it defeats the purpose.Beyond this, I really didn't know what to do about with the CO2 data. We live in the country, and the air anywhere doesn't get much better. Or so I thought, until the Withings began to suggest otherwise.Like Bob Dylan said, "You don't need a weatherman to know which way the wind blows".

I bought this light for tying flies. This is intricate work, requiring bright light as well as magnification. The magnification works well. The light - that's another story.I know that LED technology is improving in leaps and bounds. But for me it needs a bit more leaping and bounding to reach the user friendly utility of plain old incandescent.This lamp emits a pale and bluish light at best. It's nowhere near bright enough to illuminate the detail of a # 20 Griffith's Gnat.Otherwise this is a nicely designed product and certainly energy efficient as well. But if I can't really see my work it's not much good for me.

In The Little Prince, the six year old Antoine de Saint-Exupery draws a picture of an elephant inside a boa constrictor. He shows it to the grown-ups, expecting them to be terrified, to find that they can only see what looks to them like a hat.Something similar is afoot in Snow, by Caldecott Award winning author Uri Shulevitz. A little boy (identified only as "boy with dog") sees endless potential as the first flake of snow is sighted over an otherwise grey city. Filled with hope, he runs through the streets of the town crying out,"It's snowing".Here are some of the responses of the adults he encounters on his way:"'It's only a snowflake,' said grandfather with beard"."'It's nothing,' said man with hat"."'It'll melt,' said woman with umbrella".They are backed up by the media:"'No snow,' said radio"."'No snow,' said television".But as is importantly noted, "...snowflakes don't listen to radio, snowflakes don't watch television". And soon the whole city is blanketed in a thick cover of snow as boy with dog frolics about...Shulevitz' great genius, as always, is in his illustrations. They perfectly capture the overbrimming exuberance of boy with dog, and contrast this with the snooty and aloof demeanor of the grown-ups. And the transformation of the town that follows is deeply evocative.It's for good reason that Snow was selected as a Caldecott Honor Book by the 1998 ALSC selection committee.Highly recommended.

"Notwithstanding his inveterate obstinacy, the ass is an excellent and sober little beast, far too much despised by us". This observation of Francis Galton of the Royal Geographic Society is quoted early in The Lost City of Z, as part of the description of Percy Fawcett's perpetration and training for Amazonian exploration. The characterization of "inveterate obstinacy" might better have been applied to Fawcett himself...The Lost City of Z is the story of Fawcett's obsessive quest to validate his theory of the existence of a fabled civilization deep in the deadly uncharted South American rain forest. His unexplained disappearance and the fate of his final expedition created a parallel mystery that is investigated by noted journalist and author David Grann. While the ingredients of the tale should make for an absolute spellbinder, I found it to be interesting, but not more.For me it was the psychological observations relative to the protagonist that were more engaging than the adventure itself. These kept me going when the action itself dragged from time to time. Also interesting was the metamorphosis in the writing of the book of Gramm himself, from city slicker to jungle adventurer. This adds another level of psychological complexity as he himself becomes obsessed with Z. He writes, "I pulled the map form my back pocket. It was wet and crumpled, the lines I had traced to highlight my route now faded. I stared at my markings, hoping that they might lead me out of the Amazon, rather than deeper into it. The letter Z was still visible in the center of the map. Yet it seemed less like a signpost than a taunt, another testament to my folly".

A touch of hyperbole when describing the angling possibilities in the Empire State?Perhaps, but after reading this book you'll see there's some basis to this description from the introduction. The described salt and fresh water fisheries are diverse and surprisingly extensive. Time to stop thinking Big Apple only when New York is mentioned, though angling opportunities exist even in and around the city...Anyway, Gone Fishin' provides an introductory survey of what you can target, where and when. It's a starting point, and that's a very helpful thing when a visitor is confronted with so many choices.Does it really divulge the 100 best spots as suggested in the byline?Of course not - the best spots are off the beaten path and surely undisclosed. You'll have to pay your dues and befriend the old timers if you want to have a chance to sniff out where they are.Good luck!

Hmmm...What's the difference, anyway?Birders are more intense, serious, and scientific than bird watchers. A bird watcher just might be gazing at that red breasted nuthatch at the backyard feeder rather than crawling through a thicket in search of an elusive prothonotary warbler as the birder surely will.For watching, bigger, more life like illustrations and extensive descriptions are in order. Bird watchers will even enjoy various coffee table books about their feathered friends.Birders, however are all business.Grab the binoculars, put on a pith helmet, tuck that Peterson Field Guide under your arm, and off you go.If you want to distinguish between a bobolink and an eastern meadowlark with complete confidence every time, the Peterson System can't be beat. It's based on patternistic drawings with arrows to pinpoint the important distinguishing field marks of each species. In a sense what this provides is a pictorial key of readily noticed visual impressions so that the correct ID can be forthcoming in a flash. Since the publication of the original Field Guide in 1934 this approach has not been improved upon.The text is efficient and economical so as to convey a maximum of information in a minimum of space. So, for example, this is how we learn to recognize the call of the red-headed woodpecker, "Voice: A loud queer or queah, louder and higher pitched than the churr of red-bellied woodpecker".Of course, this presupposes that you're already familiar with the churr that the red-bellied woodpecker makes.No problem. After all, you're a birder.Enjoy!

In his introduction to this very good book Pope Francis writes, " Dialogue is born from a respectful attitude toward the other person, from a conviction that the other person has something good to say. It supposes that we can make room in our heart for their point of view, their opinion, and their proposals. Dialogue entails a warm reception and not a preemptive condemnation.To dialogue one must know how to lower the defenses, to open the doors of one's home, and to offer warmth".This book is the record of a dialogue between the former Archbishop of Buenos Aires and Abraham Skorka, a leading Argentine rabbi. Their conversations touch on a wide range of topics - God, prayer, death, science, the elderly, poverty, the Holocaust, globalization, and more. These are two very learned men, and the depth of their thinking on so many areas of life is remarkable.But what impressed me most was the love and respect for one another that shines through as they talk together and reason with one another.I came away with a soaring sense of human possibilities.

These replacement lenses pop in and out of Native Eyewear Hardtop Frames.The polarized blue reflex lenses are rated at 10% VLT (Visual Light Transmittance) and accordingly are suitable for extremely bright sunlight conditions. I use them for open ocean and big lake fishing.I've also got a set of polarized copper reflex and Sportflex lenses. The polarized copper are great in moderate light conditions and are fabulous for reading water on typical trout streams. They're rated at 18% VLT.For dawn, dusk, or overcast conditions the Sportflex lenses, rated at 60 % VLT are just what's needed.All Native Eyewear replacement lenses come in a handy cleaning pouch.Taken together they make for a versatile vision enhancing system for a wide variety of conditions.Highly recommended.

Good polarized sunglasses are among the most important gear for the fly fisher person. You want to be able to see beneath the surface to spot that nook or cranny that could conceal a trout. And if you succeed in enticing one out of its lair, seeing the fish chase the fly increases the fun factor, as well as your chance of hooking up.Anyway, I was recently out with legendary Adirondack guide Rich Garfield and had missed several takes in a row. We couldn't figure it out until Rich asked to see my shades, which I had paid a lot of money for. He handed me his Native Hardtops with copper (rose) colored lenses. The difference was astonishing - there were significant orders of magnitude of increased subsurface visibility.I immediately scored a pair.They're impressively light weight, comfortable, and look great. They come in a bomb proof case with a protective cleaning bag. Interchangeable lenses are another great feature. There's an available selection for any conditions you might encounter. They come with an additional set of Sportflex lenses for contrast in low light conditions - an unexpected bonus.Watch out trout. I can see you now...

Tilly and Friends is generally a pretty good series, and Polly Dunbar's illustrations are endearing and fun. But this book is a few notches below the rest.Pru is a hen. She looks a bit like Mae West. As the story gets underway, she's preening about in front of a mirror. "Oh pretty," said Pru. "I'm so pretty!"What's going on with this narcissistic outburst? As we learn, "She was putting on her favorite red lipstick".Next, Trumpty the elephant enters the scene. He asks, "Can I have some makeup?... Then I can be pretty like you".What's this saying? Makeup is necessary to be pretty? And do little kids of the age that a story like this is directed to relate to makeup? Do we want them to?It turns out that Pru is not only vain, but she's also selfish. But in the end, she makes a generous gesture, giving her favorite red lipstick to Trumpty.But I can't help it. This happy ending doesn't redeem things for me. The whole story just feels a bit too smarmy.

This is a scholarly rather than a popular work and therefore it's somewhat dry and plodding for the average reader.Modern archeology has nothing in common with the swashbuckling imagery of mysterious and exciting artifacts in faraway places a la Indiana Jones. It's more about meticulous documentation of tiny contextual details of a site, analysis of soil anomalies and the like.As this is a thoroughly modern book about excavations in the vicinity of Stonehenge, the reader is treated to all manner of archeological minutiae. For instance we learn how the activity of earthworms impacts the location of rocks in a site, "When we look at a soil profile that has not been disturbed by plowing for many centuries, we can see the effects of worm-sorting because the stones and pebbles lie at the bottom, beneath a layer of fine earth".Nevertheless, there are some colorful snippets. As an example, here's how the author introduces his colleague John Evans: "I'd know John Evans in his later years, when he was a professor of environmental archeology. He became the leading specialist in land mollusks - "snail Evans" to distinguish him from lots of other archeological Evanses - and was one of those people who's interested in everything. He'd had some difficult years when alcohol almost got the better of him, yet his mind was razor sharp and you never knew what he was going to say next".OK, maybe a touch of Indiana here.But in the balance, I found the 350 pages of this book tough going. For the average reader there's just too much arcane musing about the characteristics of various post holes and similar matters.If you're a scientist - enjoy. Otherwise, you may want to avoid.

Or pike, bass, sunfish or whatever. And do it with a fly rod just like Brad Pitt in A River Runs Through It.Well, sort of...This time of year (July) fly fishers for trout start to get glum. The water warms up and the trout get truculent. Feeding slows down or stops altogether. Even if it doesn't, you risk being admonished by the Trout Unlimited types for inflicting additional stress on stream dwelling salmonids.Not to worry! As described by Jeff Currier in this very good book, there are virtually unlimited other targets that thrive under these conditions. You just have to think outside of the conventional fly fishing box.Currier makes the case convincingly in the opening chapter titled, "Why Warmwater Fly Fishing?". He then goes on to detail the various types of water you'll encounter, as well as equipment, flies, knots and technique. Next is a section that reveals tactics for success with a wide variety of warm water species. Currier closes out the book with a look into his fly box, so you'll be ready with all the necessary patterns.Go get 'em!

Buyer beware!If you misplace that valuable proof of purchase, this lamp just might be worthless.Here's what happened to me...When assembling this made in China product, you have to attach the lamp stem to the base by way of a bolt that screws into a threaded casting in the stem. The base is heavy (though from reading other reviews not quite heavy enough to prevent the lamp from tipping over). But it weighs enough to make it difficult to keep absolutely square and level while screwing in the bolt. The bolt is steel. The part that receives it is a cheap zinc casting - much softer than the bolt. As a result, if the heavy base is even at a slight angle during assembly, you can cross thread the casting. That's what I inadvertently did...Let me say that I'm not a home improvement klutz. In fact, I have a lot of knowledge about lamps and their construction, having owned and operated a leading US based manufacturer of lighting fixtures for over 30 years. Even so, the cross threading mishap occurred.Anyway, while inconvenient, I figured it would be no big problem. I unscrewed the damaged casting from the stem and contacted OttLite customer service for a replacement. I was not asking to return the lamp, simply to replace a damaged part that I would estimate is worth not more than 25 cents. I offered to pay for the part and for shipping and handling as well.What followed was a Kafkaesque exchange of not less than 18 e-mails with the bureaucrats in the OttLite customer service (disservice?) department. The last one summed it up aptly: "I apologize, but there is nothing we can do without the requested information". The referenced requested information is that damn proof of purchase.Again, keep in mind that I wasn't asking for a replacement or anything at no charge. I just wanted to buy a small part so as to be able to use the lamp.No dice.So here's the end of the matter. Tomorrow is garbage day, and my brand new OttLite is going into the trash. It's a total write off due to a mindless customer service bureaucracy handling a poorly designed product.Better put that proof of purchase in a safety deposit box, just in case...

How come?I've owned two pairs of Patagonia Riverwalker wading boots, the model that has been replaced by this one. They fit well, gripped well, provided good support and were very light.Problem is, both self destructed after less than a year of use. It seems that the light weight came at the cost of minimal durability.The good news is that Patagonia credited both even after a year of use since they could not be repaired.I've replaced the second pair with these and have been using them for a couple of weeks now.I don't like the fit as much; they are a bit too wide for my foot and need to be cinched very tightly to provide a secure feeling. Otherwise, they look good, and as the name suggests are super light.How will they hold up to repeated clambering through the freestone streams of the northern Adirondacks?The jury is out...

In a 1980's presidential primary debate Walter Mondale famously quoted a Wendy's ad of the time, asking Gary Hart, "Where's the beef?"This book attempts to answer a similar question as it relates to trout and other fly rod quarry in New York State.As is the case with other similar guides its a useful starting point, but not much more.You'll definitely get a general feel for the lay of the land in the region you're checking out. But to really home in on where the action is, you'll still want to  infiltrate locations where grizzled geezers gather to try to learn what's biting where and on what.The book is organized into South, Central, North and West regions. Within each, major watersheds are described. There's also information as to hub cities for various rivers complete with coordinates of fly shops, places to stay, and more. In addition major rivers have useful hatch calendars and stream characteristic bullet points to further flesh out the picture. While there are maps, these would be more useful with a bit more detail.It's definitely a book that every NY angler should have for reference; just don't expect it to point you to the very best locations, which remain undisclosed...

Is truly brilliant. And she's the one who recommended this stuff.In the past I've slathered on all manner of various and sundry slime, and none of it really made a difference.This stuff is another story - you can almost see your skin take on a flush of health and a sheen of youth within a few days of beginning to use it. No skin affliction has a chance.Highly recommended.

Yvon Chouinard (founder of Patagonia) is a genius.The threat of infestations of invasive species such as didymo (colloquially known as rock snot) has put the kibosh to the use of felt soled wading boots in many locations around the country. Vermont, where I sometimes fish, is latest on the list.The problem is that until now, every alternative to felt, (studs, "sticky" soles, etc.) has resulted in dangerous falls on slippery rocks in the river. I've tried a bunch of them, and nothing worked. Inevitably, no matter how careful I was, I'd find myself on my keister, waders filling with water while being swept downstream.In recent years, Patagonia, like every other supplier of wading boots, has sold its share of such ineffective footwear. Enter Chouinard, former mountaineer and outdoor gear perfectionist. Not willing to make the trade off between environmental responsibility and personal safety he experimented with approaches derived from the design of rock climbing crampons. These Rock Grip fixed aluminum bar boots are the result.Trust me - they work. They bite into virtually any rock surface except those coated with thick slimy algae on which even felt is not too effective. I've clambered over wet rocks, dry ones, in all kinds of currents and have yet to do an unintended swan dive into the river. These boots are also comfortable and definitely bomb proof in their construction.The only downside is that they're noisy. Unless you're exceedingly careful, the metal bars make a clip clopping sound on the rocks, not a good thing when sneaking up on that skittish brown trout. On the other hand, splashing into the drink has been known to spook them as well...

Feeling's Flame LED electric candles are designed to replicate the warm ambience of real candle light.Do they succeed in this?Hmmm...PRO: They wiggle!They are rated for 20K hours of wiggling!!CON: They're expensive.They don't produce much light.They look foolish.My opinion - regular incandescent E-12 base candelabra lamps make more sense...

This is the story of Gino Bartali, winner of the Tour de France in 1938 as well as 1948. No other rider in history has won the Tour twice ten years apart.But it is much more than that. It is the story of Italy before, during and after the Second World War as it swung from fascism towards communism and ultimately settled on the multi party democratic republic that still is in place today. In it we learn about how Bartali's athletic feats inspired the nation in some of its darkest hours.And there is yet another story, this one about courageous Italians, some of who were later honored as Righteous Among the Nations for their selfless protection of Jews during the War. Excellent research by the authors illuminates the important role that Bartali played in this dangerous effort. He himself was quiet about his involvement with the resistance; during the War as a result of obvious concern for the safety of both him and others, but after it as a result of his unique and modest character.Unfortunately, the writing style of the book doesn't do justice to its content. The following description of Bartali's wedding illustrates the problem: "Adriana wore a modest long sleeved white dress and floor length veil, which covered soft chestnut waves of hair, draped over her shoulders. Gino donned a dark suit and tie, and the triangle of a smart white handkerchief peeked out of his breast pocket".In spite of this somewhat sophomoric style, the book is well worth reading. On the basis of its substance it merits a solid four stars.

Crazy Horse, that is.Here he is talking about drummer Ralph Molina in his autobiography, Waging Heavy Peace, "...Ralphie is extremely subtle and can express emotions beautifully in both a ballad and a laid-back song. He is completely unique, emotional, and driving at the same time. His flourishes with my feedback at the end of a song are always right with me, as if he knows right where I am going. Fact is, we are going there together, feeling our way, and that really applies to all of Crazy Horse. That is what makes the Horse as great as it is, and as cosmic as it is. That is the Force of the Horse. Making the new albums, Americana and Psychedelic Pill, I have found that this cosmic force has increased, not diminished, with time".This love and respect comes through loud and clear throughout Psychedelic Pill. It's clear that these guys just can't get enough of playing together. As the packaging label notes, the result is "...over 85 minutes of music". One full hour of this is comprised of just three songs: Ramada Inn, Walk Like a Giant, and Driftin' Back, a lilting 27 minute improvisation. Can there be too much of a good thing?At first I thought maybe so, but as I listened again I thought really no.We also learn in Waging Heavy Peace that Neil is into long road trips in big 50's Lincolns and Cadillacs, and that's kind of what these songs are like. The beat just keeps beating, and it takes you away, far away.
