Sometimes the proverbs lack the clarity and wit of the fables, and seem a bit obscure, so it is a bonus and pleasure to have the fables included. Both proverbs and fables are a nice reminder that human nature, despite differences in culture and the passage of more than 2,000 years, is a comforting (or is that disappointing?) constant. So even though "It's" Greek and Latin, it mostly makes perfect sense to me!

If you are a "Seinfeld" fan you know what I mean by the title. Elaine's boss, Mr. Pitt, was extremely fussy about his socks. I'm like that, too, and I think these socks are great. Not too thick and not too thin. Enough elastic so that they stay up properly, and they have enough "give" so that you don't have to be Houdini to get them on. The material is wonderful and the socks feel great on your feet. Very cozy! No complaints whatsoever!

We've been buying flannel sheets for years, so we have lots of experience with them. We were not happy with these. They were a bit on the rough side and they had a slightly unpleasant odor. While I was making the bed I could feel my eyes getting irritated, so I suspect people with allergies might have a difficult time with this item. We are not going to use these and wound up ordering a more expensive set yesterday from a different manufacturer.

I was very impressed with this pan. I have used so-called non-stick pans in the past and have always found them a bit wanting. This pan, however, did live up to all the positive reviews that were already posted on Amazon. I read the pre-use instructions and washed the pan in soap and water and then I rubbed on a little olive oil for "seasoning." I then made an omelette over medium heat, as the instructions state that the pan is an excellent conductor of heat and they suggest not using high heat. About halfway thru the cooking process I added a slice of cheese to the mix. The omelette was done perfectly and in a short period of time. It slid out of the pan and onto the plate with absolutely no sticking. Even the little bit of cheese that had dripped into the pan didn't stick. (By the way, other than seasoning the pan I added absolutely no other oil or butter to the pan.) The pan has a nice, long handle that is comfortable and doesn't get hot. In conclusion, the pan heats quickly and evenly, it is truly non-stick, and cleans up like a dream. Highly recommended.

I was a little disappointed in this book. To be honest, it was not very well-written. Many sentences were awkwardly worded and sometimes too prolix. The extensive use of military acronyms and the explanations of what they meant frequently interrupted the flow of the book. The authors had fairly run-of-the-mill jobs while stationed in Germany and Vietnam, so the descriptions of what they did in the various duty stations were not all that interesting. Actually, while you might expect that the sections on West Berlin during the Cold War and Vietnam during the Vietnam War would be the most interesting, the section on jungle training in Panama was the most informative. However, that was a very brief section. I was hoping for some biographical information about the authors which might help the reader get into their heads, but this was lacking as well. Mr. Geschke tells a tiny bit about his post-military life at the end of the book, but we learn nothing at all about Mr. Toto. And, in what was a really puzzling section, Mr. Toto intimates that he could have talked about many other things but chose not to because the topics were too painful. I am giving the book a tentative thumbs-up because, having never served in the military, I did learn a bit about the training the men had to go through, and a lot of this information was presented in an entertaining and self-deprecating manner.

Maria Sutton has written a fascinating, moving memoir of her virtually lifelong search to find out not only what happened to her father, but also to learn what kind of man he was. Along the way she also manages to locate the brother her mother hasn't seen for over 40 years. (She enlists the help of a former KGB agent to accomplish this!) Finally, she is also able to discover the identity of her mother's father. The amount of research and detective work that Maria does is incredible. Some people might look at it as obsessive, but I found it admirable. As she states near the end of the book, each of us must decide what gives life meaning. In her case, she needed to find out about the man who was responsible for her being born. And she needed to reconnect with her European roots. The book is bittersweet, as Maria finds out some extremely unpleasant things about her father which shatter her idealized vision of him. But the self-knowledge she gains and the "new" family she discovers compensate for her disappointment. The book is wonderfully written and I found it difficult to believe that this is the author's first work. I am not easily moved, but at several points this book brought me to tears. Impressive and highly recommended.

I was very disappointed in this soap. Having tried and liked "Suave" coconut bodywash and "Organix" coconut milk shampoo (both products having a wonderful coconut smell), I was amazed that this new bar soap by "Softsoap" has absolutely no coconut smell. Zero! Why they put coconut in the title, I have no idea. Actually, whatever scent this soap has is a bit unpleasant. It has got a vague, chemical smell to it. So, if you are a fellow coconut lover I would advise you to stay away from this and look elsewhere.

This is an excellent book concerning the relationship of Theodore Roosevelt and the Maine hunting and fishing guide Bill Sewall. Roosevelt first met Sewall when Roosevelt was still a student at Harvard in the late 1870's. We tend to remember Teddy as the stout and robust fellow he became in later years, but as a college student he was still thin and weedy. Miles and miles of hiking thru the Maine woods built him up, and the older (by 13 years) Sewall both tested and inspired the younger Roosevelt. The 2 men saw eye to eye on politics, morality and most other things, and you can see the seeds of Roosevelt the conservationist being sewn through his relationship with Sewall. The book details their hunting and fishing expeditions in Maine, Sewall's work for Roosevelt out in the Dakota Badlands when Roosevelt tried to make a go out of raising cattle, and the correspondence and occasional contact they had thereafter, right up until Roosevelt's death in early 1919. The author has a snappy, funny, breezy style. Sewall was also a pretty witty fellow, kind of a cross between Will Rogers and Andy of Mayberry.....so it is a pleasure to read his take on things. It is also interesting to read of Sewall's family history and of what life was like in rural Maine in the late 1800's. My only complaints are minor: The book could have used a few maps....of central and northern Maine, and of the Dakota Badlands in particular. It was also a bit odd that the book doesn't give any biographical information concerning the author. (You can, however, look at his Amazon Author's Page.) As mentioned, though, these are minor quibbles. All in all, an interesting and well-researched and beautifully written account of a relatively little known but important friendship.

This was a fairly interesting account of John Kendrick's exploration of the Pacific Northwest, and his attempts to open up that area, as well as the Hawaiian Islands to American trade. I had never heard of Kendrick so that alone was enough of a reason for me to read this book. The book goes into great detail about Kendrick's interactions with the Indians of the Pacific Northwest, the British, the Spanish, the Hawaiian Islanders, and the traders and bureaucrats of Macao. The story is a bit disjointed as it keeps hopping from place to place, and just when you are getting interested in one aspect of the story the author moves on to another area.My main problem with the book is that none of the main characters come alive. At the end of the book you still don't feel that you know anything about John Kendrick as a person.....his internal life, his likes and dislikes, etc. Likewise, the Spanish and British explorers and merchants do not emerge as flesh-and-blood people. The author's style is rather straightforward, rather than exceptional. The book comes across more as reportage than narrative.So, I wind up giving this book a lukewarm thumbs-up. It is worth reading pretty much only because it tells the tale of a little known but important historical figure.

This is a beautifully written book. Rebecca Johns has oodles of talent and the countess of the title is a fully-rounded and fascinating character. You are immediately transported into the late 16th and early 17th centuries.....the language, the sights and sounds and smells, the people....everything rings true. The author doesn't strike a false note and the world she evokes is wonderfully real. Ms. Johns also succeeds in humanizing a woman who has been demonized. Not only can you understand her actions, from her point of view, but at times you can sympathize with her for having to make her way as a woman in a world mostly run by men. But Ms. Johns also lets us see Countess Bathory's faults.....her sadistic streak, her temper and her self-delusion. This character is so real that she truly does emerge, living and breathing, from the pages of the book.My only complaint is the rather bizarre choice to put in a prologue that tells you right away what is going to happen, so that there is no suspense. If the author were a lesser writer, this decision might make you lose interest or at least reduce your enjoyment of the novel. Be that as it may, even though I knew what was going to happen to the countess I was still caught in the web that Ms. Johns has woven. A remarkable book.

I thought this was an interesting theme for a book. If the author had chosen to just write about the "death pageant" for Lincoln's corpse I don't think this would have worked. It would have been too much of the same thing. As it was, at times I got a little bored reading about the arrangements made in each city for the display of Lincoln's body, how many people lined up to look at him, etc. To his credit, the author realized there was a limit to how much of this he could present to the reader so he widened the scope of the Lincoln portion of the book to include some historical snippets from Lincoln's lifetime. We see a distraught Lincoln, in 1862, mourning for his son Willie, lose his temper when an insensitive lout badgers Lincoln for a job, even though the White House is draped in black crepe and it is clear someone has just died. We also see Lincoln, positively boyish, "trying on" Jefferson Davis' desk for size at the "Confederate White House" in Richmond.However, to me, the section of the book dealing with Jefferson Davis' departure from Richmond just before the end of the war in April 1865 was the more interesting part of the book. Whatever you think of the Confederacy, the author does a nice job of presenting Davis as a honorable man, faithful to his cause and not out for personal gain. Davis did not leave Richmond to save his own skin. He hoped to get out west past the Mississippi to rally his forces and to keep the war going. Interestingly, John Wilkes Booth did the south an immense disservice when he assassinated Lincoln. Lincoln was willing to let Davis escape. He was not interested in jailing him or putting him on trial or executing him. Lincoln also would not have treated the southern states as harshly as Andrew Johnson did during Reconstruction. Without spoiling anything with too much detail, Davis' life after he was captured by Union forces was surrealistic and fascinating.Another plus for this book was that there were some great photos, many that I had never seen before. There is even a photo of the bullet that killed Lincoln, as it was saved after the autopsy. Gruesome, but you can't help wanting to look at this little piece of lead that caused such grief and changed history.

Laura Hillenbrand must have thanked her lucky stars when she found Louie Zamperini and made him the subject of this book. Zamperini, still alive and kicking (an apt description as he was a famous runner in his youth) at 94 (this month) hit the nail on the head when he told the author, "I'll be an easier subject than 'Seabiscuit', because I can talk." Well, he may have been easier in the sense that he could relate many, many stories concerning the incredible things that happened to him during his lifetime, but things couldn't have been all that easy as it took Ms. Hillenbrand seven years to research and write this book. For the reader, it was worth every day of those seven years.If you had the imagination of Steven Spielberg and Robert Zemeckis combined, you couldn't come up with a life nearly as interesting or action-packed as Mr. Zamperini's. A wayward, rebellious childhood was followed by an obsession with running. When I was a teenager in the early 1970's I was a pretty avid follower of track-and-field and knew something of the history of long-distance runners, but there was a gap in my education as I had never heard of Mr. Zamperini. But in 1930's California he was hot-stuff, and he held the high school record for the mile for around 20 years. He made the 1936 Olympic team and although he came in 7th place in his event he ran the fastest last lap ever. He got to pal around with Jesse Owens and had the (admittedly dubious) distinction of meeting Goebbels and Hitler. He expected big things at the 1940 Olympics but the games were cancelled due to WWII.So far, we already have had enough for a "normal" book but Mr. Zamperini's experiences as a bombardier in the Pacific theater raise "Unbroken" to a higher level. He was shot at and (almost) downed. Then he was in a plane that wasn't shot at but wasn't airworthy and it crashed. He was adrift at sea for a month-and-a-half in a 6 foot raft, with 2 companions. It is no exaggeration to say that Mr. Zamperini could have suffered death by starvation, death by thirst, or death by shark. Take your pick. (One companion did die.) After the 6-7 week ordeal, the 2 remaining men were picked up by a Japanese ship. Again, the ordeal by sea would have made a book by itself. But there's more.....The remainder of the book deals with Mr. Zamperini's experiences in various Japanese POW camps. The Japanese didn't believe in surrendering. They encouraged their own men to fight to the death or to commit suicide to avoid capture. Needless to say, with that attitude they didn't care much what they did with allied POW's. They were used as slave labor, barely fed, and were beaten severely for infractions, real or imaginary. This part of the book is not for the squeamish and it makes you wonder how anyone who survived "life" in these camps could come out a reasonably normal human being. (Indeed, many POW's became physical and/or mental wrecks.) I don't want to ruin the story by saying how Mr. Zamperini coped, but it wasn't easy. After the war he was a mess for awhile, but eventually he did settle down to lead a productive life helping other people. He also stayed thin and kept himself fit by continuing to run for exercise. In his sixties he was still running a mile in under six minutes and in his seventies he took up skateboarding.This was an amazing rollercoaster of a book. I know it's a cliche to say a book is a "page turner" but "Unbroken" is such a book. I couldn't put it down and read it far into the night, well past my normal bedtime. It was, by turns, funny, exciting, frightening, depressing, sickening and, in the end, inspirational. A great, great book about an amazing man.

I really loved this book. I was a bit concerned at the start that it was going to be a bit too "New Age"...you know, maybe seeing this small, Buddhist kingdom thru rose-colored glasses as a cure for the modern world...but Ms. Napoli quickly put my fears to rest. (I think it's important that the book was written by someone in their mid-forties, who has lived a lot and who has gained some perspective.) To be honest, I don't know that Bhutan brought out anything in the author that wasn't already there. She is very bright and introspective and it seems to me she already knew what was important in life. She is outgoing and has many friends, and is warm and giving and not materialistic. Mainly, she was burned-out by her job and disillusioned about the news business. I think she really needed a bigtime change of scenery, but with her personality we aren't talking about a regular vacation where you go shopping and relax by the pool. She needed something more esoteric and spiritual, and that's what Bhutan provided.The thing I most enjoyed about this book was that it combined diary-like introspection with first-class reportage and humor. Ms. Napoli tells us about the awesome mountain vistas and wonderful, friendly people of Bhutan, but she also regales us with tales of greed (a Buddhist holy-man who is not averse to trying to squeeze a quick buck out of foreigners) and dislocation, as Bhutan lurches, ever so gingerly, into the 21st century. We have a country that is trying to change from a kingdom into a parliamentary democracy, but where the elections can't be held until the monks determine what days will be most auspicious; a country that wants tourism, but that imposes a substantial fee so that only "the right sort of person" will show up. (They want rich tourists, not the great-unwashed on a spiritual odyssey.) On a more personal level, we learn how the changes affect the people Ms. Napoli has become close to. In a country where television and the Internet are now becoming pervasive, and the Western lifestyle of conspicuous consumption is on full-display, how do you maintain traditional values? Are you able to?As an extra "bonus", early-on in the book the author describes why the University of Texas at El Paso has a campus adorned with buildings in the Bhutanese architectural style. It is a quirky, fascinating little tale.Highly recommended.

I was a bit disappointed in this collection after seeing the good reviews. Maybe my expectations were too high? The collection seemed very uneven and I found about one-third to one-half of the entries to be not all that interesting. Some of the entries seemed too long and some seemed not long enough. For example, the first entry was by a travel writer who happens to be gay and he meets a man who he wants to get romantically involved with, only to find out that the other man is only interested in making some quick money as a tour-guide. It was funny, in a bittersweet way, and pretty interesting, but it was only 4 pages long and I felt like just as I was getting interested in the story........it was over!.....Another story was over 60 pages long, and I felt it did not warrant such length.....especially in a book of this kind. That one story just took up too much of the book. Some of the stories just did not engage me, such as the story by the writer who went down to South America to study bats with his scientist father. On the other hand, one of the other stories about rich people who buy apartments on old cruise ships that have been converted into condominiums was just fascinating. These people travel the world, as part of a small but elite community, with the ship as their home. I didn't know anything like this existed and I found the story to be very interesting. Again, I was disappointed overall in the collection. It wasn't as good as I expected it to be. It is worth reading, but you may find yourself bored in spots and you may want to skip over some of the stories.

Tamara Petkevich is now 90 years old. That she has made it to this age is something of a miracle. Stalin's "camps" (what a misnomer from an American point of view!)could, and probably should, have done her in. Or, going thru what she had to endure, she could easily have chosen to take her own life. She certainly thought about it several times. That she chose life over death is a tribute to the human spirit in general and to her exceptional inner strength in particular.Anyone who has even a cursory knowledge of 20th century Russian history knows of Stalin's paranoia and the nightmarish world of the Gulag. The book presupposes that you do have some knowledge of the topic, and I imagine that anyone without some background in the subject wouldn't be interested in this book. The interesting question would be, if I already know about this stuff, why should I read this book? The answer is, "Memoir Of A Gulag Actress" is a seamless blending of the universal, political and personal.Tamara Petkevich was born in 1920, and was 17 when her father was taken away in 1937. He was a hardworking, loyal, idealistic member of the Communist Party. He hadn't done anything wrong. That didn't matter. He was found to be an "Enemy Of The People" and was carted away. Tamara didn't find out until years later, but he died in the camps. Her mother and one sister died during WWII during the siege of Leningrad. Her mother's dead body was removed from her apartment and left by the stairs, to be carted off like a bag of trash and put in a mass grave. Tamara was married and in exile at this point.In 1943 Tamara was taken away and put into the work camps. She hadn't done anything wrong, but it was enough that she was her father's daughter. Her husband was also arrested and put into another camp. The vast majority of the book deals with Tamara's life in the various work camps. She did hard labor under horrendous conditions, but also at times was able to work as a nurse and as an actress. She was young and beautiful and several people in positions of authority attempted to seduce her, so she had to fend off those advances in addition to enduring the "normal" hardships of overwork and malnutrition. She did have a relationship with a doctor who was also serving time in the camps, had a baby, and saw the baby taken away when only 1 year old, to live with the doctor and his "lady friend". Years later, after being released from the camps, Tamara tried to get her son back. The doctor had run off and when Tamara finally tracked him down she found that her son, Yuri, barely knew her and had no interest in living with her. She was devastated.The memoir is a relentless litany of the horrible: arbitrary arrests; overwork, sickness and death; false hopes and dashed dreams. Tamara was the victim of so-called friends bearing false witness against her to save their own skins. People were browbeaten into becoming informers, even if the "information" was fanciful or just a downright lie. Of course, Tamara wasn't the only victim. Indeed, there were millions who were chewed up, sometimes swallowed, and other times spit out by the system.Tamara served 7 years and was released in 1950 at the age of 30. Even after her release she was hounded and feared that she would be arrested again, for no reason, as so many were. Pressure was put on her to become an informant. To her credit, she resisted that pressure. Many others could not, or did not, resist. It was difficult to find work as ex-prisoners were discriminated against and were treated like lepers. After all, if you had been sent away by the authorities didn't that mean that you must have done something wrong?Tamara writes that her love for her son and her love for a fellow actor named Kolya (who died of disease in the camps) kept her sane and enabled her to resist the urge to kill herself. But the camps took a toll on her body and soul. On the cover of the book is a picture of Tamara when she was 20. She looks young and beautiful, even though there is already sadness in her eyes. (Her father had already been taken away.) Inside the book is another picture of her when she was only in her thirties. She looks much, much older.The only thing that disappointed me is that we don't learn anything of Tamara after approximately 1956. She was only 36 then. I would love to know what happened to her after that point. However, that is a minor quibble. This is a wonderful memoir, and the translation by Ross Ufberg and Yasha Klots is masterful. The book reads very smoothly in English, but the remarkable flavor of the original Russian is also retained. This book will stay with me for a long, long time.

I must admit, I wasn't expecting much when I ordered this thru the Vine program. I was wary of anything that is "pre-flavored". However, I was pleasantly surprised. When you open up the bag the smell is wonderful. And the taste is complex. Some people have complained that the vanilla flavor is not pronounced enough, but I find it to be just right. It is definitely there, but not overwhelming. There is another nice flavor in there which I couldn't quite place, but after reading the ingredient list on the bag I assume it is the Sarsaparilla Root. The coffee is slightly bitter, which adds to the complex flavor. (There is a yin-yang thing going on with the sweeter flavors.) I like a very strong, dark roast and I find that this falls into that category although Starbucks advertises it as a medium roast. Overall, I think this is a winner.

I found this to be a very enjoyable romp thru the life of Elizabeth I. It was especially interesting to see things thru the eyes of a woman historian, telling the story by using Elizabeth's relationships with the important women in her life as the focal point. The author starts off by giving details about Elizabeth's relationships with her various stepmothers, and it was interesting to read that she was close to Anne of Cleves as well as Katherine Parr. Anne usually comes across as a nonentity, if not a joke....you know, the woman who was so homely that as soon as Henry VIII saw her he couldn't wait to get rid of her. But in Ms. Borman's account she comes across as a good-natured woman who was kind towards Elizabeth, and she demonstrated political savvy by not making things difficult when Henry wanted to end the marriage. That way, she kept her head and was well-provided for so she could lead a comfortable and peaceful life. Elizabeth learnt a lesson about political pragmatism from this stepmother.The author goes on to explore many other relationships: most notably Elizabeth's relationship with her sister Mary, Henry's older daughter by Catherine of Aragon, and the relationship with Mary, Queen of Scots. Both relationships were fraught with mistrust and jealousy. Mary was worried about Elizabeth's ambition to be Queen, and was envious of her popularity with the public. Elizabeth was concerned with Mary, Queen of Scots desire to be Queen of England, but it was also fascinating to read about Elizabeth's jealousy of Mary on a purely personal level. Mary was reckoned to be beautiful and a charmer. There is a very funny setpiece the author describes where a diplomat from Scotland comes to see Elizabeth, and Elizabeth pumps him for information about Mary (whom Elizabeth had never met). Elizabeth wants to know who is more beautiful, she or Mary? The diplomat, being a diplomat, won't commit himself. According to him, Mary is the most beautiful woman in Scotland and Elizabeth is the most beautiful woman in England. Elizabeth realizes she is getting nowhere with this line of questioning so next she wants to know who is taller? She figures she's got this contest won, as she was famously tall. But, no, the diplomat has to concede that Mary is taller. Things are not going well.....Next, Elizabeth makes sure the diplomat "accidentally" hears her playing the lute. With schoolgirlish surprise she says "Oh, I didn't know you were there!"....of course she wants to know who is the better musician? The diplomat says that Elizabeth is. Good! Later on she dances for him. (She was an excellent dancer and very athletic.) Who is the better dancer? Once again, Elizabeth wins this contest. She is now satisfied.There are many fascinating anecdotes found throughout the book that show the personal side of Elizabeth. Indeed, the book is pretty evenly balanced between the personal and the political. We learn about the political infighting and plots, but we also see Elizabeth's relationships with the women who served her at court. They were servants to some extent, but not as we think as servants as they were of the nobility and could be quite haughty and conceited. Elizabeth was very jealous of anyone younger than herself, especially if they were attractive. There was a sort of "Catch-22" as she wanted to be surrounded by such people as they made for a "glittering court", but she didn't want any feminine competition, either. Thus, while Elizabeth wore beautiful clothes and flashy colors and exquisite jewelry, the women of the court were only to wear black-and-white and were expected to keep the jewelry "toned-down".There are also many examples of Elizabeth's famous temper. She could really act like a spoilt brat at times, yelling at "her ladies" and slapping them if things weren't done quite right. She also was easily angered by all the sexual shenanigans the women of the court go up to. (The book is chock full of clandestine affairs, hidden pregnancies and secret marriages.) However, if you were good at your job and were totally loyal and did not try to outshine the queen Elizabeth could be quite generous and loyal herself.All in all, this is a fascinating study of the political and personal side of this amazingly complex, intelligent, vibrant woman and also of the women in her orbit. I thoroughly enjoyed it and recommend it highly to anyone who is interested in this period of English history. I will mention 2 small caveats. The book presupposes some knowledge of the period. If you haven't done some reading in this area you may find it difficult to follow all the names and relationships. Also, as the author wants to maintain the flavor of the period she quotes extensively from letters of the time. As grammar and spelling were quite different back then you might fight it a challenge to understand what was written if you haven't already been exposed to this sort of thing. But, again, these are minor matters. I found this book to be refreshingly different, extremely interesting and wonderfully entertaining.

After I read this book I thought, the more things change the more they remain the same. We are fascinated with serial killers today, and we were fascinated with them over 100 years ago when Joseph Vacher went walkabout thru the lovely and idyllic French countryside. Mr. Starr covers all the angles.....newspapers tripping over themselves to sensationalize the circulation-boosting story; courtroom outbursts and shenanigans by the defendant; the ineptness of the local police; fear and false accusations before the actual killer was caught; the birth of modern forensics and the infighting between scientists who had different philosophies (the old nature vs. nurture debate). The author doesn't miss a trick, and the book is beautifully written. Not dry but not sensational, either. You'll notice that I put the word disturbing in my title line. This book is disturbing on many levels. It is scary that Joseph Vacher could walk from place to place and get away with so many murders. Your first thought is, well, this WAS over 100 years ago. But then you stop and think about modern serial killers who also go unnoticed and unapprehended for years and years. It is also scary that a fellow human being could be this disturbed. Vacher didn't just kill people. He mutilated them and sexually abused them as well. If we could write him off as "just a nut" I suppose it wouldn't seem so bad. But Mr. Starr quotes extensively from Vacher's poems and letters and he was clearly a sensitive, observant and intelligent man. Sometimes. He was also most probably psychopathic and schizophrenic, wildly unpredictable, devious and manipulative. He was "crazy" but was also aware that he was doing "wrong" and he tried to cover his tracks. That's why he was held legally responsible for his actions. But as Mr. Starr points out, if a person can't control their urges even when they know those urges are wrong, should they be treated as criminals or should they be treated as mentally ill? It was a difficult question 100 years ago and it is a difficult question today. Whatever your views on the subject, I urge you to read this excellent, thought-provoking book.

Full Disclosure: I don't use this product but my wife does, so this review was written after consulting with her and obtaining her feedback. She's been using Tucks for a long time and loves them. They are always nice and moist and are big enough to handle easily. My wife has a lot of allergies and there is nothing in these that bothers her. Tucks does make a smaller container which I think has 40 pads, but she prefers the 100-count pack as the container is easier to handle than the smaller, shorter container. Also, the 100-count pack is more economical. The witch hazel is very soothing and definitely makes living with "The H-Problem" a lot easier! No complaints about this product, whatsoever.

Great stuff! Strong yet soft, and I love the mega-rolls. We have a tall metal cylinder which accomodates normal sized rolls, so it is a bit of a squeeze to get these rolls to fit, but that's a minor drawback. I like mega-rolls because they have a nice heft and feel luxurious and it seems as though they last forever. It's nice not to have to change rolls every 5 minutes! Pricier than store brands, but it's worth the money for the softness and for the convenience of having rolls that last a long time. Really have no complaints about this product.

I'm doing something a bit different for me in this review. I usually make a point of not looking at other reviews before I write my review, as I don't want to be influenced by what other people think. Fortunately or unfortunately, my curiosity got the better of me in this case. I loved this book so much I wanted to sneak a peek and see what the "average" rating was. When I saw that the average was about 3.5 I was amazed that it was so low. I didn't look at the positive reviews, but I was curious to see what the people who had given the book one or two stars had written. I won't comment on any specific reviews, but I've digested the negative reviews and I want to respond in a generic way. I think this might be helpful as the reviews, positive and negative, seem to be all over the place and I know that when I'm trying to decide whether or not to buy a book from Amazon I get especially confused in this type of situation and usually end up not making the purchase. So, here goes.....This is, primarily, a book about characterization. As you can see from the description provided by Amazon, the plot is pretty basic. It is true that nothing earth-shattering or really exciting happens. It's not that kind of book. What we do get are some very well-developed characters interacting in believable ways. We get a lot of intelligent and funny, and also nasty and childish, observations about people and their beliefs. I was a bit taken aback that several reviewers were very sour on the book because they didn't like Flora. They thought she was selfish and immature and were bored by her observations. Personally, I thought she came across as a very complex, real young woman. Is she totally admirable? No. On the other hand she is far from being despicable. She is also very bright and has some very interesting things to say about her parents, her surroundings, and life in general. Without giving too much away, I should also note that Flora shows some growth by the end of the book. Initially, she tends to judge people  based on first impressions and she is very suspicious. And despite being brought up in a "liberal" environment she mocks people who are religious, without getting to know them. But by the end of the book she is more open-minded and generous in spirit and tends to see things a bit more in shades of grey rather than in black-and-white.The author does a nice job of making these changes seem organic rather than forced.  And the book is not just about Flora. Even though her father is dead we get a very good idea of what he was like as an academic, as a husband, and as a father. Likewise, Flora's mother is very well-drawn and funny, interesting and sometimes obnoxious. Cynthia, the father's "autumn romance", is also a wonderfully written character, as is Paul (Flora's "unexpected" boyfriend).Besides the characters being carefully developed in depth, Maggie Pouncey does a great job of describing places, things and memories. This is a very well-crafted book. There is a nice balance between descriptions, thoughts, and (really excellent) dialogue. I found it hard to believe that this was a first-novel. I did notice on the product page that you can "search inside" so the prospective buyer can take a look and see how the book is written. Take a look and see if the style appeals to you. I know that tastes differ, but all I can say is that I found this book to be an immensely satisfying "read", populated with many interesting and very real people, acting in true-to-life ways.

This is a very impressive debut novel by the author, William Ryan. Think "Gorky Park", only set in the 1930's in Stalinist Russia. If you loved the Martin Cruz Smith novel, you will love this as well. Mr. Ryan captures the monochrome Moscow of the period, along with the rampant suspicion...paranoid and otherwise. We have an honest, middle-aged policeman investigating the horrific murder of a nun.....horrific because the woman had been tortured before she was killed (an ear, an eye and her tongue were found beside the body, and to add insult to injury the body was left in a church). We know from the get-go that this is no "ordinary" murder by some madman. The author makes clear that the killer is a professional, most likely working for the NKVD (state security), and the nun was tortured because she was believed to have been privy to some important information. Again, similar to "Gorky Park", we have the scenario of an ordinary policeman getting in over his head, and possibly being manipulated by his superiors. Mr. Ryan grabs our attention right away with the wonderful, complex plot, and the finely-drawn, richly developed characters. The author knows his stuff, and the setting and people seem quite authentic. The characters all have that wonderful, sarcastic, Russian sense of humor, which laughs at life while acknowledging its absurdity. You can easily picture the chilly, damp, dark and dangerous streets of Moscow, with orphaned children (whose parents have been killed or taken to the "camps") prowling the streets like wild animals, trying to survive. I know it sounds like a cliche, but this book is the genuine article, a real page-turner, and it held my interest from start to finish. I strongly recommend it to anyone who loves a good mystery or "police procedural".

I thought this was a very solid book concerning the crash of a military training flight in the High Sierra in November 1942. There were 4 men on the flight....the pilot and three cadets. All were in their twenties. One body was located by happenstance in 2005 and another was located by the author of this book in 2007. To date, the other 2 bodies are still missing. The author does an impressive job of covering a lot of interesting topics: We get a brief biographical background of each man so that we feel, to some extent, that we have gotten to know them; the author tells us about the training each man would have gone thru; we learn about the capabilities and limitations of the aircraft they trained in; we also learn about the geology of the area and the weather conditions in the High Sierra and the difficulty of flying in the mountains in general. The author has done a lot of research and has spoken to many people to come to his conclusions concerning why the plane was flying in the direction it was heading in at the time of the crash, and the most likely scenario concerning the cause of the accident. I thought he did a great job of covering a lot of ground and providing a lot of interesting detail in a relatively short book. There is also a wonderful photo section and the author mentions that he has additional photos on his website. I think this book is well-worth your time and I heartily recommend it.
Fit in and worked perfectly!

Been ordering these sheets a few times, always nice quality, no scratches and with protective film.Cuts and bends well, welds well alsoExcellent price also!

The rubber fur removing broom is one of the greatest inventions of all time!Well OK.. maybe that's a bit dramatic, but here at work, we have ten cats that we have rescued and there seems to be fur - everywhere!This broom does a great job getting the fur off the rugs and carpets -daily here- I also use the squeegee edge when I wash shop floor; down it also works great. The handle is a good length and is metal, nice and stiff.I can give the head a good washing and it cleans up very nicely.So far this broom is holding up to all the abuse we (and the ten cats) can throw at it, I'm pretty sure that for your own home use this will last forever.*****Jim

These are a nice shape and design. Although they say unisex, they are more suited for a woman/girl's face.The coating is nice, I notice the slight blueish reflecting seen in storm windows and some cars.They are comfy and don't interfere or distort screen also.Since I received these in exchange for an unbiased review, I really wanted to put them to good use, I gave these to someone who is on the computer all day and she really likes them, at the end of the day she doesn't have a headache or "achy eyes" ..and she looked cute too!*****Jim

This mouthwash has a "soft" minty taste (I would say a cross between peppermint and spearmint).You also you don't get the punch of mint like other brands or "mediciney" taste.I keep it on hand here at work, to freshen my mouth after coffee, so I prefer a mild taste, although in the morning I like the jolt of a strong mint!

I was asked to try, and then write a review on these mounts and accessories in exchange for an unbiased review.I really like these, there is a mount for just about any situation here!The mounts fit crisp and hold tight, I really like the octopus style tripod, with it you can level out the GoPro in any situation!My favorite though is the pivot arm, it holds tight and locks in place at just the perfect angle.

I was offered to received a bottle for review to write an unbiased review, since I take these daily I was happy to try them.The first thing I noticed is that they are smaller - which for people like me who take a few of these, that's a good thing!So far I have taken these for a few weeks and no adverse reactions. They also do NOT have a fishy taste or did I get the dreaded "fish burps"As far as the potency goes, as other reviewers have stated, these are top notch.*****Jim
Works perfectly on my kindle HDX 8.9

Like others have stated I wish it came with a bit more instructions on how to fit this (loose? tight? etc..)That being said it is very soft and very easy to adjust/fit over wrist.It is about 3/8" wide, not too big - just right. The move itself is good; the subtitles are really bad though!Worth waching though.

I was asked to review this splitter in exchange for an unbiased review:I used this splitter to run my ROKU to two different TV's that way If I wanted to stream, I could on either set.It worked perfectly, I didn't notice any difference between the "split" signal and when it was just hooked up to one TV.I also tested it with my PS4, and it also worked just fine! ( Video and sound went though to both TV's ).Installation is quick and easy also, I like it! ****

This soap bar fits right into Dove's "Men+Care" line. It has a good scent not too strong, but it is there; and it gets the dirt and grime off me - which feels great after all day at work.It lathers nice, and just as it says (presumably due to the 1/4 of it being moisturizing cream) my skin does not feel dry or "tight" after!It has a nice oval shape and the color is a nice (maybe not "manly" but nice) powder blue.****

These are nice, comfy and pretty neat-looking earbuds!I was asked to review these in exchange for an unbiased review, I am very happy with these.The over the ear design is great for running or any exercise really, while I'm not usually a fan of this style, these are not uncomfy at all!The sound is very good, I listen to ambient and classical and the sound reproduction is very good.(I did not try out the Mic function, being that I primarily use these with my iPod)Like I said, the "looks" of them are neat, I like the braiding effect that the cords have, and the cords are the perfect length to me.Nice!****

This armband works as advertized! it securely holds your phone (LG Optimus, also tested it on a Galaxy 5) and you can still use the touch screen, which is nice especially when you are all sweaty and don;'t feel like holding the phone up to your ear.It is easily adjustable and has a pouch for ID, money etc..The pink is a tiny bit brighter than shown, and so far it has not chipped or flaked off.****

I was asked to review this in exchange for an honest review, I'm glad I said "yes!"I use this daily for my dog walks! it holds my phone ( LG Optimus with case ) dog treats and my keys with room left over - not that it is bulky by any means, it's just a really great size for "grab and go" stuff.The zippers work well, no binding, the velcro strap also works great, really makes it adjustable.I saw it asked if it is waterproof , I have been caught in the rain with this and my phone stayed dry - BUT I didn't test it by dunking it or anything, I doubt it would be water"proof" but it did a fine job protecting the contents from rain. ( you can spray it with water-repellant when you get it for added protection )****

This unit is so cute!I was offered a chance to review this diffuser in exchange for an unbiased review, since we have a *lot* of rescued cats here at work I said "YES!"Anyway, this unit is really cute, it has a nice wood-grain look to it, it is very unassuming.It works flawlessly - without scented oil it works as a humidifier (and I assume a negative ion generator)It has soft lights, you really don't see them unless the room is very dark, but they are nice and can be set to different arrays.You can let it run until empty, or timed intervals.It does NOT come with any oils, not even samples, so you will need to pick them up ( maybe here on Amazon when ordering?)All in all, this works great, when we did add a few drops of oil, the offices came alive with a wonderful lavender scent and the cats seem to be mesmerized by the little bit of steam coming out the top! :)*****

I was given this recorder in exchange for an unbiased review:When outside for work especially in inclement weather, instead of writing things down I just make "mental notes", then when I get back to the truck I write things down. With this it's easier can do all of the inspecting, record my notes and observations, and not worry about forgetting any details.I like that I can use this instead of my phone, especially in bad weather or dirty environments.It's a good size - it may be on the small side for some but for me it is just right not too big or bulky.The capacity is very good, I have never ran out of room.****

I have been a long-time fan of Brightech and their innovative products, So when I was offered the VIPER, in exchange for an honest review, I said yes. Brightech has an extensive line of charger and jump packs, but this hands down is their BEST unit so far!This unit has an amazing amount of power is such a compact package - 55.5Wh (15,000mAh) is insane.This can charge just about anything - from phones, tablets even laptops and of course can jump you car - several times!The unit comes with just about all the standard cables and accessories - including an Air compressor - (which I used to pump up a tire with a slow leak in my truck) and a nice bright LED light.It comes in a nice soft case, with plenty of room - so you can add your own spare cables (for your laptop, or the Samsung double cable for example) emergency radio, medicine first aid etc.. basically anything you like to keep for emergency handy in you vehicle.You can charge it either home ( with it's included AC charger) or your accessory outlet. When I got it, it was basically fully charged, I just topped it off.Like other reviewers of said, I believe this is really the best all-around package like this available from Brightech - and maybe anyone else!easily 5 starsJim

My dog ( A whippet) is a fairly picky eater, I usually break up small soft treats to enhance his food to get him to eat.Mixing wet food in left his dry food too wet.When I tried this it is a very good consistency - it's like toothpaste so it doesn't soak the food - and he loved it! :)The list of ingredients is all "human grade" and is limited, meat, berries, water, oatmeal etc.The pack itself is pretty small, I would say it would last about 5 feedings more or less depending on the weight.I can also see this being used for medicine - it's thick enough to hide a small tablet in it with the food!****Jim

I like the variety of different styles of fountains here.I tweaked some of the designs here at there ( I wanted to make a larger Deer-Chaser ) but all of the designs I checked out are laid out well,with tons of pictures.

My dog is a fairly picky eater, so I like the idea that I can swap out flavors of food so he doesn't get bored (I usually break up a little bit of treats to mix in).As dog owners know swapping foods usually leads to .. well a mess :)Switching over to this food is initially done the same way ( slowly mixing it with the old food until you finish up with mostly new and a little old food )From there (theoretically) you can swap out the flavors without any problems.I first made sure I was able to get more of this locally if needed ( I was ) and I tried it, he does like it and I can swap it back and forth!He does have an iron stomach however, if your dog has a sensitive stomach your results may vary, you know your friend best :)So far he likes the variety of foods and he eats it without treats ( or begging or negotiating!)It's a neat idea, and he seems to agree!****Jim

I like the fit and finish of this coffee grinder. you can tell a bit of care was put into designing it, it's sleek and has a minimum of parts.Since it's hand cranked, it is very compact, the handle lifts off the top so it takes up barely any room on the counter - you can even keep it in the silverware drawer or utility (aka junk) drawer!The instructions are printed on the box itself, it's basically pretty easy, you can adjust the grind, although there are not definitive settings, you just need to do some samples while adjusting the set screw. It comes with a stiff brush for cleaning.I only make coffee for myself so I don't grind too much, so for me being hand-cranked is no biggie - it smells nice, is quiet and the grind is just the way I like it.Very nice!****Jim

I was a bit skeptical when I was offered a chance to review this cutting board set in exchange for an unbiased review.Three quality boards for only 11 bucks? I was contacted to receive this unit in exchange for an unbiased review.I typically don't use my iPod for anything but to store music and take it into my car or reading ( I don't use it for jogging or working out etc..)So my review is for just the casual music listener with a lot of audio files.As others have said, the unit looks nice, the color is a little brighter - but it's a nice red.As others also have said, the instructions range from kinda unclear to non-existent  but with some fiddling I got it to do what I want/need.Plugged into the car I don't have a problem it ( the car) read it and I was able to navigate to different songs - so that is what I was happy with and why I gave it four stars.If I leave this in the car and it goes missing or gets damaged it's not the end of the world do to its price compared to name brand players.****Jim

These are handy snacks for chocolate cravings in the middle of the day. The entire pouch is 190 (60 from fat) calories, so it's not *too* bad.The flavor isn't too sweet  - I would say a good description is a chocolate covered cocoa-puff!I usually have a half a bag, then usually pick some here and there during the day... unless someone helps themselves to them first!****Jim

I received this set in exchange for a fair and unbiased review, and I'm glad I did!As you can see by the picture, we got this set right before the Fourth of July, and we put them to use right away :)These work great on glass,  very vibrant and really no fading after!

I was asked to test and review this unit in exchange for an unbiased review - I'm glad I said yes!The unit came faster than the estimated time and in perfect condition. I wanted to test it because I never had a mount that is magnetic- meaning that you can pull the phone with suction mount right off the other half (to use the phone for a minute than put back on windshield) I have to admit that's pretty cool! I do have to grab the phone a lot when I'm on the road, to it's neat to just literally grab it, use it for a few seconds, and pop it back into the magnet.The magnetic mount DOES hold the phone perfectly - I was worried that it would shift down (or fall off) but nope - it's just fine. The suction cup holds onto the windshield great; the other side that suction cups to the phone needs a nice flat surface, so keep that in mind if you have a bumpy phone case.Being that it only holds it from the back and only has a ball joint with no adjustment screw it has a very minimal footprint, great for smaller cars/windshields,I really like it, I think you will also!****Jim

I was given a sample of this product in exchange for a fair unbiased review.I really like the size of this pouch, I have others that are smaller ( for a phone or wallet) and much larger (for clothes and supplies), this one is pretty much the perfect size for a few important things like your phone, wallet and keys.I actually put paper in it, sealed in and put it underwater - the paper was bone dry!I use it hiking with my dog I keep my keys and phone and his treats in it, I have been caught in rain and everything was totally dry.****Jim

I am so impressed by this flag, I love it! I am so happy that this size was finally available.The fabric has a nice thick quality feel to it. The colors are vibrant just as shown and looks even better in sunlight!the word "PEACE" is correctly written on both sides, on a hem - so you can't see the "PEACE" written on the opposite side bleeding through.definitely *****Jim

The scent is just strong enough, it actually fills the bathroom with its scent, but doesn't overpower you when you use it.It's a very large rounded bar of soap, I'd say about 2.5x larger. It comes in a nice box with straw, so if you give it as a housewarming gift it looks nice. All around a very nice bit of luxury in your daily life!Oh..and it does get you clean, rinses away clean and doesn't leave a film behind! So it does its jobs as a very good cleaning soap as well!*****Jim

First off: I received PAS Formula free in exchange for an honest, unbiased review.Second off: Consult your physician before taking or stopping any vitamin or medicine regimen.The first thing I noticed about this formula is that it had Valerian in it.I have taken Valerian in the past in both capsules and tea (stinky!) it has been called "natural Valium".I know it has always worked to take the edge off in the past, but I never had it mixed with other ingredients.The capsules are not too big and I didn't notice aftertaste.I usually take these when I know it's going to be a stress-packed day, not daily and notice that it does take the edge off those stress packed days. I'm still alert and all, just not so "jumpy and stressed out"****Jim

First off: I received Mastermind free in exchange for an honest, unbiased review.Second off: Consult your physician before taking or stopping any vitamin or medicine regimenThe first thing I noticed is the packaging is artwork, it really looks well put together and that care was taken. I know that's not really important to the effectiveness of a product, it stands to reason if they put that much care into the packaging....The capsules are easy to swallow and I didn't notice any aftertaste. after a week or so I did notice that there was a general "calm", I didn't need sleep aids as often, and when I did, I took half of what I did ( my biggest issue was "turning off" my mind when trying to go to sleep).( I assume that's the L-tryptophan ) I didn't feel tired during the day however.. just a general feeling of calm.****Jim

I am totally hooked on this series, I wished I watched it when it came on PBS, but at least I can catch up on the first two seasons now, and hopefully the 3rd will be released in the prime side soon :)Acting, sets, dialog top notch!

I adore this show! You can have "Orange is the new Black" I'll take this show any-day!.I love dialog, it is so campy, so retro-rockabilly it's pure genius-  the more you watch it, the more you will want to 're-watch it, for the line you just missed !I binged on this and want more more more :)

I have used other Vive products in the past, so when I was offered to test and give an unbiased review on these I accepted.I wear a size 9.5 and the Large fit in very well - since 9.5 it was right on the edge of the sizing chart between Med and Large I was a little worried that they would not fit as well as they do!I put them in a pair of canvas skate shoes that I like to wear when I walk the dog, or other activities in the summer.I did notice the arch support for about 30 minutes, but after  while and now for example when I put them on they feel that they ( the insoles) have been in there since the beginning! The foam is a nice density so it doesn't get mushed down and useless quickly.****Jim

The first thing I noticed about these were that they are more "Shiny" than pictures here, I guess the best description is they have a satin sheen to them. They really look nice - almost too nice to use as dish towels! I tossed them into the wash and broke them in  they are  ince and thirstyThe designs are really nice, the 3 different colors contrast great, the squares are defined and they really make a nice finishing touch.****Jim

I have enjoyed other Go-Lo products in the past so when I was offered a free sampling in exhanged for an unbiased review, I decided to give it a shot.I did enjoy the taste of this, it is different from Nutella, not as sweet, but that's not really a bad thing to me!.I put it on banana I was snacking on and it was really good - also on apples, and graham crackers :)What i like most about this is the size is just right, pre-measured to 100 calories, perfect to bring with you or toss in your kid's lunch.Also since they are pre0packed it stops you from grabbing a spoon and digging into a jar of it :)****Jim

The first thing I noticed about this blanket is that it has a great "feel" - tight thread but still a soft feel.The color is nice, maybe a bit darker than shown, but pretty close.It also has a nice weight to it, not flimsy in the least; it doesn't move when placed on the floor, it's a perfect size for me.The blanket ships rolled and I can see how it can easily be used as a cushion or support.I haven't used it as a blanket, however I did lay it on the wicker chair and found my dog snuggled up into it - so he likes it also! :)RReally nice!****Jim

Like most of the other reviewers here, I  was advised by my doctor that I needed Omega 3 (fish oil) in my diet, so I have been taking a supplement for years now. So when I was offered a sample bottle for the purpose of inspection and honest, unbiased review I accepted.To be honest I typically went for  the cheapest bulk buy of these, but since taking these (for about a month) I do notice that there is less aftertaste with these -to me anyway- than the other, cheaper brand(s) I have taken.I always thought it was just one of those things to expect, until I tried these!I can't really comment on the "fish burp" - I rarely had a burping problem before - with these I still don't.The size is a tad bit smaller than when I have been taking, but if you have taken fish oil before, you know they are kinda large.I'm not going to say they are pleasant tasting -- because-- well it is fish oil! :PSo far, I like these, I will definitely buy more when these run out.****Jim

I was advised by my doctor that I needed more Vitamin D in my diet, so I have been taking a supplement for almost a year now. So when I was offered a sample bottle for the purpose of inspection and honest, unbiased review I accepted.In size comparison, the one I have been taking was a tablet, much larger than these! These are only about this size and shape of a Tic-Tac, they are gelatin and to be honest I don't even notice them when I take my pills in the PM. According to their label they pack 5,000 IU 12,500% Daily Value! I have been taking them for about a month now, and I am happy with the results so far ( I go in for  routine blood work in about a month or so; if something is whacky Ill let you know! )I would say since you have a year supply here to keep them in a dry spot, I have noticed when I keep them in the kitchen they do stick to each other a little ( from my cooking and humidity I guess ) but besides that I really like these!*****Jim

I admit I have too many gadgets, (a powder blue sample was provided for the purpose of testing and unbiased review) and this unit really works like a champ - it saves counter space, stays cool and the powder blue really looks neat, definitely not the same old boring black or white!I have it in the kitchen it looks neat!I have used it to charge: an iPad, Kindle HDX 8.9, Galaxy 5, LG Optimus and a Samsung Galaxy Camera. My friends charged iPhone5 and 6 too.I have used it solo and with multiple devices. Perfect example was yesterday- my Kindle was drained to 8% my Galaxy Camera was 12%and my LG actually shutoff it was so dead, so I charged all three at once quickly and efficiently and the unit didn't get too warm,so yeah I really like this unit!*****Jim

As I said in some of my other book reviews I'm "forcing" myself into reading novels for the summer, (instead of bios, tech, nature etc..)So for my next book I chose this one, and I am happy that I did.What I already thought was a touching and warm story turned into much more inspirational when I learned that the author drew upon her own family's history for the story. Adoption can be both wonderful and painful, this book shows both sides of it and I am happy she let us into her personal life.****

I think a 3 star rating is perfect, it was an "OK" story, I enjoyed it, but as others have said it was a bit predictable.That being said, I do enjoy thrillers and this was creepy enough for me, but there was something lacking, it may be the story being told in various points of few.***

I can't express how much I love this fan! It just looks so cool and retro. I wanted a fan, but didn't want it sticking out like a sore thumb in the living room. This actually *looks* cool (I got the green one) It's used currently to to help circulate the a.c., in the winter it will be by the woodstove to circulate the heat.Yes, it's more money, but YES it's worth every penny!*****Jim

I was invited to try this floor lamp for an unbiased review and to be honest, i was not expecting such a warm soft light from an LED lamp!The quality alone in this lamp is flawless. the finish is perfect. The base is nice and heavy, the sections connect together perfectly. What else is cool, is that the power does not string through the sections they plug into each other internally, so it looks like it you didn't want to extend the lamp to the full height you don't need to (I have mine fully assembled, it's  6ft.)The lamp itself is awesome it has three settings, each is noticeably brighter or dimmer than the other.I noticed no hum or interference.Finally since it is LED it does not heat up the room (and of course, saves energy) the lamp shape is nice and compact - super sleek.Not .such more to say this an awesome lamp, toss in the fact it's LED, it's downright incredible!*****Jim

This is really a cute item! The "apps" are tactile touch, and all do different things depending on the letter and level. ( B for Ball, P for Puppy ) for example. On level 1 it's very basic, level 2 begins to asks them questions and level 3 takes it a bit further with storytelling.It's easy to switch levels with the slide button - (which can be a problem since your youngster can also easily change levels also)It's neat and fun, what is nice especially is that it can be dropped ( it has several times already) without worrying the costs associated ruining your iPad or Kindle or other tablet!Mine came with batteries installed and the tablet was working as I opened the package, I don't know if is supposed to be like that, but so far the batteries are still fine.If you have already introduced them to an actual tablet then this may bore them, but I still think it's pretty nice, cute and a good teaching tool.****Jim

When I was approached to try and then review these melatonin capsules, I was a bit skeptical; I have tried melatonin before with little success.When I first opened these I noticed that there is a nice quality to them -  they are the size of a Tic-Tac, and have a smooth coating.I have started taking them - usually about a half hour or so before I go to sleep, I have noticed a nice calm and uninterrupted sleep.What is nice is that when I DON'T take them - I don't stare at the ceiling, so it's not like I "need" to take them - I usuallytake them when I spend a late night on the computer - and on a Saturday night when I just want to "re-charge the battery"These are not "sleeping pills" so if you are trying to compare them to Lunesta or Tylenol PM etc.. these aren't like that IMHO.They just get you in a nice calm state for sleep, I like these - a lot!*****Jim

I have about 5 different Dynomighty wallets in different designs, NONE of them have every ripped!Love these and this design is another cool one.My only tip for you.. the colors will eventually fade ( or rub off ) I notice it on the darker styles, But if you get lighter designs ( like the take-out box for example) they look great for a LONG time!

Being vegetarian I steam or stir fry veggies, tofu, noodles just about every night.The wok is heavy for it's size - they call it "professional weight" - this gives nice even heating. The handles are nice the handle on the front edge is a nice touch.The issue I thought I was going to have is that most "authentic woks" are not non-stick - rather many have dents or dimples along the sides so when you are stir-frying you can slide the items you don't want in high heat or oil on the sides, the dimples hold them there.How they get around this is that they have many slightly indented ridges that go around the wok, this does help to hold veggies along the side - nice! The non-stick coating does let you cut back - or eliminate - oils in your cooking unless you want them for flavor.I have had no problems cooking; the flat bottom works great on my gas cook-top.The steamer ( bamboo 2 levels ) works well with this wok it fits perfect, the chopsticks - also bamboo - are cute and nice and long so you can use them for cooking.Overall, This is a nice combo set for someone who doesn't have a steamer and wok. To be honest even if you didn't get the steamer this would still be a good buy!****Jim

I love Orbit - I even love their commercials :)Since I quit smoking.. and drinking .. and watching my weight.. I have been reduced to chewing gum.. lots of it!Made by Wrigley, all these flavors have a nice clean mint base, the newer flavor (to me anyway) "sweet mint" is good too, its a mix between "wintermint and spearmint" I think. The flavor lasts a good time and I can even make decent little bubbles with it :)I do like their "bubble mint" so I would of liked to see that inside this inside the box just to give a really different flavor(it's available in the larger variety pack ) but besides that I like it.. for a good clean mouth! ;)****Jim

June 3 update- I changed my rating to 5 stars, the capacity is better than I thought and I found that I have been using it more and more around the house - for example- crumbs on dog bed - gone!I really like a lot about this vacuum! This is a very handy, light, maneuverable - yet powerful - vacuum that I use daily in the kitchen.It is a two-in-one, and when separated, it resembles a Dustbuster, when snapped back into place you get a neat what I call "vacuum stick"It is very easy to operate, the head swivels like a snake. It fits right up to wall and around furniture legs.It easily gets all the crumbs my dog ( and I )  leaves around!There are two speed settings, usually "normal" is perfect. The battery life is very good also. The capacity of the dust collector is very good,its again - the size of a Dustbuster's - maybe a bit larger - it also has nice washable filters.I guess the only downside is the ability to turn the brush rotation off - while it is very soft - it would be nice to be able turn it off to save the battery or just to have it off when you don't really need it.****JimPS. Note on charging - The location to charge it is in the back of the main unit you will see a bump with a hole in it.Why am I telling you this? It's NOT marked and all the holes (for the screws) look the same in the dark blue color!You have to look to see with a flashlight "hey that's not a screw, that's the battery jack" - there is nothing showing it in the instructions - I'm not too proud to say I sat there looking at the vacuum for about 10 minutes trying to figure it out :) Once you do - the battery charge light will glow until fully charged then only pulse on at random times- nice!.

OK.. first with the "bad".. This isn't really "Big" in my opinion, the inside usable area is 10" x 6.5" x 4 (with the bare minimal egg-crate top padding only, 3" with one layer of foam padding and 2" with all layers) So plan your purchase accordingly, you may need the larger one.So with that being said this case is INSANE! It's pretty much the case you should put your favorite gear in.I use it to hold My Rebel, lens & accessories that I use at work. I usually am taking the camera on the road and use it to take pictures of hydrants, utility work, inclement weather etc.. so it gets tossed around.I usually use a back-pack style bag - but this is SO much better, I like it's waterproof and shock properties, plus it's just the right size to hold my gear safe and sound. It also comes with a strap but I just use the handle like a lunch box.Speaking of dust and water resistance- It has an air pressure compensation valve by the handle. On it, it says "Auto Pressure Valve IP67 Rated" so I did a little digging and found out what IP67 means found this on SourceTech411:"The two numbers in the IP67 rating code rating refer to: 6 – ” Dust Protected “; Totally protected against dust ingress.; complete protection against contact 7- ” Immersion Protected “; Protected against short periods of immersion in water.Ingress of water in harmful quantity shall not be possible when the enclosure is immersed in water under defined conditions of pressure and time (up to 1 m of submersion).Test duration: 30 minutes;  Immersion at depth of at least 1 m measured at bottom of device, and at least 15 cm measured at top of device"So I feel confident in the dust and water resistance of this case for sure.The foam inserts are pre-scored into 1/2" squares you pop out the ones you want to help fit your gear in very easily.The two snaps clip into metal bars with a very solid click.While I am not going to drop this in acid, water or a dust-storm; I do trust this case with my camera, memory cards and even my phone -  this is a tough case!*****Jim

When I saw the title, the first thing I thought was "been there.. and unfortunately.. done that!"While she described alcohol as "the gasoline of all adventure" to me it was the road to escape and also the road to creative ideas For me, running my own business, creating products and websites for them - I always had a bit of vodka to help me relax and create, and to escape.A "bit" turned to about a liter a day... I came to a moment of clarity and had to stop. This book reminds me so much of those days (both good and bad). I totally get where she is coming from. It's terrifying to just "not know" what the hell you did, how you got to your bed, couch or floor..who you insulted or angered, or if you were the life of the party! (Luckily for me, I was a "happy drunk" and was responsible enough to drink either at home, or walking distance or have a ride home.) I also never woke up in any exotic locations or with strangers.. unlucky me I suppose!So this book really hit home for me, for me - it's a very gripping and very accurate - and I believe you will enjoy and also be intrigued the tales of the excess, the joy and the pains she went though.I would love to meet Sarah one day for a drink -- of coffee :)A great read *****Jim

The scents in these are amazing, really different combinations. My favorite - believe it or not - is the olive oil!The scent stays on your hands for a while, not TOO strong though, they just smell nice and clean, even my dog came over and was sniffing :)(If anyone has tried "Method" Brand hand soaps or dish cleaners, you will like these)They clean well and lather nicely, not too much. The conditioner soaps work well also, not greasy.The labels are very hard to read (small font and bad contrast) so for people who like to read ingredients for allergies should contact mfg.Real real nice!*****Jim

To be honest I get a bit nervous testing things out on my computer or in this case my PS4.So when I received this for a test and review I was a little bit nervous with it, but after I hooked it up ( as others said it doesn't have a manual, which hopefully they will include with newer models ), I am very happy to say it works wonderful!I love how the PS4 is shaped, but as you know it's wonky- you can't really stand it on it's edge without help.This works great to hold it stable, keep it cool, charge your controllers AND easy access to USB ports.it's great!*****JimPs. I guess the only drawbacks so far is no manuals and it isn't an officially licensed accessory (as of this review at least) so if that matters, but as far as for fit and function its great!

I was offered a chance to test and review this gazing ball, I am usually not too keen on color changing items, but since I liked the look of it clear,I figured I would try it.... WOW was I amazed at how cool this looks!It has a small solar panel in the top hook area so it's nice and out of the way, the chain and light cord are the same color and the LED is very tiny. What I like is that is SLOWLY blends from one color to the next, not a harsh flip of color, just a nice morph.It looks MUCH MUCH better in real life than what's shown here, since it morphs into the colors, you a wider range of colors, not just the three shown. During the day the clear lenses sparkle.So far it's been a few rains, and so far so good, it looks great & works great, it comes on automatically and I love it!*****Jim

I love these! they are pretty cool and different, the tread is aggressive and they look great with jeans. The color has a *slight* hint of green in it not picked up by the pictures, which I personally like.*****Jim

I always liked the idea of nice smelling clothes from washing/drying, from dryer sheets to these (what I call - Tic-Tac) scents & brands like this one. I usually do one large load a week (just me.. and a dog! ) Its as easy as the other brands to use also, just toss some in -(I use cold water) and that's it.While the preference in whether you *like* the scent is up to you; I can say this is the strongest scented ones I have triedWhen the package arrived in the mail I could literally smell the scent coming from the box!The scent seems to stay on the clothes longer -in the closet or drawer, or on me, than other brands I have tried.Try it, I think you'll like it!****Jim

I was offered  this cell phone case in exchange for an honest review, at first I didn't think I would need it but..While I don't use this for outdoor sports or wet conditions, I DO use my phone to stream music to a Bluetooth speaker at work. At work the phone is subject to oils and sparks since I work in sheet metal shop. This totally protects the phone and allows me to talk on it while keeping nice, clean and protected.Real nice and durable so far!

When this item was made available for free for review purposes, I chose the Short Tubular E, I liked how it looked in the picture ( the spiral design).When I received the unit I was very pleased with the shipping, the bulb came in perfect condition.When I tried it, it looked exactly as pictured! It gives a very nice, warm glow - not yellow but "natural" if that makes sense. I have it now In a lamp that can show it off and it looks wonderful. I am going to go back and order more for a few other decorative lamps; if you have a decorative "retro" lamp, you owe yourself a bit of a splurge in this well made and great looking bulb!*****Jim

I was provided this mouse by Sodee to try out, I use a mouse for a little gaming, but more for digital art, photo retouching etc..The first thing I noticed was the effort in packaging, it just *looks* nice, it is packed perfectly.I then noticed the colors, the mouse is flat black and the yellow "pops" real nice!! The cord says it's braided, but min feels more like a flat (or oval) rubber cord, it's nice though, soft and yellow also. (I'm a lime-green guy, but this yellow is nice.)And when plugged it, it has a soft yellow glow, ( which can be turned off)Ok, the important stuff - I simply plugged it into my ANCIENT PC ( Running Win XP Pro) and it immediately recognized and installed it. NO problems at all! You control the sensitivity by the button behind the wheel, which is easy and nice for my photo-work.I guess the only "complaint" is that I with I could toggle the wheel to spin free, I may "operate" on it like I do my other mouses (mice?)Besides that - I love it, yes it doesn't have all the bells and whistles as more expensive models, but for the price - this rocks!*****Jim

What a nice mat, and it really works well! I like four things especially;1) it folds great, the 3 lines you see are actually creases that allow for flat storage.2) it has a web design (on one side) that allows air into a glass that's drying to help it dry without fogging - neat!3) very soft and foamy feel this will easily protect glasses and cups4) VERY absorbent!! It sucks up all the drips from my glasses, I even may silverware on it to dry....it works great and looks great!*****Jim

My dog Chance (a whippet) is a pretty picky eater/snacker and he *really* likes these!They are small, about 1/2", and fit inside his treat toy.They are also good for training or just a small treat...oh and they smell good too!

I already have a smaller version of this massage roller.  While the smaller one is only used as a minimal part of my exercise routine, I thought I would like to try this larger one.  It was given to me through Amazon's vine program without charge, in exchange for an honest review.  And I can honestly say that this larger one is better than the smaller one that I have been using.  .However, the retail price would give me pause.  I live on a fixed income.
