It's hard to believe that it's been seven years since "In the Arms of God", the last studio album from Corrosion of Conformity was released.  In that time, a lot has happened, most notably with C.O.C. singer/guitarist Pepper Keenan spending a majority of his time with Down, and C.O.C. seemed to be indefinitely put on the back-burner.  Now, here we are in 2012, and not only has C.O.C. returned with this new self-titled album, but they've returned boasting their classic lineup from the "Animosity" days.  Standout tracks, including "The Doom", "Your Tomorrow", and "Psychic Vampire" are sludgy, surprisingly breathtaking tracks that any lover of C.O.C.'s pre-Pepper days will enjoy, even if vocalist Mike Dean doesn't have that same growl he had way back when.  All that being said though, this self-titled release from Corrosion of Conformity is a wonderful throwback to a bygone era, and if they can manage to keep pumping out solid music like this, it will make us all miss Pepper a little less and less as time goes on.

Over 20 years later, Frankenhooker remains a totally trashy treat.  From the mind of Basket Case creator Frank Henenlotter, Frankenhooker revolves around an ex-medical student (James Lorinz) who seeks to bring his fiance (Penthouse pet Patty Mullen) back from the dead after her untimely death via remote control lawnmower.  What follows are some disgusting and hilarious moments, which still remain wonderfully enjoyable even all these years later.  Synapse has done another fine job with this Blu-Ray release, featuring some great special features and a wonderfully restored picture.  While Frankenhooker isn't for everyone, you won't find many films like it, which makes it all the more worthwhile for you to see if you've never experienced what Frankenhooker has to offer.

Based on Mark Waid's "Tower of Babel" arc in JLA, Justice League: Doom finds the JLA under attack by the immortal Vandal Savage, who has managed to round up a group of villains (including Bane and Metallo) to take out the League members one by one.  That's pretty much it in a nutshell, as Doom manages to unleash some dark and rousing action and adventure throughout its brisk 77-minute run time, which ends up being just right enough that you won't notice the plot holes and unevenness all that much either.  While the film doesn't hold a candle to Waid's storyarc, it remains a thrilling ride while it lasts.  That, and the excellent voice cast that features returning fan favorites like Kevin Conroy as Batman, Tim Daly as Superman, Nathan Fillion as Green Lantern, Michael Rosenbaum as Flash, Carl Lumbly as Martian Manhunter, and Susan Eisenberg as Wonder Woman, really help make Doom a winner.  All in all, Justice League: Doom is an enjoyable and dark blast that deserves checking out.

Johnny Depp once again channels his late, great friend Hunter S. Thompson in this long overdue adaptation of The Rum Diary, which while it retains the spirit of Thompson's source material, it also sadly feels somewhat watered down.  Depp plays Paul Kemp, a hard-living New York journalist that winds up in San Juan.  As he gets a feel for the local colour (and booze), Kemp comes across the shady mogul Sanderson (Aaron Eckhart) and instantly falls for his stunning fiance (Amber Heard) in the process.  Kemp's journey takes him through the good and bad of the locale and its denizens, although by the time the credits roll, you'll be left feeling a little empty inside.  The spirit of Thompson is definitely felt throughout the proceedings, but for some reason sadly it just doesn't feel one hundred percent right.  Still though, Depp is wonderful, and the rest of the cast, which also includes Richard Jenkins, Michael Rispoli, and Giovanni Ribisi in a scene-stealing role, are great.  All in all, The Rum Diary is hit and miss, and while it probably may never become the cult classic that Terry Gilliam's take on Fear and Loathing in Las Vegas did, it's still worth your time regardless.

Nancy in Hell is so ridiculous and over the top that it should probably get some sort of award.  A comic so awesome in its badness that you can't help but enjoy it for what it is.  What happens when an ultra-buxom cheerleader winds up in Hell?  Well, that's the story of our heroine Nancy, who finds herself trapped in Hell and trying to escape the horde of demonic forces and undead out to make her into mincemeat.  Nancy also finds herself with a very unlikely ally, and the two seek to escape the confines of the underworld in one big bloody blast.  Written by El Torres, Nancy in Hell is enjoyable for what it is and nothing more, nothing less.  It's a fun ride while it lasts, and the surprising twist and conclusion will leave you genuinely surprised.  The artwork by Juan Jose Ryp (Black Summer, Frank Miller's RoboCop) in the first two issues here is stunning, but the final two issues feature artwork by Antonio Vasquez, which while good, just doesn't match up to Ryp's incredible renderings.  All that aside, Nancy in Hell is a blast, and is well worth your time and attention.

A lost slasher gem from the 80s directed by Scott Spiegel, Intruder is something unique indeed.  What happens when the overnight employees of a local grocery store that's closing down are stalked by a crazed, bloodthirsty killer?  Ridiculous blood-letting that's what!  Though it takes some time to get going, Intruder features some inventive kills (with early effects work from KNB) and even performances from Evil Dead trilogy mastermind Sam Raimi and his brother Ted.  Synapse Films has thankfully released the film in all its uncut gory glory, with a decent amount of special features that will satisfy gore hounds aplenty.  All in all, if you've never seen Intruder but like discovering lost and forgotten horror gems, give it a try.

I'm actually surprised by some of the reviews of Choke Hold here, many reviewers claiming that it falls short of Christa Faust's first Angel Dare book, Money Shot.  While I'll agree with them that Choke Hold doesn't pack the same kind of gut punch that Money Shot does, it is nevertheless a wonderful and enjoyably nasty noir tale.  Former porn star Angel Dare is in witness protection these days, working in a low-rent diner.  One day she comes across a former colleague/flame, and from that point forward it's a barrage of blood, bullets, and bare-knuckle knockouts.  Without giving too much else away, Angel is thrown head first into the world of Mixed Martial Arts fighting, and all beneath all the publicity and glitz, Faust paints almost as sordid a picture of the sport as she did with the pornography industry in Money Shot.  Packing its share of shocks and surprises, Choke Hold is an unapologetic blast.  While Faust doesn't do much to develop Angel's character any further than how she was by the time Money Shot came to a close, the novel still manages to work so well that you won't really pay it too much mind.  All in all, if you dug Money Shot, pick up Choke Hold; you won't regret it.

One thing I've always liked about the PSP is that it has no shortage of import-type (and sometimes just plain weird) games in its library.  Pangya: Fantasy Golf is one such game, offering some fun golf gameplay with an anime-style presentation.  Unlike typical boring golf games, Pangya adds a few tweaks that keep things interesting and fun.  Graphically the game looks great for a PSP game, and is easy and simple to pick up and play.  Even if golf games aren't typically your thing, give Pangya: Fantasy Golf a try, you won't regret it.

Cowboys & Aliens is far from being anything special in the least, but qualifies as an enjoyable popcorn flick that is best to be viewed with your brain at the door.  Daniel Craig plays an amnesiac gunslinger who awakens with a strange and powerful bracelet-type weapon on his wrist, and finds himself a wanted man by the law to boot.  Before you know it, he runs afoul of a nasty Harrison Ford, and eventually the alien beings that the film's title implies.  This Extended Edition provides a stronger story than the theatrical cut (as well as some decent amounts of bloody violence), but despite that though there isn't really anything all that special about the film, other that the draw and appeal of its two stars.  The action sequences are well orchestrated by Iron Man director Jon Favreau, and there are some surprisingly creepy moments to be found as well.  Olivia Wilde provides the requisite eye-candy, and Sam Rockwell, Adam Beach, Clancy Brown, Paul Dano, Walton Goggins, and Keith Carradine are all on board as well.  All in all, if you're looking to a kill a rainy afternoon, you could do a lot worse than Cowboys & Aliens.

A hilarious satire of backwoods horror conventions, Tucker & Dale VS Evil is a smashing good time.  Good natured hillbillies Tucker (Alan Tudyk) and Dale (Tyler Labine) plan on spending some time at Tucker's vacation cabin and do some fishing and work, only to run afoul of a group of college kids that completely have the wrong idea about the situation.  Before you know it, the college kids think Tucker and Dale are inbred hillbillies trying to kill them, and it isn't long before the blood and guts start flying.  What makes Tucker & Dale VS Evil so enjoyable isn't just how it turns the typical horror conventions on its head or flat out makes fun of them, but the delightful chemistry between Labine and Tudyk.  Not to mention the fact that these accident prone teens die in some flat out hysterically gruesome ways.  Also featuring uber-hottie Katrina Bowden as one of the few people here with a functioning brain, Tucker & Dale VS Evil is a hilarious blast that horror fans will no doubt love.

Trent Reznor has come quite a long way.  Forever a fan of his Nine Inch Nails days, Reznor has gone from NIN mastermind to an Oscar winning composer, achieving the feat alongside Atticus Ross for scoring David Fincher's The Social Network.  Now, Reznor and Ross have scored Fincher's American adaptation of The Girl With the Dragon Tattoo, and the result is a beautifully haunting and atmospheric score that will send chills up your spine the whole way through.  This lengthy score is almost hypnotic, and is just simply brilliant.  All this, plus a hard-driving cover of Led Zeppelin's "Immigrant Song" featuring Karen O of the Yeah Yeah Yeahs is just the icing on the cake.  All in all, whether you're a fan of industrial-laced film scores or a fan of Trent Reznor, pick this up.  You won't regret it.

My introduction to Christa Faust, Money Shot is a bona-fide crime noir blast.  Angel Dare is a semi-retired porn star running her own production company and gets convinced to do one last starring feature alongside hot young male star Jesse Black.  Naturally, some very bad things are about to happen.  Left for dead and on the run from the law, Angel now finds herself scratching and fighting her way to get some good old fashioned revenge on everyone involved in turning her life upside down.  Twisty, nasty, and painting an incredibly ugly picture of the porn industry in the process, Money Shot is a treat.  It's everything one could ever want from a neo-noir story, and even though it seems to come apart a little bit by the time the novel winds to a close, Money Shot is a smashing piece of pulp nastiness that deserves your time and attention.  Check it out, and while you're at it, check out Faust's recent novel Choke Hold too, which is surprisingly even better.

What Arkham Asylum did so well, Arkham City takes and runs with it so far that what we have here now isn't just the best Batman game ever, but the best superhero video game ever made.  Once again playing as the Caped Crusader, you find yourself trapped in the middle of the desolate criminal wasteland of Arkham City as it appears every single villain in Batman's extensive rogues gallery is coming out of the woodwork...and they all have their own agendas, and all want a piece of you.  Featuring Joker, Hugo Strange, Harley Quinn, Two-Face, Riddler, Zsasz, Bane, Mr. Freeze, Penguin, Calendar Man, Deadshot, and plenty more besides; you're going to be in for a very long night.  Graphics and gameplay wise, things haven't really changed much from Arkham Asylum, but they didn't really have to.  The gameplay is still smooth and the action elements are wonderful, but it's the ton of side-missions that really stick out.  Playing phone tag with Zsasz, assisting Bane (yes you read that right), figuring out the next targets of Deadshot, and plenty, plenty more besides add so much to the replayability factor that you'll keep coming back.  Add to that the amount of downloadable content, including the oh so fun Catwoman missions, really make Arkham City so spectacular.  All in all, even if you missed out on Arkham Asylum, you have no reason to miss out on Arkham City.  It's the best superhero video game ever made, and you need to play it right now.

When Joe Quesada took over as Marvel EIC, he helped give refreshing takes on stale titles.  While Grant Morrison took on X-Men, the aging and boring mutant militant comic X-Force was given a complete makeover by writer Peter Milligan and Madman artist/creator Mike Allred.  Eventually re-titled X-Statix, the comic revolved around a team of mutant superheroes that were also big time celebrities, and frequently found themselves either dead or dying to boot.  Featuring brilliant and surreal artwork to go along with being absurdly and darkly funny as well as being surprisingly addictive, X-Statix was a treat throughout the remainder of its run, as it found itself eventually cancelled due to low sales.  This gorgeous Omnibus collects Milligan and Allred's complete X-Force/X-Statix run, which is wholeheartedly worth your time if you missed out on it way back when.  All in all, it's a shame that Marvel doesn't have an ongoing X-book that is this entertaining or original anymore, because no X-book around today is even half as good as X-Statix was.  That's right, I said it.

Rayman Origins defines everything that makes platforming games so great.  A tried and true 2-D side-scrolling adventure, you play as either Rayman or his pals and traverse multiple stages; pouncing on enemies, avoiding various spiky hazards, and saving nymphs and assorted creatures along the way.  What makes Rayman Origins so enjoyable is that this is practically flawless platforming action.  Granted there are moments of annoying pitfalls that can usually be found in any platformer, but these are few are far between.  Combine that with the spectacular art design and graphics of the game, along with the catchy soundtrack and some hefty replayability as well, Rayman Origins is simply divine.  All in all, longtime fans of the Rayman franchise, or platforming in general, should definitely pick up Rayman Origins; you won't regret it one bit.

It's been a long time since I've played a pro wrestling game and enjoyed it (think the original WWF Smackdown! for the PS1), so it takes a lot for me to check out any pro wrasslin' game that comes along.  WWE All Stars I found hard to resist though: an arcade-style atmosphere with legendary brawlers like Hulk Hogan, Bret Hart, Ricky Steamboat, Macho Man, Ultimate Warrior, Jake Roberts, and more besides mixing it up with current WWE superstars Randy Orton, John Cena, John Morrison, CM Punk, and others.  The game offers some great graphics and a hefty amount of gameplay modes (along with unlocking more wrestlers too) with the only drawback really being that the control scheme isn't easy to get a hold of when you first get into the game.  Maybe it's because I've stayed away from wrestling games for so long, but it took me a while to get used to it.  Once you do though, you'll have a blast with WWE All Stars.  All in all, if you want an arcade-experience fighting/wrestling game that will give you some nostalgiac moments of joy, give WWE All Stars a try.

Jason Aaron has really made a name for himself over the past couple years.  With runs on Ghost Rider and PunisherMAX, as well as his own series Scalped for Vertigo, Aaron has quickly become one of the top writers in all of comics.  His time on Wolverine has been no different either, proving to be one of the best writers to ever tackle Marvel's mutant posterboy.  This storyarc, Wolverine's Revenge, picks up where Wolverine Goes to Hell left off, as Wolvie finds himself taking on the mysterious group known as the Red Right Hand, and discovering how his past intertwines with them, leading up to an ultimate gut wrencher of a conclusion.  The shocking storyline combined with the excellent artwork here really make this arc a winner, and further cement the fact that Jason Aaron is one of the absolute best writers in the industry today.  All in all, this is the best Wolverine has been in a while, and it deserves your time and attention.

Say what you will about Grant Morrison, but there's no denying that there hasn't been as subversive a comic book writer since Alan Moore first came to fame.  His work on Animal Man, New X-Men, Batman, All Star Superman, and countless others has been celebrated for so long now that it's practically a rule by nature to hold the man in such high regard, and with Supergods, we get a better sense of the mind inside that bald head as he approaches playing around in comic book universes and bending them to his will.  Long time fans of Morrison's work will eat up Supergods with no problem, others though may have a bit of a hard time getting into it, specifically if you're not that much of a Morrison fan or have only read a few snippets of his work (those that panned Final Crisis should proceed with caution).  Personally I love seeing comic book personalities (such as Warren Ellis and Garth Ennis) breaking into the realm of more traditional literature, and Supergods may very well be the best out of them all.  Pick this up.

Jason Aaron's run on PunisherMAX has been something special up until this point, and with this storyarc simply called Frank, Aaron goes overboard and gives us a psychological look at Frank Castle like we haven't had before.  Remember reading Garth Ennis' Born and wishing that it went on just a little bit more after Frank told his family to "hold on tight"?  We get that here, as Frank reminisces about those days after the war in Vietnam ended and he came home, leading up to that fateful day in the park that seemingly birthed The Punisher.  All the while, Frank is in bad shape since his battle with Bullseye, and is recovering in the prison infirmary at Ryker's, and everyone wants to be the guy that put The Punisher down.  Where as in the first two storyarcs, Kingpin and Bullseye, Aaron pulled out all the stops in terms of shocks, Frank is much more introspective and shockingly poignant.  Jason Aaron has truly made Garth Ennis proud.  Steve Dillon provides more great pencilwork as well, solidifying the fact that no one draws The Punisher better.  All in all, Jason Aaron continues to nicely fill the shoes of Garth Ennis, and by the time his run is all wrapped up, who knows...he may go down as the only Punisher writer to stand on his own outside Ennis' shadow.

Marv Wolfman and George Perez's prolific run on The New Teen Titans is, to say it lightly, staggering.  A beloved series from beloved creators, New Teen Titans was something special in its heyday in the 80s, and now Wolfman and Perez return with Games.  Games is something of a time-capsule in a way, considering that it was originally crafted in 1988 as a be all end all to the pair's run on the title, and it was never finished...until now.  Games finds the Titans (Nightwing, Starfire, Cyborg, Changeling, Raven, Jericho, Troia, and Danny Chase) in the middle of a catastrophic showdown with someone known only as the Gamesmaster, but it becomes obvious that things aren't quite as they seem.  King Faraday is thrown into the mix, along with some other players, as things quickly go from bad to worse for everyone involved.  While the artwork of Perez is gorgeous naturally, Wolfman's story is a little lacking and occasionally confusing.  All that aside though, having this proper conclusion to Wolfman and Perez's New Teen Titans run is just plain awesome.

In an age of cruddy, needless remakes coming out seemingly every other week, the fact that the Fright Night remake is surprisingly good is quite refreshing indeed.  The basic premise of the original remains the same, as high schooler Charlie (Anton Yelchin) suspects his neighbor Jerry (Colin Farrell) is a blood-thirsty vampire when denziens of his Vegas suburb begin to go missing.  Things begin to go from bad to worse as Charlie's mother (Toni Collete) and gorgeous girlfriend (Imogen Poots) get caught in the crossfire, leading him to seek out the assistance of horror illusionist Peter Vincent (David Tennant) as things reach a bloody climax.  Alterations to the original film's story aside, this new take on Fright Night works, and delivers the goods for those looking for real vampire thrills in this age of sparkling teenage vamps that take too much care of their hair.  Colin Farrell acts every bit the predator vamp, and the great David "Dr. Who" Tennant steals the whole show here.  While it isn't perfect and leaves a little to be desired (i.e., some of the CGI effects are pretty lame looking), Fright Night is a bloody good time regardless.  All in all, if you're a fan of the original film, check this out, you may find yourself pleasently surprised.

A nearly cancelled gem of a DS game, Sega's Aliens: Infestation is a tough 2-D side scroller that harkens back to the 8 and 16-bit glory days of games like Castlevania and Metroid, only with the Alien license slapped on it.  By all means though, this is a good thing, as Aliens: Infestation is the best game to wield the Alien license in years.  Taking control of a group of colonial marines, you run and gun your way through treacherous corridors and other locations as deadly Xenos look to make you into mince-meat.  You'll also encounter facehuggers, dangerous robots, and other hazards and enemies along the way, while getting to wield franchise standard weapons like the Pulse Rifle and Flamethrower.  While Aliens: Infestation is a great game, let it be known right now that this game is not for lightweight gamers.  There's no regenerating health bar, there's no frequent checkpoints; this is pure 2-D side scrolling action the way we remember it: tough and fun.  The few flaws the game has lie in its difficulty however, including the fact that once you start firing, you're locked in that position and can't turn around to fire at something behind you.  Not to mention that the area layouts can get confusing and you'll do quite a bit of backtracking (which helps hide the fact that this game is actually really short), but other than all that, Aliens: Infestation is a gem.  It's wonderfully animated and surprisingly really creepy with some jump-worthy moments.  That in itself makes Aliens: Infestation worth picking up whether you're a new 3DS owner or have an old DS that needs to have the dust wiped off of it.  All in all, if you want a side scrolling run and gun game for your old DS and love the Alien franchise, by all means pick this up.

Further proving that Jason Aaron is a more than worthy successor to Garth Ennis, the Bullseye storyarc of PunisherMax finds the insane and deadly assassin known as Bullseye taking Frank Castle in his sights.  What develops throughout is one of the bloodiest, disturbing, and just plain brutal examples of a cat and mouse game ever seen in a comic book.  Just like he did with the Kingpin the last time around, Aaron inserts the classic Daredevil villain into Marvel's MAX world and makes him the most terrifying he's ever been.  He gets in Frank's head (and the methods to do so have to be seen to be believed) like no one ever has before, and before its all said and done the Punisher will never be the same.  Steve Dillon provides more of his excellent pencilwork to the proceedings, rounding out the overall package.  All in all, Jason Aaron's PunisherMax is the best treatment the character has gotten since Garth Ennis' prolific run came to an end.  Seriously, you will not find a better take on the Punisher other than Ennis than what Aaron continues to do with the character.

Forget the Stallone flick from the 90s (and possibly even the upcoming new take starring Karl Urban, I've got a bad feeling about it...), this is the one and only Judge Dredd.  One of the most important comic book characters ever, this first collected edition of early Dredd tales is essential reading.  In a lawless mega-metropolis of a future, there aren't any cops, there's Judges.  The toughest and most take-no-prisoners of them all is Joseph Dredd, who never removes his helmet and takes his job uber-seriously.  As previously mentioned by another reviewer, these early Judge Dredd stories that appeared in the British comic magazine 2000 A.D. were a satirical take on typical American Hollywood action hero conventions, but were also surprisingly fun, entertaining, and occasionally endearing.  This first collection of the Case Files doesn't feature the best of Judge Dredd per se', but it sets the stage for the adventures of a legendary comic book character, and one of the most revered antiheroes in comic book history as well.  If all you know of Judge Dredd is that excuse of an adaptation starring Sylvester Stallone, pick up these collections to get the real effect of who Judge Dredd really is.  You won't regret it.

Despite all the negativity surrounding Metallica over the years (most of it deserved), I remained a huge fan throughout my youth.  There's no denying the impact the band has had on the metal genre, bringing it to mainstream audiences like no band ever could before, and in all honesty, no band has really been able to do since.  Acts over the years like Korn, Disturbed, and countless others have achieved great deals of mainstream success, but didn't have either the staying power, or the mix of raw talent and songwriting ability that Metallica had all throughout the 1980s to the late 90s.  Now, here we are.  The most legendary metal band other than Black Sabbath uniting with legendary singer/songwriter Lou Reed to bring us "Lulu"; a collaboration of two distinctly different acts that could either be a smashing success or a complete and utter train wreck.  Well folks, "Lulu" is possibly the biggest train wreck of music I think I've ever heard.  With the Metallica boys in the background and Lou on vocals, "Lulu" is an unimaginitive mess.  Every single track on this album sounds so disjointed and just plain ugly that you'll be plugging your ears from the get-go.  I'm not exaggerating here or kidding either, "Lulu" is just plain horrible.  The real tragedy about this is two legendary acts combining to make this.  It wasn't a match that made sense to begin with, which is kind of what made me look so forward to it in the first place: it was something different.  Well, it is something different alright, it's just plain garbage.  It's a shame too, "Lulu" could have been something that at least warranted a listen for fans of either, or any, music genre.  Instead, this is what we're left with: a gaping black hole on the careers and discography of Metallica and Lou Reed alike.  Avoid.

It's been quite a while since we had a studio album from Anthrax, and even longer since we had one featuring classic vocalist Joey Belladonna leading the way.  With "Worship Music", Belladonna has returned to the fold and is once again voicing the legendary thrash pioneers, and things just couldn't be better.  "Worship Music" is just plain awesome and enjoyable metal that you can't help but love.  Standout tracks like "Earth on Hell", "The Devil You Know", "Fight 'Em Til You Can't", "I'm Alive", and "Judas Priest" are practically perfect, and remind you of the fact that in this day and age of cruddy metal pretending to be hard, the original forefathers of the genre still do it the best (mostly that is, I'm not mentioning anything involving a certain band that starts with the letter "M" and ends with "etallica").  Belladonna himself sounds great, and while I do miss John Bush on vocals, having the band's classic vocalist here just adds to how awesomely enjoyable "Worship Music" ends up being.  All in all, pick this up, you won't regret it.

It took me longer to figure out how to get the battery door back on the remote (it goes on backwards from what it looks like it should) than the entire setup! I connected the HDMI cable from my 32" Samsung TV to the DVD player, inserted a DVD, and we were up and running.Crystal-clear picture, intuitive remote, immediate response to remote commands. The only problem I've noted is occasional slowing during play of library DVD's (and I didn't notice this with my previous Sony DVD player - minus 1 star).

My iPad Mini slid right into the folio and linked up via Bluetooth without a hitch. The Zagg Folio - unlike the ZAGG Slim Book - is only really comfortable used on a flat surface, with the cover propped at the "typing" angle.The keyboard is responsive and intuitive, but lacks the quality feel of the Slim Book keys as well. This is a lower-priced cover, but actually has fewer weak points in the design; I think this will stand up better to regular use. The cover fully encloses the iPad when closed (magnets); it provides good protection in my bag.Right out of the package I prefer the Slim Book, but time will tell whether the Slim Book or the Folio is better able to stand up to daily use.

Wow!This is a game-changer for my iPad Mini which has been a bit idle of late. The Mini fits comfortably into the Case portion of the ZAGG, then pops into the Keyboard, held securely by magnets. Pairing was easy over Bluetooth. It's easy to switch the case from typing to video to book position. There are rubber pads on the case and hinge to prevent slipping.It was completely natural to type with the iPad; the keys were responsive and intuitive, with comfortable spacing. This converts the iPad to a very useful travel companion, micro-laptop, super-efficient email reader and writer. At 1.5 lbs, it fits in my bag with a full keyboard and a touchscreen. It's not quite a full laptop, but it's darn close. I watched several videos on the iPad, without needing to prop it up with a pillow or a book. Great viewing angle.Shortcomings are the poor fit of the case around the "power" end of the iPad; this is sure to break with even moderate use. The case is also heavy, and has a tendency to tip the little apparatus over, especially if it really is on my lap.

I had some heavy duty household washing to do - throw rugs, bedspreads, and towels - when these Arm & Hammer Ultra Power with Oxi-Clean pods arrived.Two pods per giant front HE load, and these heavily-soiled loads came beautifully clean. No need to pretreat, and no lingering scents.I've learned over the years not to use any scented detergents next to my skin, but there is plenty of other laundry in a household; kitchen towels, bath towels, linens for others, throw rugs, curtains, and winter wear. I'm very pleased with the results this detergent gives with the dirtiest wash I can throw at it!!

I've admired these socks at a small local shop, but they didn't have the Balsam colorway that I really liked, lovely greens and violet. When the socks arrived I noticed several things; the toe seams are not smooth, the fit is very loose. and there are several unfinished changes between colors with long hanging threads. Hmm, as a devoted sock knitter, these just don't pass inspection.

After unpacking the Canon MG6820, using the "Cableless Wi-Fi Setup" and the companion iPhone app makes wi-fi setup a breeze.Download the iPhone app onto your phone or iPad. I start the Cableless setup on the printer and followed the prompts: first, I initiated an SSID from the printer, which I logged into from my phone's main controls. I was now on "Canon IJ---" network. Once there, the Canon app on the iPhone prompted me to choose my normal wifi network "IP At My House" and to put in the password for that network...which the phone then sends right back to the printer. Voila! The printer was connected to the network, and I could just hover over the "Add Printer [+]" and see Canon MG---.The Canon MG6820 makes a neat job of connecting to my favorite online service, Evernote. I can see all of my notes to make a printed copy (amazing!), or I can scan a note right into the correct notebook, with the correct title (as long as the title follows arcane DOS labeling rules). Still, it's a vast improvement over, "Scan from Brother Printer" in my Inbox every time.Photos can be read from my smartphone, and printed in sharp, clear color. Ease of printing photos, and connected services are some of the strengths of this printer. Eco settings include automatic duplex in both print and scan, as well as sleep and a reliable wake from sleep. The sleek black exterior looks good on a desktop or bookshelf.

I've used an 18 ounce Hydro Flask for many beverages without problems over the past year or so; it's been invaluable! I thought this 12 ounce flask would be of the same quality as the bottle I'd purchased from a large outdoor retailer.Sadly, I had the experience many other reviewers have noted; the stainless steel interior picked up the flavor of the first batch of fruit-essence tea I put in the flask. Nothing removed the taste; Dawn, hot water, a run through the dishwasher, baking soda...every suggested remedy.I'm puzzled, because I've used my original 18 ounce flask on an extended camping trip - 5 weeks without access to  a proper kitchen - without any unfortunate flavors in the flask. I can only conclude that Hydro Flask has changed the interiors of their bottles, either the brushing or the final treatment of the stainless.

As so often happens, this book arrived just when I needed to hear the wise words of Lodro and Meggan as they write about loving yourself, loving others, falling in love, and leaving a relationship without losing your mind.Lodro is a Buddhist, living in Brooklyn, and Meggan is an Indie mom celebrating the divine feminine. This book is an extended and very enjoyable dialogue between two friends that invited me right into their conversation. The flow between their voices illustrated many points that would have taken long tedious chapters in other books, but here were the natural, gentle waves of talk between friends who enjoy  - but don't share - each others' view on every subject.While I was pondering the direction a relationship was going, these fresh young voices helped me see a clearer path, and I found a peaceful way forward with wisdom.

I've used a regular rice cooker for many years - with Beth Hensberger's The Ultimate Rice Cooker Cookbook - but this has been my first venture into the new fuzzy logic rice cookers. WOW!This rice cooker is a brilliant at cooking my now-preferred brown (Genmai or GABA or 8-grain mix) rice, and having it reading when I get home from work in the evening, or wake in the morning. Every time the rice is fluffy and nutty, just the way I like it, actually cooking perfectly on the white rice setting. Genius!I can saute a few extras using the Quick Cook setting, then hit Reset, and add the rinsed rice, water, and set the cooking time for the actual cooking. Voila, perfect rice pilaf. On the porridge setting, it makes a lovely lentil soup.This is a handsome little unit that doesn't take up much counter space in my tiny kitchen; if I need to move it, there's a convenient handle that is well designed and sturdy. The lid closes like a luxury car door. I'm in a bit of appliance heaven with this rice cooker!

Although the back of the package recommends mixing this 8-Grain 1:4 with white rice, I prefer it 1:1 with Genmai or GABA brown rice as a breakfast rice, or as lovely mixed grain dinner rice. 8-Grain is perfectly balanced in texture and taste, adding both nuttiness and a delicate texture to white, brown, or percentage rice.It is delicious with apples and almond milk (sweet), with soy sauce and sesame oil (savory), or just some steamed vegetables.

Absolutely delicious brown rice, with a delicate flavor, short grain; cooks perfectly in my Zojirushi fuzzy logic rice cooker on the white rice setting with no adjustments.Cold rice is great the next morning with some sliced apple and almond milk, or quickly fried to take to work for lunch.I've been purchasing this at a local Asian food retailer in 4.4# bags; it is still more expensive than regular brown rice, but I'm not feeding a large family :-)

These are just the sort of Vitamin C capsules I've always liked to keep on hand for cold season, though now that I've become a bit more aware of the environment and nutrition, these capsules score high in my book. They are vegetarian, non-GMO, and include bioflavonoids and rose hips.Each capsule is 1gram of vitamin C, with 25mg of rose hips and 25mg bioflavonoids. They are made in the USA from European sourced vitamins. The capsule are completely neutral in taste, made of a vegetarian substitute for gelatin. Three cheers for this winter warrior!!

Canon has introduced several new printers for home/small office use; the PIXMA MG5720 is the most trim-featured model. It has 5 ink tanks, and the lowest resolution DPI, while still including scan, print, and copy.However, it still has simple setup over wi-fi, as well as AirPrint, a high-speed USB connection (cable not included), an LCD (display-only) screen, and 100-sheet capacity for plain paper - which it will duplex print! After simple app setup*, I could easily print from my iPhone and iPad, which keeps photos from falling into a black hole.Solid printer with a good set of basic features in a well-designed package.*Download the iPhone app onto your phone or iPad. I start the Cableless setup on the printer and followed the prompts: first, I initiated an SSID from the printer, which I logged into from my phone's main controls. I was now on "Canon IJ---" network. Once there, the Canon app on the iPhone prompted me to choose my normal wifi network "IP At My House" and to put in the password for that network...which the phone then sends right back to the printer. Voila! The printer was connected to the network, and I could just hover over the "Add Printer [+]" and see Canon MG---.

I really like the sleek black outline of the printer, and the closed output tray (it opens automatically when a print job comes through). Makes this an attractive choice for the top of my very clean bookcase.Easy setup on my Mac network*. Full duplex printing, hallelujah! Absolutely top marks for photo printing, too, assured with the six tank ink setup. Printing is quiet and smooth. It's great to have two drawers for paper; one for plain paper, one for photo. Ink is still in limited distribution, and fairly expensive, so just 4 stars.With this printer, I can print from my iPhone or iPad, using Canon's app.  You could also choose to print from various online sites/applications, such as Facebook, Instagram, and Google CloudPrint, though I didn't test these.Overall, a sleek printer with an updated list of essential functions, implemented with top marks.*Download the iPhone app onto your phone or iPad. I start the Cableless setup on the printer and followed the prompts: first, I initiated an SSID from the printer, which I logged into from my phone's main controls. I was now on "Canon IJ---" network. Once there, the Canon app on the iPhone prompted me to choose my normal wifi network "IP At My House" and to put in the password for that network...which the phone then sends right back to the printer. Voila! The printer was connected to the network, and I could just hover over the "Add Printer [+]" and see Canon MG---.

I've got several small power sticks stashed in my car, my emergency kit, travel kit, for when my phone or iPad run out of power...but the PNY AD10400 is clearly the device I was looking for all along!Now this is what I call a boost! This little pack, about the size of a small backup drive, and a bit on the heavy side as you'd expect for a battery, arrives fully charged. It has one 2.4Ma port and two 1.2Ma ports for charging three devices at the same time. The battery power is displayed on the LCD screen.This is going to be my new travel buddy, replacing the smaller chargers.

Vichy Dermafinish comes in a medium sized squeeze tube, and the shade I received for testing was correct for my skin tone.The foundation is creamy, smooth, and applies easily with fingers or makeup brush, and gives even coverage whether applied in a light, medium, or full layer.Unfortunately, Vichy Dermafinish didn't wear well during the day; on dry patches, it flaked off (ugh - not a problem I ever have with my Bare Minerals Complexion Rescue), and on my cheeks it sank into every pore.The foundation is a physical sunblock, courtesy of titanium dioxide, so it photographs poorly and changes color in different lighting. It also includes dimethicone near the top of it's ingredient list, so it would cause break-outs for me or anyone else sensitive to silicones.If you need the specialized coverage of Vichy Dermablend, you'll love the texture and easy application, as well as the SPF30. For normal coverage needs, there are better options.

Most true HEPA units are fairly large, unlike tiny ineffective desktop units; fortunately, Rowenta's Intense Pure Air is an attractive, neutral white tower.There are 4 stages of filtration - with replacement filters yet to be available in the US - with most filters lasting 1-3 years, again typical of true HEPA systems. There's a regular schedule of filter cleaning to maintain effectiveness.  This unit runs quietly, making a noticeable difference in air quality, and good air circulation.  This is a solid system for allergy sufferers, asthmatics, pet owners, and those bothered by indoor air pollutants.
Easy to tolerate full potency magnesium supplement; does not cause GI upset as so many magnesium supplements do. Excellent alternative to more common formulations.

I've used earlier versions of the PUR pitcher and been very pleased with them, so I was eager to see if this was any sort of an improvement. Turns out, you can improve on the PUR pitcher.The Ultimate Pitcher uses the same reliable filter that gets rid of so many impurities in our municipal water supplies (and I'm truly thankful they are as safe as they are). The documentation also lists many medications that are removed by the filter, and that was new to me; I'm sure I don't need the assortment of hormones and other drugs that are present in today's water.The filter is easier to lock into the upper reservoir than in earlier versions; thank you, PUR! Though the reservoir is small relative to the pitcher's capacity, this keeps the pitcher streamlined. The lid has a convenient opening for filling the reservoir, rather than taking the whole lid off, much more sanitary. A small flap opens to allow the PURified water to flow out. The LED indicator is on the redesigned cover. The handle has been redesigned as well, and is far easier on my hands.The 7-cup size is perfect for the water pitcher I keep upstairs in my bedroom minifridge. No reason to have bad water - or bottled water - when you can have a nice blue pitcher of PUR.

Beautiful clear BPA-free salad jar, just perfect for a salad lunch without the worry of possible breakage. The lid screws down nice and tight, and in one of the best designs I've tried (and it seems like I've tried dozens of containers for salad dressings), the dressing container screws into the bottom of the lid; it's easy to reach, doesn't spill, and keeps the salad fresh until it's time to eat.The clear jar is a nice large 1L, so I can pack a really BIG salad for lunch or dinner, or have enough on a picnic to share. I love the cheerful berry color of the lid, a non-rusting non-BPA plastic with a strong seal. This is a Mason jar substitute - it's got much of the charm, but none of the foibles; it won't shatter, rust, or leak in your bag. As far as reliable, dishwasher safe lunch containers go, the price is right on this one.
Yup, this is the one. The perfect week on the left, and plenty of room on the right for lists or sketches or record-keeping. Start any time, and write in the dates yourself.

After trying several grey and black tones of Pilot Iroshizuku inks, I agree with many others that this is the Perfect Black! I've been using Aurora Black for over a decade, but it's time for something new...and Take-Sumi is a black-no-grey-no-black-no-grey that is just right. In my  extra fine Charcoal Lamy Safari (slealth, really), it is the perfect color combination, and writes like a dream. There are no overtones of blue or green or violet, just mystery.
Beautiful bright pink pen that writes perfectly just out of the box. An EDC pen for me; matches my Vera Bradley pen pouch, and converter holds a good amount of ink.

First quality notebooks in Japanese Tomoe River paper that is wonderful with fountain pen inks, including Pilot Iroshizuku Ink, which does not bleed through with a Lamy Safari extra-fine. The cream paper blends perfectly with other Midori refills.

Outstanding puppet, first quality materials, captivating to both children and adults! I've loved using puppets with children for many years, and found them fun, educational, and easy for children to relate to.This beautiful Snowy Owl puppet - it's a female owl, it turns out - captured the attention of several children I asked to help me with this review, as well as a number of adults who stopped by. Those who were teachers were well-acquainted with Folkmanis puppets and spoke highly of their value in the classroom; I was simply enchanted with their variety, and the obvious attention to detail in their construction. All of this adds up to a very happy puppetry experience, when used by an adult or a child over the age of 6, in the case of this Snowy Owl. It does take two hands to move both the head AND the wings at the same time, though it is quite life-like to move the head, THEN the wings, so it is quite possible to manage the puppet with one hand.Overall, a perfect choice for home or classroom. I'm eager to find more!

I'll join the other 5-star reviewers here in lauding he praises of Nate Swick's Birding For The Curious, an introductory guide that should delight beginners and renew the hearts of experienced birders sharing their hobby with others.In short chapters. Swick covers location, purpose. binoculars, sketching, field guides, types of feeders, observation skills, and so much more.I work in a nature shop, and I'd be thrilled if every backyard or trail birder picked up a copy of this book before branching out. There's a wealth of hobby information, and there are many gently infectious projects.The best possible gift for a new birder, or a family receiving a bird feeder for the holidays.

More charming labels from Avery, my go-to source for top quality inkjet and laser labels for gifts, crafts, and art projects. These labels are a light, smooth grained Kraft paper with good adhesion and great vivid black printing.Highly recommended.

First rate modem that will unlock you from cable Xfinity/Comcast serfdom - at least a little each month - and free you to enjoy great speeds.The modem itself is a handsome piece of hardware, and will look good on a bookshelf, or tucked in among your other serve-ware.I'd used a previous docsis cable modem that required a certain amount of phone purgatory, but I suspect that our provider was getting just as sick of that time sink as we were, and the modem synced up just as Vine reviewer Tarun described. Perfect!It's time to cut part of the cable/internet monopoly, at least, and this is an excellent place to start.

This is my first experience with owning Bose headphones, but I've tried them many times and wished for their noise-canceling on long flights.These around ear headphones arrive with a 1' USB charging cable, and a 3' cable with jacks for direct use. All of this fits neatly in the protective case provided. The headphones charged fully in about 2 hours, and were ready for use. They linked up with my iPhone 6 with no problem - honestly, you don't need any directions, just flip the switch on the headphones to Bluetooth, and they are ready to connect.Controls are easy and intuitive; need to increase volume? Reach up and it's at the back of the right earcup.I won't go all Hz and flowers on you, but the acoustics are what you would expect; robust, enjoyable, unmolested by outside noise. The problem is, after about 20 minutes, you realize your ears are baking inside the synthetic earcups!So, great sound, minus 1 star for the heat.

While others have raved about this sharpener (and I give both the beautiful deep periwinkle plum and the metal construction a 5-star thumbs up) I haven't had the same results. The pencils I use are Faber Castell pencils (standard pencil diameter, hexagonal), and the Desert Song sharpener made hideous gouges in the body of the pencil, while failing to sharpen the pencil at all. I tried everything, reversing direction of sharpening, removing the broken lead to provide a good surface for sharpening. This one is going back.
Good thoughts to incorporate daily. Great gift for fellow travelers on spiritual, recovery, meditaion pathway.

Oh my, all the hype about Roger Tory Peterson's 100th birthday, and the introduction of a revised text on birding...and it is this. What a shame.I looked through this book over and over, thinking that chapters had been removed from my library copy - surely this could not be the complete book? The first section is a brief, extremely short introduction to method of bird identification by its more general characteristics, rather than its specific field markings. After this introduction, the book jumps to an extended section of quizzing that comprises the bulk of the book. It is poorly designed, and the fact that it does not contain many of the bird identifications, it is more irritating than illuminating. Really, what were the editors thinking?Not recommended.

Superb followup - yet delightful standalone - volume to Donald Kroodsma's The Singing Life of Birds: The Art and Science of Listening to Birdsong. Twenty-four familiar birds make their appearance in seasonal chapters that are simply irresistible, each accompanied by sonograms and soundtracks on the CD.I'm an experienced birder, and I found plenty to enchant and enjoy in this rich book.

Absolutely beautiful, absorbing book for a bird lover. Develops a whole new dimension - so often overlooked in traditional guides - that is key in enjoying the birds we enjoy. Donald Kroodsma writes about birds just the way we enjoy them in our yards and forests - with passion, clarity, and just a bit of that bird mania we all share.The next time I'm searching for a gift for an experienced bird-lover, this book and CD combination will be at the top of the list.

I can't say enough good things about FoodSaver's Vacuum Sealer!! I've owned several models, and these 8" rolls of GameSaver bag material are great for shaping the perfect bags for fresh meats (you don't need to have a fresh batch of duck breasts to package, though my hat's off to my DIL's skills for gorgeous duck), and sous vide cooking pouches (my son the chef).Cut off the bag length you need, and seal the bottom end with your vac sealer. Label the bag while it's clean and dry. Put your meat or produce in the bag, and insert the open end into the vac sealer, as per the instructions. Ahh, watch the magic; it never gets old. And neither will your frozen food when it's been properly sealed in a FoodSaver bag. You can also seal dry goods for longer term storage, and travel items to prevent spills. So many uses!

Moorea Seal's The 52 Lists Project is inspiring and beautiful/handsome. The book is divided into four seasons - Winter, Spring, Summer, Fall - and includes 13 weeks of lists covering those seasons. If you were to start the book January 1, you'd start on List 1.I'm diving in on Week 34, "List the things that make you excited," accompanied by facing photos of wind-surfing, and a vintage bicycle (the photography throughout is stunning, and adds to the message of the book, as well as the pure enjoyment of leafing through the pages). At the end of each list there's a Take Action suggestion; for List 34, "You know that feeling of butterflies in your stomach? Make it a goal to achieve that feeling by trying something new and exciting!"Some weeks are more serious, others more light-hearted, most list prompts will get you writing. Great book for you journal basket, or gift for a good friend.

Excellent BPA-free water bottle with a wide spout for ice cubes, and a sturdy straw that screws into the lid. The bottle isn't insulated, so there is be condensation of my 24oz. of ice cold water...but I don't really mind, the bottle has a handy clip built into the cap handle, and it's right there on my day bag where I need it.The spout pops open with a one-handed button press, and closes one-handed, too. There's a simple lock for the spout that will keep it closed, but won't guarantee a leak-proof seal in your bag; Contigo is wonderfully clear about the features of this 5-star basic in the labeling of the product.

There isn't any substitute for the quality of Reynolds Wrap Heavy Duty Foil when you're wrapping foods to grill, lining a freshly cleaned oven or grill, or taking baked goods to a neighbor. Plenty of cheaper foils, but none that will beat the performance of the original and the best!

Poise Impressa Bladder Supports are a disposable soft and flexible pessary, that's fitted at home by the user, inserted like a tampon, and worn for just 8 hours at a time. Bottom line - they work. And today's woman may just be ready for such an over-the-counter solution to bladder leakage.The bladder support comes with complete directions for fitting and use, and the supports are - for an at-home device - remarkably comfortable and effective. They will not take the place of an office-fitted pessary, which can be left in place for extended periods of time without any sensation at all, if it is a truly perfect fit. A pessary fits between a series of anatomical landmarks to prevent bladder leakage, as well as treat other symptoms not discussed in the Poise Impressa literature. The Poise Impressa solely focuses on bladder leakage, and does it quite well, depending on the anatomy of the wearer (as a reviewer of the product, I'm certainly not qualified to comment on the limitations of the product as related to conditions outside its stated use).The bladder support is inserted like a tampon, something 99.9% of women are familiar with. My one recommendation would be to lean over forward (very far forward) during insertion to allow as much space as possible for the bladder support to expand between the aforementioned anatomical landmarks if the first few uses are less than successful. The applicator is removed, and the support expands to put gentle pressure on the structures to allow them to function more normally; no more urinating while coughing, laughing, sneezing, etc.This is an impressive product, and will bring blessed relief to dignified women who are closet tinklers. Follow all cautions on the product. Renew your acquaintance with your GYN if you have any problems. Allow your body to adjust. Lubricate. And enjoy your freedom.

This is a terrific coffee maker for the solo coffee drinker in a household, or at the office. The FlexBrew Programmable makes excellent single cups, from 8 to 14 ounces, using K-cups or fresh grounds. The coffee is plenty hot when it finishes brewing, so adding milk still leaves a great hot cup of coffee.The coffee maker is large (as big as a mixer, as another reviewer's photos show), handsomely designed, holds a generous 44 ounces of water, and has a programmable start to be sure your coffee is ready when you need it.  Fits smaller mugs, large mugs, and (drumroll please!!) has a timer so your single cup is ready when you wake up. Outstanding coffee maker for a solo coffee drinker, with many extra features. One star off for its giant size.

I've been using another top-quality wiper blade on my SUV, so was interested to try this blade on my passenger side, which was in need of a change.Very impressed with both the installation, and the quality of the blade! There's a reason Bosch is known for the quality of its blades. Top notch!

I've had a consistent problem with bird strikes against my north facing sliding glass window over the past year, so I'm very glad to have the opportunity to give these window films a try.The Bird's Eye View films are thick, substantial, with both texture (which act as reflective rings), UV, color, and pattern to warn birds of window glass. They apply to clean windows with the adhesive power of water and their own natural cling - ie, you can reuse, and replace them. Instructions say to apply about every 4", and the package includes 6 decals. I simply put the six decals across my windows in a straight line where there was (sad) evidence of bird strikes.Since applying them, I've seen no more bird strikes, and it's a busy bird mating and fledging season here at the moment, so I think they are doing their job admirably. If it turns out they are not at the proper level, it's easy to move them (they have thick edges, so they are easy to pick up from the windows) to a better location. An advantage for apartment dwellers is that they are applied from the inside. Well done Bird's Eye!

Solid Belkin car charger for my iPhone 6 - NO problems with the latest IOS, no error messages (and I've had them with other cables/chargers, so annoying!). The MIXIT chargers are available in several colors.This latest model has a larger outer ring so the charger won't get swallowed up in your port, and the active/green light is much less bright so less distracting.  It's a full 2.1 amps, so my phone charges quickly, as does my iPad.I've been using Belkin chargers in my car since I got my first iPhone 3, and I find with reasonable care, they generally last as long as the phone. This one has a thinner cable than my last Belkin car charger, but the plug seems quite solid.

This is another new line of Moleskine journals <sigh> featuring such thin paper, I can't even imagine what I could use it with!I've got tiny immaculate writing, and even I'm pressed to find a pen to use on this tissue paper; show through is a real problem.The new open/sewn binding is a very attractive feature, and I hope we see more of this in better quality paper from Moleskine.
Works perfectly in my ROKU 3 to speed up channel loading. Took me quite a while to find the exact, low-level, slow speed card for the job, and this one is the winner!

This braided cable is strong, moderately flexible, and very handy for my car's CD/stereo/iPhone port. Looks great, works great, and spares me from having a much longer cable (neatly tied up) hanging from the USB port. Good fit on the connections. Highly recommended.

This is a terrific car camping bag for the price! It's got just about every feature you could want for your summer adventure, whether you're a 6-footer or a teen heading off to camp.The zippers work. Yes, they work. The layers adjust for cold sleepers, hot sleepers, night temperatures. There's even a hood for really cold nights, and a vent for your feet!This has almost everything, except a color that your preteen daughter will love, and it's heavy and it needs a dust cover that will work without a struggle. For the first, head to the toy/mass market aisle. For the second, you'd need a much more expensive bag to get these features at a lighter weight - with a decent stuff sack.

Used the 30spf version last summer, but now that I've moved to a sunnier climate, I've switched to the 50spf version. Goes on just as quickly, blends down to an invisible finish, stays dry all day without chalkiness or pulling on my fair skin. No greasy shine during day for me.
Great nibs for modern calligraphy, and super price and delivery from Amazon.
Comfy, silky, no-ride-up, and no-droop-down. Excellent fit. Colors remain true in weekly wash, and non-late grips remain firm. Slight irritation from off center front seams with some of my jeans.

There's no doubt that Rodan & Fields skin care regimens work; I swear by one of their revitalizing regimens for discolored, aging skin. And with Rosacea, as well as hormones, there can often be the most annoying blemishes, completely unrelated to age or generally excellent skin care. <sigh>This is where a handy little tube of BP or Salicylic Acid can really work wonders. Applying just a tiny drop to the oncoming blemish does the trick, using this beautifully formulated BP 5% treatment lotion.The scent is light and fresh, application is easy and invisible, and the product washes right off your fingers. No irritation here.I held back two stars because I can't see that this is anything more than two small (< 5ml) drugstore size tubes of BP 5%, dressed up in Proactiv packaging and marketing at a huge markup. They ARE good, so make your own decision.  They just AREN'T magic.

A close friend who has an unreliable beast of a car turned me on to the value of a Schumacher "jump box." My car is perfectly reliable, but I really put her through her paces during a 6-week camping trip across the United States last summer.This Schumacher was invaluable. I could charge my cell phone, charge my laptop, camp on wild land, and know that I would be ok if I needed light, power, or a jump start if I had miscalculated my car battery's capacity.In fact, I think so much of my Schumacher, that when a couple of kids stole it from my car earlier this year (long story), I replaced it with the same model at my own expense. It's that good.

This little vac is outstanding! I've downsized to 100 square feet of living space, so I use several small appliances - and the problem with small things is that they can be underpowered, badly designed, or just toys. Not so with this Shark Rocket!As a test, I used the pet rotating brush (which will not attach to the hose, but must attach directly to the handheld unit) to vacuum my sisal area rug (8 x 12). Slam dunk, it had plenty of power to pick up stray bits of yarn (I'm a knitter), the usual dust and dirt, and my floor looked terrific. The pet rotating brush didn't really get up dust, so I switched out for the hose and passive brush - still plenty of suction - to go over the rest of my room. Amazing clean, and like other reviewers have said, although it may feel a bit awkward at first, I had no sense of hand fatigue after a solid 15 minutes of use. Can't wait to get this baby into my SUV!1. Check the filters - several of mine were folded and incompletely covered their respective openings on arrival.2. When I emptied the canister, plenty of fine particulate fell out, showing the Shark pet rotating/suction head really gets into the fibers to clean.3. Didn't bother these arthritic, cranky hands. YMMV4. Needs a storage container or simple stand for accessories.I like the idea of a reusable shopping bag.5. No costly replacement filters...at least for a while.6. 5 year warranty.Highly recommended

Many years ago - ok decades  - I learned to make tailored shirts for my father, a professor, and for myself. I used the best techniques I knew at the time.Reading David Page Coffin's book was both a trip down memory lane - the many historical examples of beautiful shirts and superb shirt-making - and inspiration for a whole new generation of shirt-makers. Coffin details handsome techniques, and skilled modern shirt-makers throughout this beautifully illustrated book.There are so many variations of collars, cuffs, plackets, and bands, that the ideas are truly limitless. I can't stress enough the beautiful photography, and the excellence of the designs he has included. For the tailor looking for inspiration, this book is your muse.

I tried three different types of pencils in this sharpener, and none of the types were sharpened.The blue pencil (see photo) was gouged about 1 cm above the usual sharpening area, but nothing seemed to happen to the point. The white pencil was ground down to a dull stump. The black Prismacolor wasn't touched at all, in spite of other reviewers' apparent success.Since I use mechanical pencils for all "lead" work, I've been using sharpeners for years with art pencils without trouble. This Bostitch Vertical Battery Sharpener is not even close to the quality of the $3 manual sharpener I keep in my pencil pouch. I'd say pass on this product.

Rich, lightly scented, just the thing for my gardening hands. This is a small tube, perfect to toss in my bag, for travel, or my night table.From the first application, my sorry cuticles and over-worked hands felt softer, smoother. I think this hand cream is a keeper!
This is such a great LED TV, that I've just bought 3 more for the guest rooms in my home. Perfect size, great picture, great price, logical remote, pairs really well with Roku 3.

I've had every Roku from the Roku 1, now having Roku 3's in every guest room. This is the perfect, PERFECT addition to the Roku setup!The adhesive strips attach the Roku-box-holder to the back of my Samsung's (in this case, there is a recessed area on the back of the TV that is perfect), and the 18" HDMI cable makes a tidy connection. Sure beats the poster putty I was using to hold the Roku to the TV stand. Yuck. This is elegant.

Charming patterns for cats in all poses. Patterns would be improved, I think, if charts were included for colorwork, as it is quite tedious to follow written directions for the tabby on the cover. That being said, you couldn't find a better place to adopt-a-kitty than this book!My grandchildren will be getting their first "kitties" straight from this book, as their allergic father isn't going to be getting a real cat any time soon.

Hmmm...the one that arrived at my home is perfect for a guest room, nice and quiet. I wonder if these less expensive Big Ben's (which are really Baby Ben's compared to my more expensive LL Bean Big Ben, now close to $50, $30 when I purchased it) come from different suppliers?At any rate, it's compact at about 3.5", stylish, quiet, and just right on the night table of the guest room. I've bought several, and they've each been the same. Holding back one star to see if they last past the one year mark.

I've tried multiple active cases over the years for multiple iPhones - and this one is rock solid, the best. The case has relatively soft front edges, then turns into a serious locking back that doesn't add much to the sleek iPhone 6. I've got a decorative case I use in my purse, and it takes 3 seconds to pop my iPhone into this case for sports use.On my arm, my phone is totally accessible for music, pacing, tracking my workout, while happily removed from my sweat, or potential injury. The grip on my arm is secure and comfortable.The Annex Quad locks onto the super smart double-adjusting neoprene armband (with soft grip Velcro running its full length), making the smallest measurement 9" inside the armband up to 15-1/2" without stretching the strap. Surely this will fit on a wide variety of arms, wrist to bicep. The case is fairly pricey, but it is part of a system that can be used on your arm, your bike, or your car, each with or without the case; once you've invested in the system, it's easy to add the various mounts.

Outstanding information for every aspect of Social Security planning - retirement at various ages, benefits for widow/ers, children, and the disabled. Extensive charts, tips, and guidelines make this very confusing topic seem clear and accessible.Laid out like all Dummies guides, so the format is easy to navigate. Each page is broken up into many different kinds of information bites so that I didn't get bored reading about a government agency! There were tips in here that may save me tens of thousands of dollars --- but I wouldn't have found out about them until way too late. I'm so glad I picked up this book at this point (10 years or so until retirement) to get an idea of how I should begin to think about Social Security and my retirement.Packed full of retirement that is invaluable for anyone - from a parent of a severely disabled child, to a young widow/er, to an adult newly diagnosed with a catastrophic illness, to a "regular retiree," this book is likely to have information that will help guide the reader through the Social Security maze, making it much less of a puzzle.

My Little Pony goes punk little girl...perfect for a young friend! This little charmer has fishnet tights, a safety pin earring and a mohawk, not to mention the most amazing make-up, and a guitar-shaped tiny tote that she carries. Her shoes are spiked, she has extra clip in hair, wings, bracelet, and a purse.If you haven't seen a MLP doll in a while (like me), you'll be stunned by this little rockin' chick!!

Yes, please! Four pounds of chocolate and peanut butter goodness on my doorstep, perfect for eating, sharing with friends, and baking projects.The flavor is fresher than I remember - but it's been a while since I've had the miniatures - and there's nothing quite like the distinct, excellent chocolate, and the authentic peanut butter flavor. Doubly good as frozen bites. And doubly good baked into brownies, blondie bars, and PB s'more bars.This bag is huge! It's the party bag...it's the bag you really want. Really!

I lovelovelove the electronic view finder! This is the first camera I've used since switching to digital that offers this feature, and I've really missed it - bright sun that washes out the LCD, and a lifetime's habit of checking the viewfinder, have left me wishing for this feature on my EDC digital cameras (quite a number of Panasonic Lumixes, Canons, Nikons, and a Casio). In this case, the viewfinder is electronic, so it is an accurate reflection of the LCD screen, a bit of an optical illusion that in the end, will give me a better idea of what I'm shooting.There are the usual choices of Auto, Scene, and the preferential modes, as well as superb video. The zoom is outstanding (and you can set the ZS50 to remember the zoom setting, very helpful when birding), as well as the macro; the Leica lens is housed in a lightweight matte-painted metal body that at first nonplussed me, but captured me with its weight and balance, housing an outstanding lens at this price. In addition, Panasonic made the decision to charge the battery in camera with a micro-USB cable that ends with a - wait for it - USB connector! Yes, it slips into the Panasonic charging block (marked 5v, 800mA), and your laptop, but I suspect it may be far easier to charge on the road than my previous camera batteries.Then there's the wi-fi! Panasonic has added a power-hungry feature (but remember the easy charging) that I'm going to love when traveling. Knowing I can upload my photos directly from the camera to a cloud service, my computer, or my phone is reassuring, and one less step. Again, this feature is a step up from the cameras I've used in the past, many of them predecessors of this Lumix.Delighted with the quality of the photos, both zoom  and macro, as well as a recent holiday with family. This Lumix is a winner.

I've been a fan - ok, total addict - of the Brother P-Touch labeler since it came to the home market. Some of the labelers are easier to use than others, but I've had a trusty labeler and tapes in my desk for years. I thought it would be great to try out a wireless labeler.Other reviewers mentioned the difficulty in setting up the wireless connection, so I went directly to Brother for the latest Mac OS X 10.10.x drivers and held my breath; the installation, with the included USB cable - directing the software to choose wireless as the preferred connection ** while connected by USB ** - worked like a charm. My MacBook Air 13" was able to find the PTP750W on the network right away.Here's where a glitch set in. I opened the PTouch Editor software, and chose to use a prepared template, and it quit. I tried not using a template, it quit. Restarted, it quit. After multiple tries, I was able to close the Template Chooser, and use the software to print labels. The PTouch Editor can detect the label in the printer, and sets up a box for text. Piece of cake to type in text and numbers, format and print. Barcodes, QR codes, and address book are all available from the task bar.I was able to use my iPhone and Brother iPrint & Label App to successfully test the label printer, too. It offers a simplified menu of options that includes barcode printing (multiple types), QR codes, multiple templates, photo labels, and the ability to save labels. Even this simple label app offers dozens of fonts and features, automatic label detection, and multi-line printing. It doesn't offer access to your contacts.

Great for everyday food storage; easy to use slider that doesn't leak in the fridge, or let in/out food smells.I also use these for so many other household uses - travel, knitting projects, knitting needle storage, keeping notecards and stamps clean in my travel bag, and about 100 other uses. Coupons in the car, snacks for a child, quick first aid kit, handyman kit of mini adhesives and cable ties, keeping a paintbrush fresh overnight...definitely, 100 uses.
Installed without a hitch in the ceiling of my den, and is perfect for any of my exercises requiring a pull up bar. Rock solid construction; follow instructions for totally secure installation.

Perfect fit for my new Queen memory foam mattress, great protection. The fabric is nice and soft, without any plastic feel or crinkly sound. Once the bed was made up, I couldn't even tell there was a protective mattress cover on the bed.This is a luxurious protective mattress cover that works two ways. One, it protects the sleeper from allergens that develop over time in normal clean beds. Two, it protects the mattress from everyday accidents (surely I'm not the only one who enjoys my morning cup of coffee at the crack of dawn in bed while the house is quiet). This top-notch Perlux covers all the bases without separating me from the lovely modern mattress I've come to enjoy!

It's been years since I picked up a Bible study like this, but my interest was caught by the title Anonymous.This is beautifully written, food for a hungry soul, and beautifully laid out on the large pages. Sound theology and good writing draw out hidden women of the Bible. You'll be glad you picked up this study for yourself or for a group.

Either I received a defective product or it is just garbage .  The adhesive protector would not remove. In the fact the starter sticker on top broke.  Seller listed as premium, which is completely false.  Tried to get the protector off the sticky side without the starter tab but I ended up cracking this cheaply made protector.  I do not like wasting money, which is exactly what I did.

So far so good.  I have been running this switch for about 1 month now.  It replaced my 8 port / 4 port POE switch from TP-Link.  While the TP-LInk has worked well, the Linksys has allowed me to isolated my security cameras on their own VLAN.Currently I am running 3 POE cameras and I have noticed the difference of not impacting the rest of my home network. With the unmanaged switch there was a noticeable lag at times when all cameras were recording to my NVR.While the interface is advanced it is still easy to use and work with.  I highly recommend to go through the user guide if plan to use a separate VLAN.  There are other areas that could be isolated like voice.  My use is with POE security cameras.I will update my review as I get more use and if my opinion changes

We bought 4 of these bottles for the school year because our daughters really wanted them.  Should have just bought Contigo bottles from the start.Not even one month into the school gear and all 4 have broken.  The plastic breaks away from the lid with little effort.  You are left with the silver liner.Do not buy these cheap water bottles

Epson is trying to change the printer landscape in the U.S.  Pay more for the printer but less for the ink.  I am a fan of this idea; however, it is too early to know if this will take off and if the printer can really save you money in two years.  If you do not do a large amount of printing then it will be hard for you to recoup the costs in two years.I have small concern around the warranty and its length.  The warranty on the ET-4550 from the date of purchase is one year or 50,000 sheets. If you register the printer you get an extra year but the sheets remain at 50,000.  Not sure how many people would hit the 50,000 sheets in two years but it is something to be aware of.  If you are paying that much more for the printer I would have liked to see a warranty in the 3 to 5 years.  Having a $100 printer fail just outside of the warranty period is easier to deal with than a $500 printer, I have had this printer for about month now and these are my initial thoughts and impressions.- Ink FillingEven with taking my time, I still spilt some black ink.  Make sure you have something under the ink tanks prior to filling.Once filled, it takes around 20 minutes for the printer to have the internal ink cartridges ready.- SetupSetup on my wireless network was quick.  Printer found my network and I connected the printer.I downloaded the latest drivers from Epson’s website rather using the CD that came with the printer.  Drivers installed and located the printer on my network- Print SpeedThis printer is quick but not as fast as my Epson workforce 845 I have.- ColorsThe color prints on this printer are much more muted than those from the workforce.  This is a negative for me, I prefer the colors to be more vibrant.  I would not even consider trying a photo on this printer.  (This printer is not really made for printing photos)- Cloud OptionsI was already using the Epson Connect feature prior to this printer.  Adding this printer to my account was an easy process.It is too early for me to recommend this printer over the normal cartridge based printer.  As I have more time with the printer I will update my recommendation.  My rating is 3 1/2 stars.  (Warranty length concerns and the colors are muted)If you have questions, please add them to the comments field.

This IR Thermometer does exactly what the documentation stated.  Provides an approximate temperature of an external source.  I have used this and my other IR Thermometer mostly for checking temperatures on the grill.  Distance has the greatest impact on the reading of the temperature.  There are other IR Thermometer that have a greater range on temperatures so make sure understand how plan to use the IR Thermometer and of the if range is big enough.If you are thinking purchasing an IR Thermometer, personally I would recommend looking at some of the lower cost one.  They will more than likely meet your needs.

This does come with other attachments and can use it to clean your but the primary purpose is the mattress. This Dyson comes with a special mattress attachment to get the dust and must mites out of the mattress.Prior to using the vacuum I fully charged it.  It did arrive with a charge.  Stated time to charge is 3.5.  I did not test to verify that claim because I let charge over night.I was able to clean a queen, full, and part of a twin mattress on one charge.  We have covers on all our mattresses.  Even with the covers there was still a fair amount of dust on the mattresses.My only negative is the battery. If you use the max mode to get even better cleaning you can complete one mattress before the need to recharge.
