Don't get me wrong, it is still fun, but it isn't too different from other games you might have played before -like UNO.  Sure it has some variations -it has more "special" cards, and some rule twists, but it is along the same lines.  If you hate UNO you probably won't like this game, and if you like it, you probably will.That said, I thought it was fun.  I did have one gripe, however... the cards are really small -smaller than a normal deck of cards.  It is obvious that the makers intend for you to purchase another set so that you can play it with more people, because the insert in the box has two holes, and the entire deck only fills one of the two cavities.  I don't have a problem with the smaller size, per se, but I do have a problem with a huge box which actually takes two decks to fill up.  I much rather would have had a box that was slightly larger than the card deck so that I could put it in my pocket.  Instead, I am stuck with a large rectangular box that reminds me of opening a bag of chips only to find out that two thirds of the bag was air...Okay, enough nitpicking -still a fun game, though better, I think, with three players (rather than two).

I like these bags.  I've been burned when I've purchased bags OTHER than Ziploc or Hefty, and there is a reason for it.  I really do believe the quality of these bags is slightly superior to generic store brands.  It only takes a few tears or failures with thinner bags, or ones with weak zippers to make you swear off the low end bags forever.First off, these bags are NOT freezer bags... if you want freezer bags you'll have to purchase something else.  Will they work? Sure, but the freezer bags are more durable and are more likely to keep food fresh that these are.What I liked about these bags.  They have a zipper -not a necessity for me, but a "nicety".  Sometimes you don't want to deal with trying to make a seal -especially with the cheaper store bags which may not even have a "yellow and blue make green" locking guide.  These however, are pretty foolproof.  The zipper is easy to use, and the slight bumps in the zipper cause a slight zipping noise.  It also claims that you know it is done when it "clicks" at the end.  This is a slight exaggeration.  Yes, there is the TINIEST click at the end,  but you have to listen very carefully and even then you may not be sure that you heard it.One slightly obvious but appreciated feature is that the bags have "open" and "closed" with errors pointing to the correct side.  This is a nice touch because sometimes you can't immediately tell if you've zipped the bag open or shut.The bag also has a white area (like most bags) in which you can write with permanent marker, and easily read it.Finally, and most importantly, for a zipper bag, this provides a good seal.  I filled the bag with water and hung it upside down for an hour and I saw no leakage.  At best I thought I might see a slight drip, reinforcing my presupposition that these bags are best for non liquids, but they really seemed to do the job well.  I've used them for a week now and have no complaints, with the slight exception that if I were trying to be frugal I'd avoid these and get the non-zippered bags, instead.Recommended.

Although not a brand I'd personally tried before, I have to say I was pleasantly surprised with this Curel product.  I like to use lotion on my face after a shower and I have sometimes been disappointed by "fragrance free" lotion products before.  Once I tried something that claimed to be fragrance free, or something like that, but not quite that exact language.  I was then disappointed by the scent -yes, it still had an odor, even though nothing artificial had been added.  And, since it was used on my face, it was very obvious and I had to smell it until it was completely absorbed.I am happy to say, though, that with this product there was no scent at all.  Very nice.What else can I say? Well, it claimed to be non-greasy, and after using it for a couple of weeks I have to agree.  I've had no clogged pores, or reaction, or anything that I didn't like.It also seems to absorb quickly.  Ever tried a lotion that you need to wait a few minutes before touching skin that you've used it on? This is not it.  After rubbing it in you don't have to wait long before the opportunity to rub it off goes away while it is completely absorbed.  I have a more "specialty" lotion which takes forever to absorb, and I don't like it as much as this for that very reason.There was nothing about this product I did not like.  It worked well, the dispenser did its job nicely, it wasn't greasy, and there was no odor.  I can't think of anything else I'd need to look for, in a product at this price point.  Recommended.

When I first tried this monitor I was shocked to see all the bad reviews.  I had used it for a couple of days and had no issues -in fact, I pretty much liked it! Then I realized that in my haste to get cracking on this thing I didn't bother using the WIFI feature, I just got it going out of the box, and used it with only the included hardware... and when I did that, I had no issues.But when I got down to it and followed the instructions to use the monitor with my phone I was sorely disappointed.  IT... DID... NOT... WORK... For those of you who have struggled with setting up routers or yelled at your computer or phone when you are trying to configure something that is just out of your knowledge zone, then you'll understand my frustration.  I am a tech savvy guy, and I followed all the instructions to a T -and everything seemed to go to plan, until it didn't.Here's how it went down: download app (check!), register on app with name, email and password (annoying, but check!), scan QR code on back of monitor (very nice! advanced tech at work here...), now within the app find your home network (check!), and now type your home network password (ugh, I have to dig that up again? fine...), now go into your phone settings and pick the monitor's "Summer WIFI" network (ugh, I have to change my phone WIFI to the monitor WIFI? does this mean I have to change it every time I don't want to look at the monitor and browse the web using my home network? what a hassle, but ok), ooh look, it says it is connected! now go back to the app and it fully loads and says... uh oh, not connected. What??? then I spent 15 minutes going back into my phone settings, troubleshooting, and trying to find the issue.  The "Summer WIFI" network kept appearing and disappearing, and then it was gone for good.  It didn't appear again, so I pulled the plug and deleted the app. Too much hassle.  Thank goodness I don't need the WIFI function, or I'd be returning the product.So I say to you -DO NOT BUY THIS IF YOU WANT THE WIFI UNLESS YOU READ A BUNCH OF REVIEWS AND SEE WHAT PEOPLE SAY THE ISSUES ARE, AND ARE STILL COMFORTABLE GIVING IT A SHOT.  I would NOT buy it if you want the WIFI function, unless you are ok with returning it.Will it work for you? who knows? what phone do you have? (I have an iPhone 6)... what internet do you have? (I have FIOS)... was my problem related to either of those? was it because of a defective monitor? was it just a blip in the WIFI? who knows... Too much hassle for me, and since I don't need the WIFI it wasn't worth the stress of taking time away from my children to deal with it.BUT, and this is a big BUT. If you really don't care about the WIFI, or if a newer model of the camera seems to fix the WIFI issue and people love it again, OR if you got it as a gift, THEN and only then I like the camera a lot.Unlike the two other similarly priced cameras I have, this one allows you to move the camera around with the handheld remote/monitor.  This is a VERY nice feature.It also has a belt clip, which my other cameras lacked, and makes it easy to walk around with in the house if you have your hands full.It also has an in room temperature sensor (which only one of my other cameras has, and which I like).  My house is old and has hot and cold areas so it was useful information to have.It also is very easy to understand -the buttons have words on them, and the plugs have pictures on them! (this was AWESOME; you can't get the wall plugs confused because one has a drawing of the camera on it, and one has a drawing of the monitor on it).There is a battery indicator on it, which is helpful.  It also beeps when the battery gets low (so you don't sleep through the night and have your monitor turn off because the battery runs out and you didn't realize it wasn't plugged in).You also have a switch on the camera which allows you to turn off the green light ring on the camera, to make it less visible at night -this is a nice touch, as it won't be visible to your child.I thought the picture quality was good, too.  (Keep in mind, though, that I am basing this off of the camera hardware, and no WIFI connection.  I bet a lot of complaints have to do with poor streaming quality, which you avoid if you are avoiding the WIFI mode.)And finally, the two way intercom feature has a nicer and less robotic sound than my other monitors.All in all, if this monitor/camera package were not WIFI enabled (and the price were a little lower, to be comparable to non-WIFI enabled monitors) I would actually consider giving this item 5 stars, but because the main selling point of this monitor is the WIFI, and because my WIFI mode success rate over the course of one hour of setup and troubleshooting was 0%, my opinion of this product declines significantly.

I previously purchased a much cheaper “Scotch Thermal Laminator 2 Roller System (TL901)” a few years ago, and have been using it off and on.  It laminates up to 9 inches wide, and pouches of up to 5 ml thick.  I never had any problems with it, but sometimes would have to laminate objects twice to make sure that it was done right.  So is getting Fellowes Saturn3i Laminator at FOUR times the cost worth it? It depends.  Do you want an entry level car? Or do you want a luxury sedan? Both can be right for you, for different reasons.PROS:+++ REALLY QUICK TO START.  The Saturn3i only took 50 seconds to warm up.  I was impressed.  My other laminator took up to five minutes to heat up and only had a red light indicator come on when ready.  THIS one, however, beeps as soon as it is ready to go.  Nice.+++ VERY SIMPLE TO USE.  There is a wire guide on the back to keep the laminated object straight, and there is a simple to use lever to remove any stuck items.  You cannot miss understanding what thickness you want to laminate with the four simple buttons on the front –each with a size indicated, or cold lamination.  (On the other hand, my cheaper laminator had the same items –a wire guide, a lever to remove stuck sheets, and a toggle switch for each lamination width.)+++ THIS WILL LAMINATE LARGE OBJECTS UP TO 12.5 INCHES WIDE.  This is a key differentiator over other laminators I have seen.  If you really want to laminate large objects, then this is the product to get.  If you don’t have any particular plan to laminate large objects DO NOT BUY THIS VERSION OF THE LAMINATOR… IT IS HUGE.  Buy the smaller version of the same brand of laminator instead.  (I have to say, though, unlike with my smaller laminator, I am actually thinking about additional things to laminate… Looking through some ideas I see I could almost make mini posters, or custom placemats for my kids… it really does open up some possibilities.)+ WILL LAMINATE MULTIPLE THICKNESSES.  This laminator will do 3ml, 4 ml, or 5ml sheets.  (My cheaper laminator would only do 3ml or 5ml sheets.  Is this a big deal? No.  I have no problem choosing either 3 or 5 ml, but the fact that there is more choice is not a bad thing.)NEUTRAL:(o) THIS LAMINATOR IS VERY LONG.  It is bigger than I thought but since the whole purpose of this beast is to laminate larger than normal paper size, this is neither a positive or a negative.  Just be aware.CONS:-- VERY EXPENSIVE.  This is not an inherent criticism of the product; you pay for quality, and my damaged product* aside, this product appears to be “quality”.  My point, though, is that although this is clearly a quality product, you can buy a laminator that does many of the same things, albeit more slowly, at  the price.*Note: When I took my laminator out of the package I noticed that there was a small object loose inside the main body of the mechanism which rattles around whenever I turned it around or flipped it upside down.  (As there is no way to easily open the item I have to ignore it.)  It doesn’t APPEAR to have affected performance or safety, but it worries me that this occurred… I imagine the company wouldn’t have spent money on this internal part if it weren’t necessary.Final thoughts.  If I were to have to purchase a laminator for my personal use, I probably would not purchase this.  I would purchase the much cheaper model.  However, if I truly thought I’d laminate a few objects a month (instead of a few objects a year), or if I were a home crafter and really wanted to use this seriously or professionally, I ABSOLUTELY would purchase this laminator.  It does lamination very quickly and easily, and it accepts VERY large objects for lamination.  Recommended.

I don’t currently suffer from either, but I can absolutely see where this would be a godsend in those cases.  The amount of pressure you need to apply is way less with these shears (when cutting thick branches) than that is needed for the more traditional Fiskars shears.  However, the hand motion required is slightly awkward, it is for right handed users only, and it is more difficult to use for tiny hands (since the shears open wider than usual due to the gear mechanism operation).PROS:+++ BLADE IS SUPERB.  It is thick, rust resistant, and coated with a slick low friction coating.  There is not much to improve on here.  Based on this alone I would consider any of their bladed products.+++ REQUIRES VERY LITTLE PRESSURE TO USE.  Though you have to squeeze through a larger range of motion, the rolling gear mechanism allows you to get great mechanical advantage –especially when cutting through larger branches.+++ HAS A LIFETIME WARRANTY.  This is critical when you beat the heck out of the shears outside and get it exposed to the elements, oils, and grit.  I like knowing that if I use it REALISTICALLY (and not in some sterile test environment where the tool is cleaned perfectly after use) that it will last.++ EXCELLENT CONSTRUCTION.  It feels very solid.  It is lighter than older models because there is more plastic, but I didn’t find that this degraded the overall quality of the item.++ EASY TO USE SAFETY LOCK.  Unlock some more hard to reach tiny metal blade locks on the sides of older shears, this lock is on top, easy to see, and easy to use.  You can open and shut it with your thumb instead of your index finger, and it will ensure you don’t cut yourself while in transit.CONS:-- THE CUTTING PROCESS IS A LITTLE AWKWARD. The bottom of the blade handle basically spins and rolls towards the top of the handle when you close it.  This makes it a slightly awkward motion to close the blade.  I didn’t like it, but I imagine if I had arthritis I would LOVE it, because the unusual motion would be eminently preferable over hand or joint pain.-- MIGHT BE DIFFICULT FOR SMALL HANDS.  If you have very small hands you might find the range of motion to be a little larger than you are used to.  If this is the case I recommend trying this out in a gardening supply shop before purchasing.- CAN ONLY BE USED RIGHT HANDED.  Though not a problem for a righty like me, I thought it should be pointed out.  The way the gears work it is awkward to use in your left hand.Overall this is a well-crafted instrument.  Though I wasn’t crazy about the gear mechanism making opening and closing the blade awkward (for me), I respect that for certain users of this tool, the benefit will far outweigh the awkwardness.  Without hand or joint pain, however, I’d recommend considering the more traditional shears, while topping them off with the Fiskars 32-Inch PowerGear Bypass Lopper which I recommend highly for the larger jobs.

I currently use a waiter style corkscrew to open my wines, though I have used many different styles in the past (air pressure injectors, a battery powered corkscrew, the traditional metal screw with two arms that are manually lifted, etc...)  Overall this one performs superbly, but is overly bulky, and has pieces to lose.PROS:+++ VERY EASY TO USE.  I find that this corkscrew is intuitive and requires very little pressure to open.  I was impressed at the ease of use, and would recommend this feature of the corkscrew highly.++ QUALITY MATERIALS & NICE FIT AND FINISH.  The product appendages feel clean and smooth, and pleasant to hold.  (Very much like the "OXO" branded products.)NEUTRAL:It comes with a large plastic case, a replacement corkscrew (why? is it so flimsy that it will break? It doesn't look any different from the corkscrew already installed...) and a foil cutter. (I wish they could have just built that in… Who uses this? It is so tiny if not in the case it will just get pushed to the back of the drawer.  I’ll probably just use the tip of a knife instead.)CONS:-- IT IS TOO BULKY FOR ME.  I only have dedicated horizontal drawer space and this contraption really needs to take valuable space vertically because you need to keep the case to hold the corkscrew and the extra pieces which would otherwise soon get lost.  (You really can't just keep the spare corkscrew loose in a drawer -you'll poke yourself or puncture things...)  Unlike some other levered corkscrews this cannot be compressed any tighter than you see in the product picture.  It really is wide, and it makes it awkward to store unless you use the plastic case -which is not appealing for me.  Realistically I would put it sideways in a drawer and just toss out the case, the spare corkscrew, and the foil cutter.- THE CORKSCREW POPPED OFF ONCE DURING USE.  The first time I used it and then ejected the cork the corkscrew apparently was loose and popped off the top and fell on the floor.  It wasn’t broken but I had to put it back on, and rescrew on the bolt.  This was easy to do, but I don’t know why it occurred, and it did not happen the next few times I used the contraption, so I’ll put it down to “first use blues” from the factory.  (This probably wouldn’t have happened if they didn’t design the corkscrew to be replaced.  In fact, I would rather that they would have made it permanent.  If the corkscrew snaps you are probably just going to buy a whole new product, I know I would!)Overall, if you are not at all concerned about the storage of this product, and want something that is easy to use, or if you hate other corkscrews due to the hand pressure you have to use then this is a wonderful product.  I would highly recommend it to people who have limited hand strength or who don’t like fighting a cork in a really tight cork fit.  For me, though, I’ll probably stick to the waiter style one I currently use.  (For my wife, I’ll probably keep this in a bottom cupboard somewhere, if she finds the other corkscrew too difficult to use.  But why is she drinking wine without me? Where am I????)

I was impressed by the case/keyboard.  It converts the iPad Air 2 into a laptop-"lite" device pretty seamlessly.  I say "lite" because it really still isn't a laptop.  Without a mouse or a touchpad it really is only a ‘jacked up iPad’ that is very convenient on the road.  This is not a complaint, because there are laptops that act like, well, laptops, but I didn't want a laptop, only an iPad, with the occasional ability to help with some serious typing when I am traveling.  That said, this really fits the bill well.  The case is slim, it is light, it is sturdy and well designed, and it does what I needed it to do -let me type more easily.The biggest drawback to me with this product was mostly psychological.  It makes the iPad 2 Air more like the original iPad, because it increases the size of the iPad.  (Kind of like when you first got your super slim iPhone but then had to put a case on it after dropping it and cracking the glass… Your iPhone was now protected, but not as slim as it used to be.) Not a criticism, but realize that you are reducing the convenience of size (super slim design), and trading it with a convenience of use (ease of typing).Anyway, on to functionality… The keys on the keyboard have a nice feel to them -they don't feel rickety or cheap.  Yes it isn't a FULL keyboard, as the function keys are doubled (instead of having dedicated keys) but I don't see how they could have optimized the keys much better given the space footprint available.It also has strong magnets embedded in the case which allow you to change the display view of your screen, though none are really drastically different from the other.  (Still, it's better than no choice at all!)Additionally, I found that there is no way to swivel the iPad in the case to obtain portrait mode -which, from a typing perspective, makes sense, though I was a little disappointed.  But, this isn't really meant to be a stand, but a typing facilitator, and the wide iPad screen (since it is so small horizontally, when in portrait mode) really isn't optimized to work that way.  (So, if this really matters to you, consider other cases with this flexibility.)One thing I really liked, though, was the ease of being able to flip the keyboard under the iPad, if you didn't want to disconnect it, but wanted to use it without the keyboard temporarily.Finally, the keyboard comes with a micro-USB for charging, and claims to hold a charge for 6 months.  As the keys are not backlit there (apparently) is very little power consumption, and this keyboard is very energy frugal.  I like how it is an auto-turn on/off keyboard; no struggling to find the power switch or to connect/disconnect the WiFi connection.  Nice touch! Oh, one more thing, apparently Belkin actually sells a more premium version of this keyboard [called "PRO"] with BACKLIT KEYS and a few other differentiators, so consider that one as well, if the lack of backlighting matters to you.

This is a very â€œcheapâ€ piece of furniture, but is rather expensive for the quality of the product you receive.  DEFINITELY not heirloom quality, and something Iâ€™d probably just give away or toss in the trash if I were moving, and my kids were a little older, because I am sure it will get scratched, and banged up, and it will not wear well.  (Now, if this were made of plywood, it would easily be double the cost, but worth itâ€¦)It is engineered wood, which means it is terribly heavy, and made of ground up scrap wood which is glued together.  The glue used to bind the wood shards typically also has the potential to â€œoff gasâ€ fumes, but I donâ€™t know enough about the materials and process to speak authoritatively on that.  (Google â€œoffgassingâ€ for more information.)Yes, you can buy a nicer product from Ikea (though youâ€™d have to pay an additional $75 to get it delivered, but it might actually be real wood.)  What you are buying here, though, is something that (if not damaged during shipping or assembly) looks nicer that it is.  (And since it is so heavy Iâ€™d bet that $50 of the cost of the item was probably tied up in the shipping costs.  That makes more sense to me why this would top $200.)Aside from the fact that the â€œwoodâ€ is the cheapest possible wood, two other things reduce the effectiveness of the product in my eyes.  1) the backing is really thin hard cardboard.  I mean, I know that the backing is supposed to be pressed board or something like that, but this may be the thinnest backing I have seen.  2) The instructions, though visual, are pretty sloppy.  Yes there are pictures (and this is a great help) but it is clear there wasnâ€™t someone from the â€œApple Design Teamâ€ working on making these user friendly.  Label the parts more clearly.  Make the labels more easy to peel off.  Label all the parts like Ikea doesâ€¦One note: when making this product solo I recommend the following: take a few pieces out of box to reduce the weight if you are moving it around the house before installation.  Otherwise you risk banging it against the floor or walls, and raise the risk of crushing edges or scratching pieces.  (This engineered wood is pretty fragile, and has a low tensile strength.)  Then, treat each piece like it is made of glass -very delicately! If possible, place them individually on a carpet so they donâ€™t scratch other pieces with their sharp edges, or get scratched by anything on the floor.Overall I would be very leery of ordering this heavy item for delivery, because if it is dropped on the corner pieces WILL crush.  I canâ€™t recommend this product for that primary reason, but Iâ€™ll say that if yours arrives undamaged --not always a given due to the weight, and the fragility of the materials- and if you patiently are able to put it together in the room of final destination, then it may be of use to you.  If you are able to do this, then I give the furniture a 3 star rating (for its overall LOOK, and for the convenience of door to door shipping at no added cost.)I, however, will only buy engineered wood in person so I can ensure it isn't damaged, rather than dealing with a return or replacement.

What first caught my eye was the rather strange advertising: "The best diapers for dancing".  Honestly, that took me by surprise because I'd never heard of the brand before.  Anyway, after realizing that it wasn't a joke I tried them out with my toddler and here is what I found.Unlike the Pampers version I usually prefer, there is no wetness indicator on these.  Not a big deal for a walking child, who cares much less about a wet diaper, but something I am a real fan of for an infant. (-1)No special "branding" in particular.  Though I (and my child) really didn't care about "Elmo" on the diaper for the first year, let me tell you, he sure does NOW.  These "Cuties" have no trademarked figures, and that is fine -they are cheaper without the licensing.  But, if you are looking for Sesame Street figures or Mickey mouse, or whatever, you won't find them here.Build quality doesn't seem THAT different from Pampers.  I studied them side by side, and measured the pads, and stretched the elastic, and I couldn't see any discernible difference (other than the lack of a pee strip, and that the Pampers brand has a light webbing on the inside.  Not sure why that is there, but perhaps it's too keep the wet filled diaper slightly away from the skin?The price is right. Right now these diapers are about 75% the cost of comparable Pampers diapers.  This is a big deal if you are looking to keep the cost as low as possible.  I see no reason for not trying these diapers if cost is an issue for you.The pads are not quite as absorbent as Pampers, but they seem pretty close.  I only detect a very slight difference in thickness, and had I not the Pampers version nearby I might not have noticed.  However, performance has not suffered.  I probably would just not use them as OVERNIGHT diapers.  (I actually use the Huggies Overnights for this.)Overall, these diapers have no noticeable flaws to me.  Were I starting diapers for the first time I'd probably give these (or a similar generic) a shot.

The base of the heater is at a sharp angle and cannot stand up on its own.  This was done on purpose so that you didn't get the itch to dual purpose this heater and use it as a space heater in another room.  (It is so tall and thin I imagine this would be a fire hazard, as when I tested it on the ground --pointing up-- it did not turn off automatically.  Putting that into perspective, this is a GREAT design.  It's like making a toy too big for an infant's mouth -you effectively design away the danger.  Nice.Anyway, this is a modern looking, and very simple to install heater.  It comes with the required hardware to hang it, and, most conveniently, comes with a temporary/disposable level with holes in ends which show you EXACTLY where to drill the screws so that the unit is perfectly level on the wall.  Very nice.It also is pretty intuitive to use, and comes with a remote control to adjust the heat from across the room.  (And conveniently, the batteries are included).The display on this thing is extremely generous.  HUGE, and I mean HUGE numbers are displayed which you can see from across the room.  This is EXACTLY what I want to see from a heater I have tucked in a well under-heated laundry room in near darkness.The cord on the back initially seems too short but give it a hard pull and it extends a couple more feet.  It is not as long as I would want it, as you have to be pretty close to an outlet to mount it, but I imagine this is also designed for safety.  You cannot have the risk of tripping on the cord, were it to be long enough to touch the floor, because the heater would probably fly right off the wall and crash to the floor.  (Only two screws hold the 9 pound item to the wall.)The heater is pretty quiet and when you turn it off it actually runs for a bit to basically get rid of the excess heat.  Just like some of the modern ovens, the fan will then turn itself off when the core temperature of the heating elements has decreased to a safe level.l I thought the design of this heater to be excellent, and the heater to be very versatile and easy to use.  Recommended.

I have purchased three (non wood) "North States Safety Gate" products in the past, and have used them all over my house to prevent my toddler from going up stairs, and between certain rooms.  These Munchkin gates are very similar in style to the gates that I have but are a higher-end LOOKING gate with basically the same functions. However, there are two main differences: first, the center piece is brown (which is fine), but the other difference is that it is an AUTO-CLOSE gate.  THAT is a nice feature.  I am always closing the gates in front of or behind my child.  (I DO really like this addition.)Personally, however, the auto-close feature is not enough for me to pay 40% more for a gate with the same basic functionality that I have been using previously.Yes, I like Munchkin products -I use their tableware, their silverware, and assorted other items.  However, I think this gate is a little over-priced (and so I only give it 4 stars out of five).However, if cost is NOT an issue, and you really like the wooden centerpiece, then I would say it really is a five star gate.  It is relatively easy to install (once you know what you are doing) and it comes with two extensions which will allow you to put the gate in a wider doorway, or at the top of some wider stairs.  And, most importantly for me, this gate is a pressure gate -which means you do not have to drill holes in your wall, or in your doorway or in your bannister -you can apply these gates, and twist the tighteners over and over -which will extend the gate wider and wider and will eventually cause the gate to lock when closed* and seal most gaps.  (*Note, when you first put the gate in a doorway it looks like something is wrong with it -the opening is way too wide and the gate doesn't lock closed.  This is because you need to tighten the gate at least a couple of inches and then the gate edges {which lock closed} get closer and closer and closer together.  Then, at the end of the tightening you know you are done because the gate locks tight.)Recommended.

This is heavy duty duct tape!  From the minute you try to peel it off the roll, to the moment when you start cutting it with scissors, it is abundantly clear that this is some super strong adhesive tape!It is very, very sticky!  It is very, very thick! It is very, very hard to tear! (In fact, you cannot really TEAR it, you have to cut it with scissors.)This is not tape that you want to put somewhere and remove later -this is the tape you use when Armageddon comes, and you need to tape a knife to a broom handle to scare away intruders.  (If you remove the tape later you risk the intruders rushing you when you only have a broom, but more importantly, you will leave a sticky residue on your broom that your spouse will not appreciate when she comes home if Armageddon has not yet occurred! AND, believe me, she really will not care about your Armageddon broom story...)This is the tape that you'd use to tape a pig upside down to the back of a donkey.  No, I don't know why you'd do that, I only mention it in case you HAD to do it --then THIS would be the tape that you'd use.All in all I recommend this tape highly, and it is truly what I would call "industrial tape".  It is super strong, and super sticky.  If I were a contractor, I imagine that this would be the tape I'd use.

These are a throwback to another era.  They look "vintage" and I think they are much more interesting than the standard plastic numbers (that are usually single color, but without any decoration).  Though not perfect, they do offer an alternative to the typical mass produced equivalents of our era, and give your child something else to focus on, other than the numbers themselves.  This is because each of the plywood backed tiles has a specific illustration corresponding to the number written on the wood.  Almost all are animal related (bunnies, flamingos, etc...) but there are a couple of others (people & fruits) which fill out the collection.  This is more important for this NUMBER set, as unlike with the LETTER sets which allow you to make words, you can't really do anything with the numbers other than look at them.  Therefore, I found that the illustrations helped keep interest from my little one, and will probably extend the longevity of these magnets with him.What I didn't like, however, is that the plastic cover of the wooden box broke off two sharp plastic shards almost immediately, and we had to throw the box and its cover to prevent further breakage, or swallowing of the broken pieces.One more thing, since these are thin plywood backed with a vinyl type magnet, they are not very super strong.  If these are scattered on your carpet and you happen to dance across them in the middle of the night -you know, the "ouch-ouch-ouch-lego-stepping-dance", you'll hear some bending and cracking.  In my case, though none of the pieces broke, they bent slightly, but I was able to rebend them without too much damage.Overall, a nice alternative to more modern designs.

I have used a total of four different brands of car seats in the past, to include Chicco, Evenflo, and Britax (2 models).  And now with this Graco seat I feel I have seen most of what typical car seats have to offer.  I think that overall this is a very good model and one that provides reasonable protection for the money with only a couple of drawbacks, and at a great price that is only about 60% of the cost of the premium models.  It is lightweight, pretty durable, obviously well padded around the head area for side impact collisions, and not complicated to install (though it isn't necessarily EASY to do so).  Other than a harder-than-it-needs-to-be installation, a tough to unhook chest strap, and the lack of a head tether option (when REAR facing) I am pretty happy with this model.PROS:+++ LIGHTWEIGHT.  Very easy to carry.  I didn't feel like it was too bulky or heavy.+++ VERY WELL PADDED AROUND HEAD.  This is comparable to many of the more expensive models.  Very nice.  They did not skimp out on the head protection.  You are getting a safe seat.++ HAS A CUP HOLDER.  For a toddler this is a nice addition, because my little one occasionally drops his water off to the side and can't reach it, and I don't have this option on some of the other seats I have used.++ UNCOMPLICATED INSTALL.  Though you need a lot of strength to pull the final strap it is not complicated HOW to do it.  They did a good job making this simple.CONS:--- DIFFICULT TO TIGHTEN LATCH STRAPS.  Though it is really easy to click on the latch straps, it is a little weird because there is only ONE tightener for both straps.  The strap for one has no tightener, then goes through the seat to the other latch strap on the other side, and THAT side has the tightener.  I feel like I am a pretty fit male and I had difficulty tightening this strap.  I spent five minutes pulling on it, and leaning on the seat, and reading the instructions until I felt confident that THAT really was about as tight as I was going to get it, and that the seat still was going to move a little in either direction.  (This is where the head tether really would have made this seat more secure and further limited movement).  Anyway, you have to press down on the center of the seat as hard as you can, and then pull up on the tightening strap as hard as you can, and it doesn't appear like anything is happening, but it eventually does (but not really noticeably).  I found this unsatisfying, but then, I guess, having only one tension lock is probably why this seat is more affordable.-- HEAD TETHER NOT USABLE REAR FACING. I always use a tether on the top of the seat and hook it to my car ceiling anchor.  This is the most safe installation of your seat, and really prevents the seat from moving from side to side, and will take most of the stress off of the seat in a collision, as the straps act like springs to break a lot of the impact.  However, instead of two straps hooked to the top back sides of your car seat which cross around the front and meet in a "v" on top of the seat (and away from your child's head) this seat only has a single strap directly OVER the seat, which means that it is physically not possible to use a head tether with this seat in the rear facing mode (and the seat instructions say that the tether CANNOT be used REAR facing).  (For a point of comparison, my instructions for another brand of car seat say "NEVER use the seat without the head tether, as the full safety protection is diminished otherwise. This is just a "scare" warning, but interesting nonetheless.) The lack of the head tether renders the seat much less desirable to me, personally, for a child under two years, unless it is only for occasional (and not daily use).  However, once you turn the seat around the head tether goes backwards, and works fine.  I personally really don't like this design, because your seat moves a lot more without the tether and any side to side movement is less safe than no movement.-- DIFFICULT TO RELEASE LATCH STRAPS.  Instead of a push/click latch release, these latches are hooks with tension bars.  This means they latch on really easily and safely, but if your latches (like in some cars) are really buried down in the seat, it is difficult to get your fingers in there and depress the tension bar to unclick your latch.  If this going to be a problem for you I recommend buying another seat like any of the Britax models (which have a very simple latch release system).- CHEST LOCK TAKES A LOT OF FINGER PRESSURE TO UNLOCK.  I did not like this; I had to pinch the heck out of the buckle to unhook it from my child, and it was a lot harder to do than with more expensive models.  I really hope they re-engineer this piece in newer models.Overall I would give this seat 3 STARS.  It is not a bad seat at all, but its difficulty in unhooking, and without a top tether (when REAR facing), I wouldn't buy it for daily use (unless using a top tether is just not practicable in your car, or for you, for whatever reason).  However, if only using it FORWARD FACING, I give this seat FOUR stars, as the overall safety is excellent in that direction.

I saw a commercial potato slicer once, it looked pretty similar to this and was permanently mounted on the side of a wooden table in a kitchen.  That thing was more heavy duty, and had a larger mouth -and it would cut whole potatoes in one smooth motion; no trimming or precutting required.  It was so easy to do repetitively that there was a bucket below it to catch the dozens or so of potatoes that were cut to make the house fries.  Unfortunately, though, THIS is not that same quality.  Do not be misled.  This is an amateur version at probably 1/3 the price.I was really only interested in juicing, but when I looked at this as a potato cutter, I was still disappointed.  I already have a hand potato dicer which I got at  the cost and it does the exact same job as this one, though the leverage on the large one makes it a lot easier to use.  But my big complaint still stands -the mouth is not large enough to consistently cut potatoes in one go.  You have to slice them in half to really ensure success, and this seems like a waste.  For the money you pay the mouth should have been a little bigger.  But, that is the price you pay when you try to make a machine that does 3 things.  Had it been a dedicated potato cutter, you probably would have had a better machine.On to the apple cutter.  Though it seemed to work fine, I thought switching the attachments was a little bit of a hassle.  They could have made it simpler, and spent a little more time designing the machine to be really user friendly.  It worked fine, but I didn't see much advantage over the flat apple corer that I keep in my drawer.  I mean, it isn't like I need to ever cut more than one apple at a time, so I didn't think this function made much sense.And finally, the juicer.  This is where the machine did well.  The attachments are a lot simpler to use -the bottom just twists and locks in place intuitively and the juicer is mostly effective.  A couple of the oranges looked like they had a little wasted pulp, but when I tried to get the last little bits out it really wasn't worth it for the effort required.  I must say, finally the machine lived up to what I expected.  I had no issues in juicing, and the machine was heavy duty and stable.Other notes:The machine is very sturdy.  It is cast iron, and you can tell.  It is not going to tip over or snap when you use it.The grip is made of rubber which is nice for comfort, and for non-slippage.The cast iron is enameled.  This will make it less likely to rust.The rubber pad on the base is easy to take off for cleaning.  It really took no effort.Final thoughts: overall I thought it not perfectly suited to potato cutting, and it didn't make sense to me for apple coring, but when it came to juicing it did a pretty good job. I would not recommend it for those who really want to make fries, but if you want to juice, it might be worth a shot.UPDATE:It is now a couple of weeks since I started using this and I have to bring up another observation.  I just used this to cut smaller red potatoes into strips. Although initially very excited that it seemed to be cutting pretty on the smaller than usual sized potatoes I quickly had a much less favorable impression.  This is because the blades actually shaved off pieces of plastic when I depressed the handle all the way, and I had to spend 10 minutes searching for the 6-8 tiny pieces that came off and attached to the side of the starchy wet potatoes.  AAAAAAAAAAH!!!!! What a downer.  I realized this occurred because the blades do not align perfectly with the other side of the equation, the plastic PUSHER piece.  There is a little too much wiggle when fully tightened, so that sometimes when the blades comes down they don't quite come down easily.  This is a MAJOR disappointment and I must say that I'll probably never use it as a potato cutter again, only a juicer.

This is my third Britax car seat, and I have been using the others for a couple of years, and I now have this newer model, the G.4.1., which I have been using for about a month.  (Honestly, though, I really don’t see much difference AT ALL between the two.  Well, aside from one obvious one.  The color of the handle and a couple of other parts on the 4.1 are bright red.  It appears that this was done for style purposes, and possibly to draw your attention to some of the moving parts so you can figure it out more easily.  Other than that, however, I don’t see any advantage of one over the other, though I suppose the 4.0 model is probably now discontinued.)I (so far) have only used it rear facing, and (when not in a rental car) I use it with the top anchor strap which hooks to the rear ceiling of my car.  I use it both in a Honda Civic and a Honda CRV and it fits fine in both in the center seat, with just enough room for people to sit on either side.  (Unlike with the most expensive model of Britax seat, which has additional special side impact protection –and juts out to the sides- this seat fit without cramping the space of the other rear passengers.)One note about the anchor strap (which attaches to the top of the car seat, and hooks either to the ceiling of your vehicle, the back of the car seats, or the floor of your vehicle):  In the CRV there is easily enough space to put in and take out my child without undue effort (below the anchor straps).  In the lower ceiling Civic, however, it is a tighter fit, and I usually have to lift my son up and bring him horizontal above the seat before I put him in (because it is tricky to insert him under the ceiling anchor straps).  He doesn’t mind at all, but I imagine this to be a little more difficult for my wife when she drives my car –but not a concern at all in the larger car.  (To be clear, though, this is in no way a car seat issue, but rather a make of the car issue…) I tell you all this because I am a real fan of the anchor strap.  The seat doesn’t wiggle at all from side to side, and I can totally visualize how this V strap is going to hold the car seat perfectly in place in an accident, while still allowing needed movement to cushion the blow.  There is also going to be a whole lot less chance of car seat failure when using this strap because it will act like a spring and take a lot of tension out of the huge jerk that will occur in a really sudden stop.  (Britax also advertises that the strap will degrade in usage immediately in an accident, to take some of the impact out of the crash.  In other words it will start to tear itself down, and rip and fray, with that energy going to destroying the strap and not the car seat… kind of like the crumple zone in the front of the car…)What about installation? Well, I’ve installed it about a dozen times and after the first couple of times I had no issues.  It is a little heavy but you are paying for a really solid protection system for your child, and that is the result.  If you buy a cheaper seat it will be lighter, but it might not give as much protection, OR, the seat may not be as easily adjustable.  That said, I always use the LATCH system and I find it works really well.  It IS a little tricky, though, when you have taken out your car seat and you proceed to reinstall it in a different car (or in the same car at a later time).  This is because you now have to loosen the straps holding the latch anchors enough to allow you to clip them back on, but if you are not installing the seat frequently, this won’t be a big deal.  (On the flip side, however, this seat has never loosened, so I don’t worry about re-tightening it all the time.  A few minutes of annoyance in loosening straps and retightening them after the latch anchoring, and this car seat works like a dream).Would I buy it again? Yes, absolutely.  (However, I slightly prefer the Pavilion over the Boulevard, because the ‘Click Safe’ feature works pretty well –but I can live without it.)  Recommended.

I like it.I recently bought a new couch which had been treated with a stain resistant spray.  The problem, though, is that even though it was in an empty back room and had been airing out for a few weeks, it still seemed to have a slightly stale, funky smell.  However, I sprayed the couch with a light to medium amount of spray (because I worried a little about overdoing it and possibly staining the new fabric), and left it alone in the back room for a full week.  When I came back the couch didn’t have the ’off’ odor, but did have telltale traces of the pleasant Febreze smell.  So, for me at least, it worked.There are two things that are not perfect about it, though, but which are pretty minor.  First, it is super expensive –twice as much as I thought it would be- but probably because it is still under patent protection, and they can charge what they want (with no generic brands yet using the proprietary odor reduction technology).  I do think the product works, and isn’t simply just covering up a nasty smell with a more overpowering “nice” one.  (In my opinion, it is too expensive to waste on general house cleaning, so I intend to keep it for when I need to bring out the ‘big guns’, like the day before a party, or when relatives come over to stay…)Second, you have to take a little care when using the product –it is not aerosolized so you have to manually “spritz” it to get it to release the mist, and have to apply just the right amount of pressure so as to not overpower the nozzle and cause drippage of the really powerful scent.  (The downside would be that this drip might possibly stain what you are spraying.)Overall, however, it seemed to work well, and I would buy this in the future to eliminate annoying odors on trouble areas of furniture in my house.

This is the first OXO product that I felt was junky.  I've had a much higher quality OXO (side opening) can opener for many years and I thought this (top opening) can opener was significantly inferior.  In fact, I was quite surprised at how little this reminded me of the typically superior OXO brand.So, OXO is known for being a simple to use, high quality, and expensive product most usable by old people or those with arthritis.  For those not in these two categories this product is just easy to use and a good buy.  Unfortunately, however, I felt that this product fell a little flat.  The handles (instead of the typical grippy soft rubber) are, instead, hard plastic, and the cutting mechanism is no more than average.For the first time I was not able to differentiate an OXO product from generic items from other manufacturers.  There was nothing about this that lent itself to feeling grippy, to feeling high quality, to feeling like "yes, I spent a lot of money on this, but it is clearly superior".  This product just felt like nothing worth mentioning.  It is a can opener -decidedly average, and bright light blue.

These are well designed: simple, easy to clean, and colorful.  They also work.  However, since we haven't forced the sippy cup to trainer cup transition, my son tried these for a while and went back to the sippy cup, because these were a little more work that he was used to.  That said, when we make the move permanent, we'll consider getting some more of these and use them exclusively, while retiring the sippy cup.One thing, it isn't as if the liquid just flows out of the cup effortlessly.  Basically the child needs to use about the same amount of suction as it would with a straw (between two really close rows of plastic) and the liquid comes out, breaking the tension that holds the liquid in the cup.  When the suction stops, so too does the liquid.  The other thing, your child needs to know how to suck.  My child had no idea how to use the cup even though he'd used cups with straws before.  I had to show him for a couple of minutes where he had to put his lips, and how he had to get the liquid.  It wasn't a big deal, and he had it down within a minute, but it isn't as if the liquid flowed without conscious effort or thought.I like the handles on this version.  I can really see using these at the dinner table when handles get messy and the cup gets slippery, but I'd also buy ones without handles to use without food.  (The handles are permanently attached with these cups, so you'll have to buy the other version if you don't want them.)Overall I'd recommend these.  I have no real issues, and I like the brand.

These are very ecofriendly and made with ingredients that are very low on the `parent worry' scale.  I don't know if I would purchase them myself because of the slightly annoying packaging, but more so that they weren't as wet as I would have liked, but they were definitely high quality.PROS:+++ NO ARTIFICIAL COLORS OR SCENTS.  I want as few scents and artificial ingredients in my products, and these fit the bill nicely.++ NICE, SOFT TEXTURE & THICK.  They really are velvety smooth, and I wasn't worried about any abrasion.  I never felt that the quality of the wipe was ever in question.+ THEY ARE A GOOD SIZE.  Yes, they could have a bigger package, but their somewhat slim size makes it a lot easier for me to dump a pack in a diaper bag and not have to worry about using some tiny travel pack which has already lost all its moisture.CONS:-- DISLIKE THE OPENING ON THE PACKAGE.  There is only a plastic piece of tape that you open and close over the opening.  Technically, it works, but I much, much, much prefer the snap/click openings of other brands.  I find that I can't leave a partially pulled out wipe to be pushed back in (with the lid closed on top of it) like I can with other brands; I need to pull that last wipe out entirely before I can seal the package.  After reflection I suppose the design of the package may also have been done like this to be as ecofriendly as possible, and I respect that.  I didn't lower my rating on the product because of this, since I probably would get used to this `new normal' over time, and probably wouldn't notice it as much down the line.- COULD BE A LITTLE WETTER.  I wish they were just a little wetter.  I found myself having to wet the wipes sometimes to get the cleaning power that I wanted.  Sometimes when I had to scrub more than I liked to clean some dried poop  I felt I was going to cause abrasion without additional wetness.  This was rare, but memorable enough to be noticeable.- A LITTLE PRICEY.  You get what you pay for, though.  No complaints regarding the quality or the safety of the product.I love that it is fragrance free.  I like that it is compostable.  I can get over the price, but I'm not sold on the container packaging.  Worth trying, though, if you want an ECO friendly solution -they may work for you.

I am totally surprised by the rave reviews this book got.  Let me say that I am a horror story lover and was a Mark Lukens fan since Ancient Enemy.  If you look at the reviews, you will see that Ancient Enemy hooked a lot of readers.  This is my fourth book by Mr. Lukens and I'm sorry to say my least favorite.  He has not ever come close to the suspenseful horror of that book.  I read The Exorcist's Apprentice, to which I gave 4 stars.  It was interesting, but lacked the kind of terror that the plot should have contained.  Then I read Night Terrors, which read more like a thriller, with supernatural overtones, rather disappointing, to which I gave 3 stars.  I was tempted to give this book only two stars, but gave Mr. Lukens an extra star, just because it was him and because the book held my interest, somewhat, even though I found it getting sillier and sillier.  I like stories of people who wake up not knowing who they are and trying to solve the mystery.  Good beginning.  He is led to a town where a past serial killer has killed many people and then himself.  The people he encounters are somehow spooked out by him.  So far, so good.  He meets a girl and they really hit it off and begin to fall in love.  Okay.  But, and I really hate this, every other chapter or so is involved with a dream about a cut-up scary man with mutilated fingers, dripping blood, wanting to show him the answers he is looking for.  I find this touch, and the way it was handled, very melodramatic and clichéd.  He is delivered a suitcase that may solve who he is and he puts it under his bed and never looks into it.  Really?  Then he finally decides who he is and we get to the totally ludicrous ending, where people become other people and the silliness just abounds!  That made me really angry and tempted to give this 2 stars.  Totally stupid ending.  Even the characters, themselves, were just cardboard stereotypes.  I am being generous in giving 3 stars, and may decide to stop getting books by this author.  He just doesn't seem to have lived up to the promise of Ancient Enemy.

I usually like to write my review early on, but this month found me finishing a book I was in the middle of, so I didn't get to this choice right away.  Besides, I was burnt so badly with last month's choice that I decided to read some reviews before I made my choice. But I was unprepared for how quickly this book would get so many reviews and such rave ones. That made it a no-brainer for me as to which book to choose. I generally don't go for political thrillers, but the politics in this book, though crucial to the plot, actually are not present through most of the book. The themes of computer hacking and chasing after clues trump actual politics through most of it. Computer geeks who love mysteries will really go for this book. Reading the other reviews, there's not much left to say to add to them. It is important to me to like at least one of the main characters. The main character of Gibson Vaughn is so likeable, and his quest to find his missing 14-year old friend, Suzanne, who disappeared 10 years ago, is so absorbing and grabbing, that I found myself glued to this book. As had been said, the characters are well-developed and this is no formula thriller. The twists and turns leave you guessing continually. Often, I don't care as much for a book, if it gets too complex that I get totally confused. Not so here. With all its twists and turns, everything fits into place and I never had the feeling of being lost or confused. It is a complex puzzle that is simply amazing to behold, a joy to follow and never leaves you in a state of frustration. This is one of the best Kindle Firsts I have ever read and I am so glad to have chosen it. I can't believe that this a debut novel for Mr. FitzSimmons. Bravo to you!  You have created a winner. We Amazon Prime members were lucky to have been able to read this, and for free no less. This should be a hard-cover best seller at all the book stores. Fellow readers - if you haven't picked a Kindle First yet for this month, and love thrillers, please read this book.  It's a winner!

First of all, I have to say that, although a horror fan, I am not a fan of zombie books.  I watch the Walking Dead mostly because my girlfriend loves it and I've gotten attached to the characters.  But this is a zombie book like no other.  It takes place after the zombie apocalypse has already taken place and two key figures are going on trial, while a new threat suddenly emerges. one that could wipe out the planet.  It is an unusual and welcome change of pace for this genre.  I enjoyed it, surprisingly.  The characters were well-developed and the action was well thought out and suspenseful.  I subtracted a star because I found some dead spots in the action.  The protracted portion where they were leaving the city in search of the lab was very boring, in my opinion and dragged on.  It could have used a lot of editing.  Likewise the love scenes.  I didn't read this for the romance and I think that if you're going to write a suspenseful horror story, you should minimize the sex scenes.  We could have gotten the fact that they loved each other without so many intimate details.  This is not a romance book, and I skimmed through most of that.  Otherwise, this book was a lot of fun.  Just to comment on one other reviewer's criticism about aspirin, I have a perfectly normal friend who gets sleepy from aspirin and these people have had hardly any medication available to them.  I don't think it's far-fetched.  Though the ending indicated more to come, and I see there are others in this series, I will probably stop with this book, as I mostly read free books (mostly Kindle Firsts and Lender's Library) unless given a gift of Amazon dollars.  You can certainly go on to the other books in the series, but I think this works okay as a stand-alone (as long as you understand that more goes on in this story).

Let me start off by saying that this is the first pedometer that I have ever used. I was looking for something cheap that would count my steps and tell me the distance I have walked. I haven't been able to make a test of just how accurate it is, but subjectively, it seems quite accurate. It not only tells me my steps, it tells me the distance I have walked, how many steps were aerobic, the average walking speed, the calories burnt and possibly more I'm forgetting. It has a belt clip that works fine, but I would get the strap they recommend to go with it, as I've found that if I sit or bend a certain way, it can come off of the belt. It runs on batteries, so I also got the pack of batteries that they recommend. I am totally satisfied with this pedometer. Cheap, accurate (from what I can tell), easy to use (you just have to put in some information, like your weight and height, and calibrate your stride (which was not difficult). It resets itself automatically every midnight and shows you the past week, so you can compare days. It is so cheap and effective, I could not be happier.  Highly recommended.

Let me say I was a fan of Mark Lukens after reading Ancient Enemy, to which I gave 5 stars. I thought it was a terrific supernatural thriller. Even to the end, it had a lot of guessing and things left unsaid. I love that. I next read the Exorcist's Apprentice and really liked that one, too.  I don't remember if I gave that 4 or 5 stars. I was expecting as much with Night Terrors. In fact, I have a whole bunch of Mark's books on my wish list. I intend to read The Summoning, next. So this 3-star review is somewhat a statement of my expectations of Mr. Lukens, as it is an overall rating. I didn't feel it was up to his best. Understand that 3 stars means I thought it was okay. It is not a very negative review. I just expected more. Though there was the supernatural element (somewhat) in that the protagonist, Tara, had psychic powers and especially connected with the killer and his killings. But after that it really was a typical serial killer suspense novel. It followed a very formulaic plot and I even guessed the killer way ahead of time. It was not that hard, if you've read a lot of thrillers. The writing was good. The characters were fine. The idea was a bit cliché and that already made it hard to stand out. Given the premise, I'm not sure what he could have done differently, but it read like many other thrillers I have read. Not to say it was not enjoyable, just a bit too predictable and pat. And far from the supernatural mystery of Ancient Enemy. If you're looking for an easy read serial killer book, with psychic overtones, you may give this four stars. If you've read many of those kind of books and you're looking for something like Ancient Enemy, go with my 3 stars. It's okay, but not great. I really feel bad giving Mr. Lukens only 3 stars and hope for more from the next book of his. (I guess I'm in the minority on this review.)

I usually only give one star to books that are so amateurish that I'm am totally embarrassed to read them. Books that sound like they are written by a teenager, without any training. Otherwise, I usually give at least two stars. I can't do that, in this case. I really hated this book.  I wish that I had not been so impulsive as to picking a book the moment they came out. If I had waited a day, I would have read the review by C.R. Hurst, a top-100 reviewer and amply qualified as a writing instructor and student of literature. He said this book was bizarre, incomprehensible, long-winded and pretentious. I totally agree with him, with the exception that, though not understanding the extremely technical scientific jargon, I was managing to get the gist of the story, even though written in such a strange and confusing manner. Unfortunately, unlike him, I did not give up. I thought that all of this intelligent, albeit indecipherable, writing would eventually lead to a wow of a climax. I not only found reading this book to be thoroughly torturous, but found the ending to be the most disappointing and confusing ending I have ever encountered. If you read some of the other reviews, you see that even the good reviews said this was no pleasure book, no walk in the park, but very demanding stuff. I didn't read all of the reviews, but one that gave spoilers obviously didn't understand the ending and had various interpretations. After the torture of reading this pretentious novel which, by the way, read more like a textbook than a novel, I should at least have had the pleasure of a profound ending.  No such luck. If you are one of the lucky ones that have not yet picked a book, please skip this one! That is unless you love difficult, bizarre, pretentious and totally confusing books with no ending. Well, on the good side, it is over. I can go on to something enjoyable. That would be pretty much anything other than this.

Though these are not my cup of tea, and I didn't care for them, I am reviewing this for readers who take to this genre.  I like horror and often get free horror story anthologies to read at the end of each month, when I am through with my Kindle First and Kindle Prime Lender's Library books.  My favorite was Tales From the Mist.  Other collections proved to be more flash horror stories, very short, dark and pure shock value.  While these three stories, all concerning witches, were a bit longer than the usual flash stories, they were similar in style.  Not what I generally like.  The writing was good and the reading easy, but really for pure dark shock value.  If you like that kind of thing, give this four stars.  The second one bothered me in that it had no ending.  You were supposed to imagine what happened.  The other two were not bad for the genre.  I prefer longer, more developed stories that are not as dark and shocking.  If this is what you are looking for, go for it.

I've read some of the other reviews of this book and agree to a large extent.  So this review may seem redundant.  I had written to Amazon a couple of years ago, complaining that "If I Never Get Back" is not on Kindle.  It has been one of my favorite books.  I think last year or this year they put it on Kindle and, when I discovered it, immediately bought it and reread it.  I knew he had also written this book, but had no idea it had anything to do with the first book.  Then I discovered it was a sequel to the first.  Even though I read the reviews and knew, generally what to expect, I got it anyway.  I agree with the reviewer who said that this is best for those who have read the first book.  It is really a continuation of that, and might not stand up so well on its own.  This could get no less than four stars from me because the writing is quite good and so are the characterizations.  I knew there was less baseball in this, but didn't realize that there was virtually no baseball in it.  Likewise, it (by definition) lacked the aura of suddenly discovering yourself in the previous century and having to adapt to it and learn about it.  It lacks much of the charm of the first book and reads more like an adventure book and love story.  Instead of baseball being the focus, there are train hoppers, Indians, striking miners, Molly Maguires, hucksters and the bad guys from the first novel.  Mark Twain is visited again and even given advice on writing Tom Sawyer.  If you take it for what it is, it is an excellent novel, though I think you have to have read the first one.  I just missed the charm and the baseball theme of the first one.  The main reason for reading this is to see the outcome of the love story and how Sam Fowler's life finally finds it's way.  I hope I have been of some help, even it it's only to corroborate what others have already said.

I will not write one of my usual long reviews.  This was simply one of the best horror novels I've read on Kindle, since Andrew Van Wey's "Forsaken."  Unfortunately, I did not have a lot of reading time and had to read this over a week or more.  As it has various stories that all tie in, it is best to read this in a short time.  Bentley's writing is quite good and he does a good job of shifting between the first and third person narration.  Sure, it's reminiscent of some of King.  Dan's (the protagonist's) brother, Barbie, a mentally damaged individual with special powers, reminded me of Duditz in Stephen King's "Dreamcatcher."  But this was an excellent book in its own right.  The characters were well drawn and the individual stories that finally come together at the end were truly horrifying.  Someone said, in their review, that this was his first book.  If so, bravo.  It seemed like it was written by a veteran horror writer.  I wholeheartedly recommend it to horror lovers.

I usually write long reviews, but I'll try to be brief, here (never happens). I was unsure which Kindle First to pick, as several seemed promising. I love cases with amnesia and past mysteries to solve, so I chose this. Let me say that 3 stars is not a bad review. It just seems bad when so many books get 4 stars and up. I found this book passably enjoyable and was not unhappy I chose it. I would not give this a negative (one or two star) review. But after getting a bit into it, I decided it would definitely not be a rave 5 star book. The story moved along at a good pace. But I had some problems with it, and opted to go for only three stars. First of all, I didn't care for the bouncing around between many different characters from chapter to chapter that the book started out doing. A lot of books do that, but I find it annoying. It settled down a great deal later in the book and didn't jump around as much. Then, there were two male involvements with the heroin Kate/Catelin. The sparring between the two I found very annoying. Then the book got extremely complicated, with so many characters (most of them seedy), that I actually forgot, at the end, how some of them even played into the story, and had to go back to get the picture. You also had to suspend quite a bit of disbelief. Finally, I was not happy with the ending, not who lived and who died, simply Kate/Catelin's decision. Sounds like I had a lot of problems with the book, but it was not that bad. It moved at a fast pace and was reasonably interesting, just not one of my favorite thrillers.

I agree with C.R. Hurst, the first reviewer I read, that this was a difficult choice for a Kindle First.  I was not interested at all in the dysfunctional family drama, the legal thriller which looked a bit boring to me, and the silly-looking teenage supernatural hunter book one of a series.  That left this psychological thriller as the only choice.  It is really misnamed as a psychological thriller, as it should really be labeled as a romantic thriller.  I was not totally unaware of this, having read the summary and editor's review, but I was hoping that the romance would be downplayed.  I was wrong.  This was a romantic thriller, through and through.  Not really my style.  So if you like romance, drama relating to love-hate relationships of fathers and sons, fathers and teenage daughters, etc., and like a serial killer thriller mixed in, this is a book for you.  By romance, I'm talking the whole nine yards - she noticing his biceps, deeply tanned skin, masculine appeal and yearning for what she has denied herself all these year, etc., this is it.  As another reviewer said, this book was similar to "The One That Got Away" in it's plot of the one serial killer victim that escaped, but with serious PTSD which she fights to overcome.  I also agree that this one was richer in its plot and character development.  But I think it has too many flaws to get the full five stars.  It is ridiculous that a just retired cop would lure the killer he still believes to be on the loose to the home of the victim that got away (not going into how he knew that) and not warn her or anyone else there of the danger. I don't buy his disease as affecting this decision and being a good excuse.  I also think that the playing out of the plot was somewhat predictable and the ending too pat.  The characters were well-drawn, but too formulaic to me. I was also frustrated with the way characters knew things that they kept to themselves, when being open about their knowledge and their feelings might have solved a lot of things.  I find that type of plot line too frustrating.Yet, there are many readers who love books about strong female lead characters that overcome tremendous odds to survive.  Many eat this kind of book up. If that is your thing, then this book is for you, if you don't mind the drawbacks I mentioned.  It is a plot line that has great appeal to many readers and if you are one of those, consider this a four-star, or even five-star, review.  I also agree that there was rich texture in the depiction of the surroundings, which is the rugged Canadian northwest, which adds flavor to the book.  I was certainly not bored with it and three stars is not a negative review.  The writing is good, though not extremely incisive, and it holds your interest.  I really don't think it covers new ground, though.  So, in the end, don't go by the number of stars I gave this book, go by the things I've said about it, and the other reviews you've read and if this is your kind of book, go for it.  But if romance is not your thing, skip it.  This is not a true psychological thriller, like the ones by Andrew E. Kaufman, which are generally darker in nature, and without the romantic involvement.  I hope I've been helpful in your decision-making.  Good luck.

Let me start off by saying that I'm a big Andrew Van Wey fan, even though he hasn't written all that much, yet.  I was hooked after reading Forsaken.  It is one of my favorite horror novels.  I immediately bought all of Mr. Van Wey's books.  His writing is so mature, so developed, as if written by a much older and more experience writer.  He reminds me so much of early Stephen King (when he was still writing horror).  This short novella fits that statement very well, reminding me of "It," even though this is about 120 pages and "It" was 1400 pages.  It is about three young boys I would say about 10 years old.  The beginning is character development, which Van Wey does so well, much like King.  Then they go up to the tree house and the horror begins.  Even though it's about young boys, this book is definitely not a young reader's book, but a book for adults who don't mind seeing through the eyes of young boys.  The ending took me by surprise.  Let's say it's darker than King.  But he gives you the choice of stopping at that ending or going on to Book Two.  I already bought that, so I definitely will.  My only disappointment is that there will be apparently a Book Three and a Book Four.  I prefer stand-alone novels to series' that may go on and on.  Of course, I'm going to have to read all of them.  Andrew, please write another book like Forsaken!  But for a short dark horror, this is great (and you can go on, if you want to.)

I just finished A. G. Riddle's Departure as a monthly Prime Lending Library book.  In one sentence I loved this book.  I won't go into all of the plot details, since you're probably read them in both the plot summary and many other reader reviews.  I loved the premise, loved the plot development and loved the characters.  I will compare this to Manney's Revolution, which I just read prior to this, as a Kindle First.  They were both sci-fi novels and both included elite clubs with global aims and main characters that either want to thwart them or join them.  But where I gave Manney's novel only two stars because I thought it was overly technical, overly wordy, totally far-fetched and with a main character that was not so likeable, I thought this shorter book was much more enthralling.  (I have to admit that, inexplicable to me, Revolution got very good reviews.)  It was shorter, much less caught up in its own brilliance and technology, and had characters that you got to care for.  That made a big difference to me.  I am certainly not a romance novel lover, but the romantic involvement and the emotions in this book made it far more interesting to me.  One reader said that he lost interest as the characters' emotions gained importance toward the end of the book.  I didn't find that.  My only criticism was that the ending was a bit too mamby-pamby and lacked the impact I expected from this high octane plot.  Nevertheless, I still loved this book and highly recommend it to sci-fi lovers who don't mind a bit of romance and emotional involvements to be mixed in.

I agree with much of the review written by TooManyHobbies. But, whereas he/she gave it 3 stars, as an okay techno/thriller, I am subtracting a star.  I basically slogged through this book, without much enthusiasm. I am late writing this review, not only because I haven't had much time to read lately, but also because I found it very slow and monotonous, especially the first half.  I agree that the prologue was the most exciting thing in the book. It was just loaded down with too much technical jargon and I never really cared much for the main character, Peter/Tom. I found him too full of himself. He knew he was a genius and didn't hide the fact that he was the smartest person in the room. That really put me off to him. I never felt any emotional connection to the characters (with the possible exception of Talia). The science may have been accurate but it didn't make for good reading, in my opinion. And though it got into some interesting philosophical issues (re Huxley's Brave New World), this came at the very end and was lost in the science and plot turns.  The musical references were tiresome as was the Yiddish (though I have a smattering). Why is the use of songs to reference emotions a good technique, when you need a chapter at the end to explain them? I was even tired, rather than intrigued, with all of the plot twists.  The book may have had a good concept, but needed some serious editing, as it was overlong, overwordy and overblown. I will not be looking for book 2 in this series. I can't imagine why this book got so many good reviews.

First of all, let me say that I am a big fan of Andrew Van Wey, after reading Forsaken and A Feast of Rot.  His writing skills are beyond compare.  Mesmerizing!  This is a very well written short story.  Why did I subtract a star?  Because I have come to expect horror from Mr. Van Wey and this is more of a fantasy/morality tale, albeit extremely well-written.  It does come to horror at the end, but I was expecting more.  After Forsaken, which is one of my favorite horror stories, he has raised the stakes quite high.  Next, I will be reading A Hollow Dream, seasons one and two.  It seems that they are a mixture of fantasy and horror, so I will be better prepared.  It also seems A Hollow Dream may become a series.  I am rooting for more books like Forsaken.

I doubt many people will read this review or be influenced by it.  In general, people who go by these reviews, lean toward the majority viewpoint. That is why I read this book. After reading it, I am completely flawed at the many rave reviews. A really scary book? Please! This book was like a grade B horror movie. I agree with the reviewer who criticizes Mr. Lopez on his writing, saying that he simply tells you things. That is not creative writing and not what is needed here. You're supposed to be scared out of your wits because someone hears the sound of chains and a sickle?
